It develops a novel LM-related signature (LM.SIG) using scRNA-seq data, validates its predictive capacity using machine learning across multiple cancer datasets, and identifies LDHA as a key biomarker for immunotherapy response and survival, further validated through experimental studies.

title: Establishment of a cholangiocarcinoma risk evaluation model based on mucin expression levels.
main_goals: To investigate the functions of mucins on the progression of Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) and to establish a risk evaluation formula for stratifying CCA patients. The study elucidated functional mechanisms of mucins in CCA development and provided tools for risk stratification.

title: Spatiotemporal proteomic profiling of cellular responses to NLRP3 agonists.
main_goals: This paper maps subcellular proteome changes in response to NLRP3 inflammasome agonists, identifying disruptions in retrograde trafficking pathways. It also characterizes NLRP3 trafficking during activation using temporal proximity proteomics, supporting a model of recruitment to endosomes. The findings aim to provide granularity to understanding NLRP3 activation and serve as a resource for cell biological research.

title: Single-cell transcriptomics reveal distinct immune-infiltrating phenotypes and macrophage-tumor interaction axes among different lineages of pituitary neuroendocrine tumors.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)', 'bulk RNA-seq', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'immunohistochemistry', 'multiplexed quantitative immunofluorescence (QIF)']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Phenotype Analysis', 'Tumor Microenvironment Analysis']
main_goals: To analyze the heterogeneity, spatial distribution, and clinical significance of macrophages in PitNETs using various techniques, revealing distinct immune microenvironment subtypes and macrophage-tumor interaction axes among different lineages. The study aims to provide insights into the control of the tumor immune microenvironment affecting PitNET development and identify potential therapeutic targets.

title: 3D reconstruction of a gastrulating human embryo.
main_goals: To construct a 3D model of a Carnegie stage 8 human embryo using high-resolution spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies cell subtypes, characterizes lineage trajectories, and maps regional signaling centers and activities during gastrulation.

title: Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptome Profiling Identifies the Transcription Factor BHLHE40 as a Driver of EMT in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the cellular mechanisms driving EMT in colorectal cancer. It identified BHLHE40 as a key transcription factor promoting EMT and liver metastasis by analyzing single-cell and spatial transcriptomic data. The findings provide insights for improving diagnosis and treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

title: Batf3<sup>+</sup> DCs and the 4-1BB/4-1BBL axis are required at the effector phase in the tumor microenvironment for PD-1/PD-L1 blockade efficacy.
biological_context: Tumor microenvironment (TME) in the context of cancer immunotherapy
data_modalities_used: ['flow cytometric analysis', 'gene-targeted mice', 'blocking antibody studies', 'immunofluorescence', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'human tumor samples']
main_goals: This paper investigates the cellular source of positive signals that reinvigorate T cells within the tumor microenvironment (TME) for PD-1/PD-L1 blockade efficacy. It identifies Batf3-lineage dendritic cells (DCs) and the 4-1BB/4-1BBL axis as essential for this process. The study highlights the importance of Batf3+ DCs and their proximity to CD8+ T cells for anti-PD-1 efficacy in human tumor samples.

title: Spatial Proteomics Reveals Alcohol-Induced Damages to the Crypts and Villi of the Mouse Small Intestine.
biological_context: Alcohol-induced damage to the mouse small intestine
main_goals: This study employed laser capture microdissection and label-free proteomics to investigate the proteomic changes in the crypts and villi of the mouse small intestine following alcohol exposure. It aimed to understand how immune-related cells in the gut are perturbed during this process. The findings reveal alcohol-induced changes in alcohol metabolism, defensin levels, lipid metabolism, and apoptosis.

title: Integrated spatial metabolomics and transcriptomics decipher the hepatoprotection mechanisms of wedelolactone and demethylwedelolactone on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
biological_context: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) induced by thioacetamide (TAA) in zebrafish
main_goals: This study investigated the impacts and mechanisms of wedelolactone (WEL) and demethylwedelolactone (DWEL) on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) using a zebrafish model. The research utilized integrated spatial metabolomics with liver-specific transcriptomics to identify distinct hepatoprotective mechanisms of WEL and DWEL.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing reveals the alterations in epithelial cells during nodular formation in benign prostatic hyperplasia.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To integrate spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing to elucidate epithelial cell alterations during nodular formation in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The study identified a specific basal epithelial cell subgroup (BE5) crucial for BPH progression through hypoxia-induced EMT and validated the role of c-Fos.

title: Integrative spatial analysis reveals a multi-layered organization of glioblastoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper defines glioma cellular states and uncovers their multi-layered organization using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics. It identifies three modes of organization: local environments enriched with single states, preferential pairing of specific states, and a global architecture composed of five layers. Hypoxia is highlighted as a key driver of this long-range organization.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals segregation of tumor cell states in glioblastoma and marked immunosuppression within the perinecrotic niche.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatial organization of tumor cell states within the glioblastoma microenvironment using spatial transcriptomics. It reveals patterns of segregation between different tumor cell states and highlights the immunosuppressive nature of perinecrotic regions.

title: Integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics analysis reveals the tumour microenvironment in patients with endometrial cancer responding to anti-PD-1 treatment.
main_goals: This study integrates single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to analyze the tumor microenvironment in patients with endometrial cancer responding to anti-PD-1 treatment. It aims to reveal the cellular composition and spatial organization that contribute to treatment response.

title: The neuroendocrine transition in prostate cancer is dynamic and dependent on ASCL1.
biological_context: Prostate cancer progression and neuroendocrine differentiation
main_goals: This study describes an in vivo platform to study the neuroendocrine transition in prostate cancer. It reveals that ASCL1+ cells arise from KRT8+ luminal epithelial cells and highlights the dynamic nature of this lineage plasticity, emphasizing the importance of therapeutic timing. The work provides a platform for identifying further drivers of lineage plasticity.

title: Multi-pronged analysis of pediatric low-grade glioma reveals a unique tumor microenvironment associated with BRAF alterations.
data_modalities_used: ['single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'cytokine analyses', 'bulk analyses']
main_goals: To characterize and understand tumor and immune cell heterogeneity across pediatric low-grade gliomas (pLGG) using a multi-pronged approach including scRNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, and cytokine analyses. The study aimed to reveal differences in the tumor microenvironment associated with genetic drivers, particularly BRAF alterations, and to inform potential therapeutic strategies.

title: Spatial enrichment and genomic analyses reveal the link of NOMO1 with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
biological_context: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) in the human motor cortex
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Burden analyses']
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the spatial enrichment of ALS-associated genes in the human motor cortex and identify novel genes linked to ALS risk. It developed a tool called SpatialE for spatial enrichment analysis and used it to analyze human motor cortex and prefrontal cortex tissues. The study identified NOMO1 as a novel ALS-associated gene, down-regulated in ALS, consistent with a loss-of-function mechanism.

title: Identification of hypoxic macrophages in glioblastoma with therapeutic potential for vasculature normalization.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'xenograft model antitumor assays', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper identifies a subset of tumor-associated macrophages (Hypoxia-TAMs) in glioblastoma localized to the peri-necrotic niche. These macrophages acquire a hypoxia response signature, destabilize tumor vasculature via adrenomedullin signaling, leading to hyperpermeability. Targeting Hypoxia-TAMs and adrenomedullin shows therapeutic potential for vasculature normalization and improved drug delivery.

title: Identification of signaling pathways that specify a subset of migrating enteric neural crest cells at the wavefront in mouse embryos.
biological_context: Mouse embryo enteric nervous system development
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', "human Hirschsprung's disease gut tissue"]
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study identifies signaling pathways governing wavefront enteric neural crest cell specification and niche interaction during mouse embryonic development. It uses single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to map these dynamics and links pathway disruptions to human Hirschsprung's disease. The research also highlights the role of these cells in shaping the gut microenvironment.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis of Pituitary Corticotroph Tumors.
main_goals: This study presents the first spatial transcriptomic analysis of pituitary corticotroph tumors (PitNETs) using formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissues. The analysis aimed to uncover spatial interactions and identify intratumor heterogeneity by comparing gene expression profiles with immunohistochemistry results. The findings provide insights into the spatial cell profile of PitNETs and reveal potential cell variability within tumors.

title: Co-expression of immune checkpoints in glioblastoma revealed by single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the pattern of immune checkpoint expression in glioblastoma using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identified major cell types, analyzed interactions between specific malignant cells and immune cells, and proposed potential therapeutic targets based on immune checkpoint expression patterns.

title: Spatial and single-cell explorations uncover prognostic significance and immunological functions of mitochondrial calcium uniporter in breast cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the prognostic significance and immunological functions of the mitochondrial calcium uniporter (MCU) in breast cancer (BRCA). It employs a multi-omics approach, including spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing, to analyze MCU's role in the tumor microenvironment, immune cell infiltration, and clinical pathology. The findings suggest MCU alterations have diagnostic and prognostic implications for BRCA and could be a target for precision medicine.

title: Structural, Functional, and Genetic Changes Surrounding Electrodes Implanted in the Brain.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: To investigate the structural, functional, and genetic changes occurring in brain tissue surrounding implanted electrodes. The study aims to inform improved designs of implantable neurotechnology by linking biological responses to device characteristics. New biomarkers for benchmarking electrode effects are also a key outcome.

title: Lung Tissue Multilayer Network Analysis Uncovers the Molecular Heterogeneity of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease.
biological_context: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) lung tissue
main_goals: To unravel mechanisms associated with clinical characteristics of COPD by integrating different omics data using a novel multilayer network approach. The study identified five distinct patient communities and characterized molecular differences between patients with similar clinical presentations (low FEV1 and emphysema) using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Peripheral HMGB1 is linked to O<sub>3</sub> pathology of disease-associated astrocytes and amyloid.
biological_context: Alzheimer's disease pathobiology associated with ozone exposure
main_goals: This study investigated the role of disease-associated astrocytes (DAAs) and peripheral myeloid cell high mobility group box 1 (HMGB1) in ozone-induced Alzheimer's disease pathology. It characterized the O3-induced astrocyte phenotype in 5xFAD mice using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics, revealing impacts on DAA transcriptional fingerprints and astrocyte-microglia interactions. The research demonstrated that peripheral myeloid cell HMGB1 is crucial in regulating the O3-induced DAA phenotype, suggesting a potential intervention target for air pollution-induced AD.

title: Spatial and single-cell colocalisation analysis reveals MDK-mediated immunosuppressive environment with regulatory T cells in colorectal carcinogenesis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Single-Cell Analysis', 'Spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study investigates cell-cell interactions in the tumor microenvironment of early colorectal cancer using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies MDK as a key signaling molecule mediating an immunosuppressive environment with regulatory T cells and assesses its clinical significance.

title: The p21<sup>+</sup> perinecrotic hepatocytes produce the chemokine CXCL14 after a severe acetaminophen overdose promoting hepatocyte injury and delaying regeneration.
main_goals: This study investigated the role of p21+ perinecrotic hepatocytes in acetaminophen-induced liver injury. It identified CXCL14 as a key secreted factor from these hepatocytes that promotes injury and delays regeneration. The findings suggest that targeting CXCL14 can improve liver recovery.

title: scRNAseq and High-Throughput Spatial Analysis of Tumor and Normal Microenvironment in Solid Tumors Reveal a Possible Origin of Circulating Tumor Hybrid Cells.
biological_context: Solid tumors, specifically breast and colon cancers
main_goals: This study aimed to identify the tissue origin of circulating hybrid cells (CHCs) implicated in metastatic spread. Utilizing scRNA-seq and high-throughput spatial transcriptomics, they identified tumor hybrid cells (THCs) co-expressing epithelial and macrophage markers in breast and colon cancers, and characterized their transcriptomes. The findings provide evidence for THC tissue residence and offer insights into their invasive capabilities.

title: Spatiotemporal immune atlas of a clinical-grade gene-edited pig-to-human kidney xenotransplant.
main_goals: To study the human immune response to a gene-edited pig kidney xenograft in a brain-dead human recipient using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. The study aimed to characterize the immune cell infiltration and phenotype to inform immunomodulatory strategies for xenotransplantation.

title: The discovery of regional neurotoxicity-associated metabolic alterations induced by carbon quantum dots in brain of mice using a spatial metabolomics analysis.
biological_context: Mouse brain neurotoxicity induced by carbon quantum dots
main_goals: This study investigated the regional neurotoxicity-associated metabolic alterations induced by carbon quantum dots (CQDs) in the brains of mice using spatial metabolomics. The findings identified specific metabolites and pathways affected by CQDs, contributing to understanding their neurotoxic mechanisms and guiding future safety evaluations.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic changes of human ovarian aging and the regulatory role of FOXP1.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study systematically characterizes human ovarian aging using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies spatiotemporal molecular signatures of ovarian cells and reveals DNA damage response as a key pathway in oocyte aging. The study also identifies FOXP1 as a regulator of ovarian aging, declining with age and inhibiting CDKN1A.

title: Spatial co-transcriptomics reveals discrete stages of the arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis.
biological_context: Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis in Medicago truncatula and Rhizophagus irregularis
main_goals: This study utilized single-nucleus and spatial RNA sequencing to investigate the arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis in Medicago truncatula and Rhizophagus irregularis. The researchers aimed to reveal distinct stages of the symbiotic interaction at cellular and spatial resolution. The findings demonstrate dynamic interplay between plant and fungal cells during symbiosis establishment.

title: Single-cell multiomics reveals the interplay of clonal evolution and cellular plasticity in hepatoblastoma.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell multiomics', 'chromatin accessibility landscapes', 'single-cell mapping of somatic alterations']
main_goals: This study uses a single-cell multiomic strategy to reveal the molecular determinants of cellular plasticity in hepatoblastoma. It identifies a continuum of cell states and describes the gene regulatory networks and transcription factor activations underlying cell state transitions. The research highlights the interplay of clonal evolution and epigenetic plasticity in shaping the response of hepatoblastoma subclones to chemotherapy.

title: Mgp High-Expressing MSCs Orchestrate the Osteoimmune Microenvironment of Collagen/Nanohydroxyapatite-Mediated Bone Regeneration.
biological_context: Bone regeneration mediated by collagen/nanohydroxyapatite biomaterials
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study depicts the osteoimmune microenvironment around collagen/nanohydroxyapatite biomaterials using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies Mgp high-expressing MSCs as a pioneer subpopulation orchestrating bone repair by modulating macrophage polarization and osteoclastogenesis via the Mdk/Lrp1 pathway. The research also highlights crosstalk between immune cells and Mgp⁹rMSCs through the SPP1 signaling pathway, aiming to advance biomaterial design strategies for osteoimmune modulation.

title: Identification of cells of leukemic stem cell origin with non-canonical regenerative properties.
biological_context: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) regeneration and relapse
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Single-cell transcriptomics analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study identifies a new cell population in AML, termed Regeneration Enriched Cells (RECs), which are derived from leukemic stem cells but lack stem/progenitor capacity. RECs influence leukemic regeneration and prognosis by interacting with CD34-expressing cells. The findings contribute to understanding the non-canonical framework of AML regeneration and relapse.

title: Single-cell approaches define two groups of mammalian oligodendrocyte precursor cells and their evolution over developmental time.
biological_context: Murine cortical OPCs throughout postnatal life
main_goals: This paper characterizes murine cortical OPCs throughout postnatal life using single-cell RNA sequencing, ATAC sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies two distinct groups of OPCs, termed active (actOPCs) and homeostatic (hOPCs), with differential localization and epigenetic states. The study also investigates the differences in oligodendrogenesis between neonatal and adult OPCs.

title: Cellular atlas of the human ovary using morphologically guided spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing.
biological_context: Human ovary function and follicle development
main_goals: To create a cellular atlas of the human ovary using morphologically guided spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing. The study aims to characterize the functional attributes of ovarian cells, identify specific gene activities for key cell types (oocytes, theca, granulosa), and uncover variations in cellular activities across ovarian regions, ultimately serving as a resource for future ovarian research.

title: Spatial omics reveals molecular changes in focal cortical dysplasia type II.
biological_context: Focal cortical dysplasia type II (FCD II) in a mouse model and human samples.
data_modalities_used: ['Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI)', 'fluorescence imaging', 'label free proteomics', 'bulk transcriptomics', 'laser capture microdissection (LMD)']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Proteomic Analysis', 'Spatial Lipidomic Analysis']
main_goals: This study aims to characterize the proteomic and lipidomic changes in a mouse model of FCD type II using spatial omics techniques. It also investigates the interplay between genetic mutations and molecular changes in human FCD type IIb by analyzing bulk transcriptomics. The goal is to understand the functional consequences of somatic mutations and identify potential therapeutic targets.

title: In situ profiling reveals spatially metabolic injury in the initiation of polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal epithelial injury in mice.
biological_context: Polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal epithelial injury in mice
data_modalities_used: ['mass spectrometry imaging', 'spatial metabolomics', 'spatial metallomics', 'histopathological damage', 'microstructural changes']
main_goals: This study investigates the mechanisms underlying polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal toxicity in mice. It reveals that while direct inflammation or histopathological damage is not induced, nanoplastic accumulation leads to enterocyte microstructural changes, gut microbiota dysbiosis, and host metabolic reprogramming, ultimately initiating intestinal injury. The findings highlight the critical role of gut microbial-host metabolic remodeling in nanoplastic-induced intestinal damage.

title: Immune microniches shape intestinal T<sub>reg</sub> function.
data_modalities_used: ['in vivo live imaging', 'photo-activation-guided single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'RNA sequencing']
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial mechanisms of T regulatory cell function in the intestine. It identifies the lamina propria as a key microniche supporting effector T regulatory cell function and reveals a tolerogenic interaction between CD206+ macrophages and eTreg cells. The findings offer insights into spatial tolerance and potential therapeutic strategies.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals discrete tumour microenvironments and autocrine loops within ovarian cancer subclones.
data_modalities_used: ['Visium spatial transcriptomics', 'CosMx single molecule imaging', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'gene expression profiling']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to identify HGSOC subclones and analyze their association with the tumor microenvironment. It reveals subclone-specific ligand and receptor expression patterns that modulate interactions with stromal and immune cells, identifying autocrine loops within subclones.

title: Digital Spatial Profiling Identifies Distinct Molecular Signatures of Vascular Lesions in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension.
biological_context: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) and vascular lesions
main_goals: To test the hypothesis that microscopic IPAH vascular lesions express unique molecular profiles. The study used digital spatial transcriptomics to profile the transcriptomic signature of key pathological lesions in IPAH lungs and compared them with control pulmonary arteries. The findings provide a molecular-structural framework for IPAH vascular lesions that can inform novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Glioblastoma-instructed microglia transition to heterogeneous phenotypic states with phagocytic and dendritic cell-like features in patient tumors and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts.
biological_context: Glioblastoma tumor microenvironment in patients and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts (PDOXs)
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multicolor flow cytometry', 'immunohistochemistry', 'functional studies', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['single-cell analysis', 'spatial analysis', 'flow cytometry analysis', 'immunohistochemistry analysis', 'functional studies']
main_goals: To characterize the heterogeneous tumor microenvironment (TME) in glioblastoma (GBM) patient tumors and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts (PDOXs) at single-cell and spatial levels. The study aims to understand how GBM cells instruct myeloid cells, particularly microglia, to adopt diverse phenotypic states and to assess the relevance of PDOXs as models for studying the GBM ecosystem and treatment responses.

title: Imbalance in Glucose Metabolism Regulates the Transition of Microglia from Homeostasis to Disease-Associated Microglia Stage 1.
main_goals: Investigate the role of glucose metabolism and PKM2 in the transition of microglia from homeostasis to disease-associated microglia (DAM) stage 1 in the context of Alzheimer's disease. The study aims to understand the molecular mechanisms regulating this transition, particularly focusing on metabolic dysregulation.

title: Single-Cell Multi-Omics Map of Cell Type-Specific Mechanistic Drivers of Multiple Sclerosis Lesions.
biological_context: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) brain white matter lesions
main_goals: To provide a single-cell multi-omics map of cell type-specific mechanistic drivers of multiple sclerosis (MS) lesions, uncovering specific genetic signatures, cellular endophenotypes, and B-cell coexpression networks within MS brain white matter. The study aims to offer detailed insights into cellular dynamics and interactions in MS pathogenesis.

title: Molecular architecture of primate specific neural circuit formation.
biological_context: Primate brain development, specifically neural circuit formation in the marmoset cortex
main_goals: To understand the molecular mechanisms of primate-specific neural circuit formation by assessing gene expression dynamics in the marmoset cortex using spatial transcriptomics. The study identified differentially expressed genes, particularly axon guidance molecules in the prefrontal cortex, and investigated the role of PRSS12 in circuit formation.

title: Dysregulation of cell state dynamics during early stages of serous endometrial carcinogenesis.
biological_context: Serous endometrial carcinogenesis in a mouse model
main_goals: This study provides a comprehensive census of cell types and their states during the early stages of serous endometrial carcinogenesis in a mouse model. It identifies molecular and cellular dynamics associated with pre-dysplastic changes and highlights aberrant cell-cell interactions. The paper also proposes a panel of 44 genes as potential early diagnostic and prognostic markers for human serous endometrial carcinoma.

title: Chemotherapy induces myeloid-driven spatial T-cell exhaustion in ovarian cancer.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell analysis', 'spatial analysis', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'in vitro immuno-oncology platform']
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatiotemporal remodeling of the tumor microenvironment induced by chemotherapy in ovarian cancer. It identifies chemotherapy-triggered spatial redistribution and exhaustion of CD8+ T cells, driven by macrophages, and proposes novel immunotherapeutic strategies.

title: Integrative spatial omics reveals distinct tumor-promoting multicellular niches and immunosuppressive mechanisms in Black American and White American patients with TNBC.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate racial disparities in TNBC by characterizing the tumor microenvironment (TME) in Black American (BA) and White American (WA) patients using imaging mass cytometry and spatial transcriptomics. It revealed distinct TME profiles associated with survival differences and immunosuppressive mechanisms, suggesting potential race-inclusive therapeutic targets.

title: Integrating Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals Heterogeneity of Early Pig Skin Development and a Subpopulation with Hair Placode Formation.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell Differentiation', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This study integrates single-cell and spatial transcriptomics on fetal pig skin across four developmental periods to understand heterogeneity and hair follicle formation. It identifies conserved genes with human skin diseases and pinpoints progenitor cells (OGN+/UCHL1+) for hair placode development, providing a resource for studying human skin diseases using porcine models.

title: Deciphering the spatial landscape and plasticity of immunosuppressive fibroblasts in breast cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Trajectory Inference', 'Deconvolution', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper aims to decipher the spatial landscape and plasticity of immunosuppressive fibroblasts (FAP+ CAFs) in breast cancer. It identifies spatially organized cellular niches and investigates the mechanisms driving CAF transitions and their impact on the tumor microenvironment, linking CAF subpopulations to invasive recurrence risk.

title: Identification of spatially-resolved markers of malignant transformation in Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms.
biological_context: Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms (IPMN) and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) progression
main_goals: This paper identifies subtype-specific spatially-resolved gene expression markers for Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms (IPMN) across two independent cohorts and two Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) technologies. It aims to improve risk stratification and guide therapeutic options by revealing the role of specific gene activations in IPMN progression and its relation to pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).

title: Single-Nucleus Multiomic Analyses Identifies Gene Regulatory Dynamics of Phenotypic Modulation in Human Aneurysmal Aortic Root.
biological_context: Human aortic root aneurysm, specifically in the context of Marfan syndrome (MFS)
data_modalities_used: ['single-nucleus multiomic (gene expression)', 'single-nucleus multiomic (chromatin accessibility)', 'spatial transcriptomic sequencing']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling', 'Chromatin Accessibility']
main_goals: To perform the first integrative analysis of single-nucleus multiomic and spatial transcriptomic sequencing data of human aortic root tissue under healthy and Marfan syndrome conditions. The study aims to identify cell-type-specific transcriptomic and cis-regulatory profiles, delineate regulatory and spatial dynamics during vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotypic modulation, and identify key regulators of this process, such as FOXN3.

title: SPINK1 Overexpression Correlates with Hepatocellular Carcinoma Treatment Resistance Revealed by Single Cell RNA-Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'single cell RNA-sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study aims to elucidate the functions of SPINK1 on HCC therapy resistance using single cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It reveals that high SPINK1 expression is associated with drug resistance and identifies SPINK1 as a potential therapeutic target for refractory HCC.

title: Unique Spatial Transcriptomic Profiling of the Murine Femoral Fracture Callus: A Preliminary Report.
biological_context: Murine femoral fracture callus formation with metastatic breast cancer impairment
main_goals: To provide the first spatially intact characterization of genetic expression changes within an orthopedic model of impaired fracture healing using the Visium CytAssist platform. The study aimed to identify spatially localized gene expression changes in the fracture callus and investigate the impact of metastatic breast cancer on these patterns. The findings suggest that spatial transcriptomics is a valuable tool for orthopedic research by providing temporal and spatial context.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals molecular dysfunction associated with cortical Lewy pathology.
biological_context: Parkinson's disease and related dementia, specifically cortical Lewy pathology
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to identify specific classes of excitatory neurons vulnerable to Lewy pathology in the cortex of Parkinson's disease patients and a mouse model. It also describes a conserved signature of molecular dysfunction, termed LAMDA, characterized by downregulated synaptic, mitochondrial, and protein degradation genes, and upregulated DNA repair and immune genes in aggregate-bearing neurons.

title: Pharmacological suppression of the OTUD4/CD73 proteolytic axis revives antitumor immunity against immune-suppressive breast cancers.
main_goals: This paper identifies and pharmacologically targets the OTUD4/CD73 proteolytic axis in immune-suppressive breast cancers, specifically TNBC. It demonstrates that inhibiting this axis with a new compound, ST80, can revive antitumor immunity and sensitize tumors to immunotherapy. The study highlights the role of TGF-β signaling and uses spatial transcriptomics to understand immune cell interactions.

title: EHMT2 Inactivation in Pancreatic Epithelial Cells Shapes the Transcriptional Landscape and Inflammation Response of the Whole Pancreas.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of EHMT2 inactivation in exocrine pancreatic epithelial cells in shaping the transcriptional landscape and inflammation response of the whole pancreas. It reveals that EHMT2 inactivation enhances the injury-inflammation-repair response by reprogramming the local environment to recruit mesenchymal and immunological cells, contributing to the suppression of pancreatic cancer initiation and modulation of inflammatory pancreatic diseases.

title: Fetal liver macrophages contribute to the hematopoietic stem cell niche by controlling granulopoiesis.
main_goals: This study investigates the heterogeneity of fetal liver macrophage populations in mice and their roles in hematopoiesis. It found that specific fetal liver macrophages interact preferentially with long-term HSCs and are crucial for controlling granulopoiesis and supporting erythropoiesis.

title: Spatial Mass Cytometry-Based Single-Cell Imaging Reveals a Disrupted Epithelial-Immune Axis in Prurigo Nodularis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This study uses spatial imaging mass cytometry to characterize the spatial organization of the cutaneous infiltrate in prurigo nodularis (PN). It identifies disrupted epithelial-immune axis and highlights phosphorylated extracellular signal-regulated kinase-positive CD14+ macrophages as contributors to itch in PN.

title: SARS-CoV-2 infection modifies the transcriptome of the megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.
biological_context: SARS-CoV-2 infection in mice, focusing on bone marrow megakaryocytes
main_goals: The study investigated whether SARS-CoV-2 infection affects the transcriptome of bone marrow megakaryocytes. Using spatial transcriptomics and machine learning, the researchers aimed to identify transcriptional changes in megakaryocytes based on their proximity to bone marrow sinusoids and in the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection and systemic inflammation. The goal was to understand the impact of COVID-19 pathogenesis on these cells.

title: Mapping functional to morphological variation reveals the basis of regional extracellular matrix subversion and nerve invasion in pancreatic cancer.
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'Ex vivo experiments', 'in vitro experiments']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study aims to elucidate the gene expression programs that underpin intratumor morphological variation in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC). It identifies three major morphological and functional variants co-existing in PDAC, associated with distinct extracellular matrix organization and linked to neural invasion. The research provides evidence for dynamic transitions between these variants influenced by the extracellular matrix.

title: Transcriptomic, epigenomic, and spatial metabolomic cell profiling redefines regional human kidney anatomy.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Metabolomics Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study aimed to create a large-scale multimodal atlas of the human kidney, integrating transcriptomic, epigenomic, and spatial metabolomic data to redefine its regional anatomy. It identified cell-type specific signatures based on location and explored metabolic dysregulation in disease, highlighting PLEKHA1 as a potential marker for proximal tubule differentiation.

title: Deciphering the spatiotemporal transcriptional and chromatin accessibility of human retinal organoid development at the single-cell level.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper presents a single-cell spatiotemporal transcriptome of human retinal organoid development by combining single cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. It aims to recapitulate key events of retinogenesis and reveal cell-type specific transcription factor binding motifs on accessible chromatin.

title: YAP induces a neonatal-like pro-renewal niche in the adult heart.
main_goals: This study investigates how YAP activation induces a neonatal-like pro-renewal niche in adult mouse hearts post-myocardial infarction. It reveals a cellular triad involving cardiomyocytes, fibroblasts, and macrophages, orchestrated by C3a signaling, that is crucial for heart regeneration.

title: Down to the coronary arteries: When spatial multiomics open up a narrow path.
main_goals: This paper discusses the application of spatial multiomics to study coronary arteries, particularly in the context of heart transplantation. It highlights the challenges and opportunities in using these advanced techniques to understand conditions like antibody-mediated rejection (AMR), cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV), and donor-specific antibodies (DSA). The focus is on how spatial multiomics can provide insights into the complex biological processes occurring at the cellular and tissue level in these critical vessels.

title: FASN-mediated fatty acid biosynthesis remodels immune environment in Clonorchis sinensis infection-related intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'whole-exome sequencing', 'RNA sequencing', 'metabolomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'in vitro co-culture system', 'mouse model']
main_goals: This study investigates the clinical impact and molecular characteristics of Clonorchis sinensis (C. sinensis) infection-related intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (iCCA). It reveals that C. sinensis infection is associated with worse prognosis and immunotherapy response due to FASN-mediated fatty acid biosynthesis, which remodels the immune microenvironment. The paper proposes that combining FASN inhibitors with immunotherapy could be a promising treatment strategy.

title: Cancer-associated fibroblast spatial heterogeneity and EMILIN1 expression in the tumor microenvironment modulate TGF-β activity and CD8+ T-cell infiltration in breast cancer.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomic data', 'immunohistochemistry analysis', 'histological images']
main_goals: This study investigated the spatial heterogeneity of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in the breast tumor microenvironment. It explored the relationship between CAF populations, TGF-β signaling, and CD8+ T-cell infiltration, identifying EMILIN1 as a key modulator of T-cell recruitment and patient prognosis.

title: Modulation of hippocampal protein expression by a brain penetrant biologic TNF-α inhibitor in the 3xTg Alzheimer's disease mice.
main_goals: This study investigated the effects of a brain-penetrant biologic TNF-α inhibitor (TfRMAb-TNFR) on protein expression in the hippocampus of 3xTg-AD mice. The researchers used spatial proteomics to identify differentially expressed proteins and understand the mechanism of action of the inhibitor, which appeared to be largely microglia-centric.

title: Integrated single-cell sequencing, spatial transcriptome sequencing and bulk RNA sequencing highlights the molecular characteristics of parthanatos in gastric cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The study aimed to investigate the molecular characteristics of parthanatos in gastric cancer by integrating single-cell, spatial transcriptome, and bulk RNA sequencing. It identified cell types in the GC microenvironment, revealed elevated parthanatos pathway scores across multiple cell types in GC tissues, and characterized the spatial distribution of parthanatos signaling. The integration of parthanatos signaling with clinical indicators allowed for the creation of novel survival prediction models.

title: A longitudinal single-cell and spatial multiomic atlas of pediatric high-grade glioma.
data_modalities_used: ['single-nucleus RNA sequencing', 'ATAC sequencing', 'whole-genome sequencing', 'CODEX spatial proteomics', 'spatial proteomics']
main_goals: This study aimed to create a longitudinal multiomic atlas of pediatric high-grade glioma (pHGG) to understand its evolution during treatment. It profiles pHGG patients using various omics techniques to capture tumor microenvironment changes and identifies key transcriptional regulators and potential therapeutic targets, highlighting differences from adult glioma.

title: Large-scale single-cell profiling of stem cells uncovers redundant regulators of shoot development and yield trait variation.
biological_context: Plant shoot stem cells, maize and arabidopsis development, yield trait variation
main_goals: This study used large-scale single-cell profiling of stem cells from maize and arabidopsis to identify conserved and novel regulators of shoot development and yield trait variation. It aimed to improve crop engineering by uncovering regulators expressed in stem cells.

title: Differentiation signals induce APOBEC3A expression via GRHL3 in squamous epithelia and squamous cell carcinoma.
biological_context: squamous epithelia and squamous cell carcinoma
main_goals: This study investigates the expression of APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B in healthy and malignant mucosal epithelia. It reveals that APOBEC3A expression is largely confined to terminally differentiating cells and is dependent on GRHL3, while APOBEC3B is expressed in mitotic keratinocytes. In squamous cell carcinoma, expanded GRHL3 expression leads to APOBEC3A expression in proliferating cells, suggesting a mechanism for acquired mutagenic activity in tumors.

title: Spatiotemporal metabolic responses to water deficit stress in distinct leaf cell-types of poplar.
biological_context: Poplar leaf cell-type responses to water deficit stress
main_goals: This study investigated the spatiotemporal metabolic responses of palisade and vascular cells in poplar leaves under water deficit stress using MALDI-MSI. It identified cell-type specific metabolic shifts and highlighted the value of MSI in complementing whole-tissue metabolomics for a deeper understanding of plant stress responses.

title: Targeting ESE3/EHF With Nifurtimox Inhibits CXCR2<sup>+</sup> Neutrophil Infiltration and Overcomes Pancreatic Cancer Resistance to Chemotherapy and Immunotherapy.
data_modalities_used: ['genomic single nucleotide polymorphism sequencing', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplexed immunohistochemistry', 'flow cytometry', 'multiplexed cytokines assays', 'chromatin immunoprecipitation assays', 'KPC mice', 'CD45.1+ BALB/C nude mice', 'CD34+ humanized mice', 'cell line', 'tumor samples']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Immunotherapy Response Prediction', 'Chemotherapy Resistance Analysis']
main_goals: This study investigated the role of EHF in pancreatic cancer, particularly its impact on CXCR2+ neutrophil infiltration and resistance to chemotherapy and immunotherapy. It identified Nifurtimox as a potential therapeutic agent that targets EHF, leading to reduced neutrophil infiltration and improved treatment outcomes. The study also highlighted the importance of the CXCL1-CXCR2 pathway and the JAK1/STAT1 signaling in mediating these effects.

title: Mast cell activation disrupts interactions between endothelial cells and pericytes during early life allergic asthma.
biological_context: Early life allergic asthma in mice and humans
main_goals: This study investigates the impact of allergic asthma on the pulmonary microcirculation during early life. It reports that exposure to house dust mite extract disrupts endothelial cell/pericyte interactions, driven by mast cell proteases. The research also suggests intense vascular stress and remodeling in pediatric asthmatic endobronchial biopsies.

title: Comprehensive transcriptional atlas of human adenomyosis deciphered by the integration of single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study aimed to map transcriptional alterations in human adenomyosis lesions, eutopic endometrium, and the endometrial-myometrial junction using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial profiling. It identified unique cell subpopulations within lesions, characterized endothelial cell heterogeneity and angiogenic signaling, and revealed differences in cell-cell communication pathways between ectopic and eutopic endometrium. The findings are intended to guide the development of precise diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for adenomyosis.

title: Integration Analysis of Single-Cell Multi-Omics Reveals Prostate Cancer Heterogeneity.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study integrates single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and bulk ATAC-sequence to analyze prostate cancer heterogeneity. It identifies a stemness subset of club cells enriched after therapy and a reduction in CD8+CXCR6+ T cells in malignant PCa. The research also examines cellular diversity, cell-cell communication, and macrophage/neutrophil states, linking the immunosuppressive microenvironment to Tregs induced by FAP+ fibroblasts, with potential implications for diagnosis and therapy.

title: The HIF-1α/PLOD2 axis integrates extracellular matrix organization and cell metabolism leading to aberrant musculoskeletal repair.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of HIF-1α in metabolism-linked extracellular matrix (ECM) organization and cell fate during aberrant musculoskeletal repair, specifically heterotopic ossification (HO). It identifies the HIF-1α/PLOD2/LOX axis as a key regulator of HO formation by influencing collagen organization and cell metabolism in mesenchymal progenitor cells (MPCs). The findings suggest this pathway as a potential therapeutic target for mitigating HO.

title: Chronic SIV-Induced neuroinflammation disrupts CCR7+ CD4+ T cell immunosurveillance in the rhesus macaque brain.
biological_context: Rhesus macaque brain during chronic SIV infection
main_goals: To investigate the role of CCR7+ CD4+ T cells in brain immune homeostasis and their disruption during chronic SIV infection. The study aimed to characterize these cells using multi-omics approaches and to understand the consequences of their depletion on neuroinflammation.

title: Spatial Single Cell Profiling Using Imaging Mass Cytometry: Inflammatory Versus Penetrating Crohn's Disease.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Dimensionality Reduction', 'Cell Type Clustering', 'Cell Frequency Analysis', 'Marker Distribution Analysis', 'Spatial Neighbourhood Analysis']
main_goals: This study presents the first highly multiplexed single-cell analysis of the immune cell compartment of Crohn's disease fistulas and their spatial context. It links immune cell dynamics, particularly MMP9+ neutrophils, to extracellular matrix remodelling in CD fistulas, offering insights into the complex network of cellular interactions and potential therapeutic targets for CD complications.

title: Mapping the metabolic responses to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy with in vivo spatiotemporal metabolomics.
biological_context: Lung metastases caused by colorectal cancer (CRC) and response to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy
data_modalities_used: ['spatial metabolomics', 'in vivo lung perfusion (IVLP)', 'solid-phase microextraction (SPME) microprobes', 'global metabolite profiling']
main_goals: This study explores the potential of spatial metabolomics for evaluating metabolic phenotypes and therapy outcomes during the local delivery of oxaliplatin to the lung. It identifies toxic doses and investigates lung injury mechanisms by analyzing metabolic alterations. The findings suggest spatial pharmacometabolomics is a promising tool for understanding chemotherapy responses.

title: High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomic Atlas of Mouse Soleus Muscle: Unveiling Single Cell and Subcellular Heterogeneity in Health and Denervation.
biological_context: Mouse soleus muscle in healthy and denervated states
main_goals: To leverage Seq-Scope technology for high-resolution spatial transcriptomics of mouse soleus muscle in health and denervation. The study aims to reveal single-cell and subcellular heterogeneity, including details of muscle fibers, other cell types, and specific subcellular structures like neuromuscular junctions and hybrid muscle fibers. The findings aim to enhance understanding of muscle cell transcriptome diversity and its response to denervation, providing insights for aging and disease-related muscle decline.

title: NAD <sup>+</sup> activates renal metabolism and protects from chronic kidney disease in a model of Alport syndrome.
data_modalities_used: ['bulk RNA-sequencing', 'single nuclei RNA-sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'mouse model', 'biochemical assays', 'imaging techniques']
main_goals: To investigate the mechanism by which NAD+ supplementation protects from chronic kidney disease (CKD) in a mouse model of Alport syndrome. The study aims to identify the specific cell types involved and the metabolic pathways affected. It also seeks to report sex differences at the transcriptional level in this model.

title: General Capillary Endothelial Cells Undergo Reprogramming into Arterial Endothelial Cells in Pulmonary Hypertension through HIF-2α/Notch4 Pathway.
main_goals: This study investigates the mechanisms underlying pulmonary hypertension (PH), specifically the loss of capillary endothelial cells and formation of obliterative vascular lesions. It demonstrates that lung capillary endothelial cells reprogram into arterial endothelial cells through the HIF-2α/Notch4 pathway during PH development. The findings suggest targeting this transition as a novel therapeutic approach for PAH.

title: Precision unveiled: Synergistic genomic landscapes in breast cancer-Integrating single-cell analysis and decoding drug toxicity for elite prognostication and tailored therapeutics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to develop a prognostic staging index for breast cancer patients by integrating T-cell related genes (TRG) and glutamine metabolism (GM). The developed TRG_GM classifier stratifies patients into different groups, illuminating distinct immunological attributes, genetic profiles, and drug responses, thus providing avenues for tailored therapeutic interventions.

title: Potential Role of Lymphocyte CD44 in Determining Treatment Selection Between Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy and Surgery for Early-Stage Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.
main_goals: To identify molecular biomarkers using spatial proteomics to optimize treatment selection between stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) and surgery for early-stage non-small cell lung cancer (ES-NSCLC). The study investigates the role of lymphocyte CD44 expression in predicting treatment efficacy and guiding patient selection.

title: Cellular senescence is associated with the spatial evolution toward a higher metastatic phenotype in colorectal cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study explores the dynamic process of colorectal cancer progression, focusing on the evolution toward a more metastatic phenotype. It highlights the spatial correlation of this evolution with tumor cell senescence, identifying two distinct types of senescent cells. The findings suggest that type II senescent cells are associated with local invasion and lymph node metastasis, potentially impacting patient prognosis.

title: Characterization of Vascular Niche in Systemic Sclerosis by Spatial Proteomics.
main_goals: The main goal of this study was to characterize cellular alterations of the vascular niches of patients with Systemic sclerosis (SSc) by applying spatial proteomic approaches. The study identified a novel population of CD34+;αSMA+;CD31+ VECs increased in SSc and associated with clinical progression of fibrosis.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals altered lipid metabolism and inflammation-related gene expression of sebaceous glands in psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.
main_goals: The study investigates the spatial transcriptome of sebaceous glands in psoriasis and atopic dermatitis patients across lesional and non-lesional human skin samples to understand their role in disease development. The study identifies genes related to lipid metabolism and inflammation that are differentially expressed in sebaceous glands in these diseases. The results suggest that sebaceous glands actively and differentially modulate inflammation in a disease-specific manner.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid: Insights into pathogenesis and therapy on bullous formation.
main_goals: The study uses spatial transcriptomics to investigate the pathogenesis and therapy of bullous formation in pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid.

title: Perturbed liver gene zonation in a mouse model of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis.
main_goals: This study investigates the perturbation of liver gene zonation in a mouse NASH model by combining spatial transcriptomics, bulk RNAseq, and in situ hybridization. It demonstrates the alteration of Wnt signaling in a mouse NASH model, leading to perturbed liver zonation.

title: Multi-omic profiling of follicular lymphoma reveals changes in tissue architecture and enhanced stromal remodeling in high-risk patients.
main_goals: The study examines cell-intrinsic and -extrinsic factors governing progression and therapeutic outcomes in FL patients using a multi-modal strategy. It aims to identify tumor-specific features and microenvironmental patterns enriched in individuals who experience early relapse. The study identifies stromal desmoplasia and changes to the follicular growth pattern present before first progression and first relapse.

title: The cell-type-specific spatial organization of the anterior thalamic nuclei of the mouse brain.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplexed fluorescent in situ hybridization']
main_goals: The study aims to identify cell-type composition and spatial organization of the anterior thalamic nuclei (ATN) in the mouse brain. It combines single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and multiplexed fluorescent in situ hybridization to uncover marker genes, molecular pathways, and putative functions of ATN cell types. The study also demonstrates spatial variation and covarying protein products in the ATN.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals prognosis-associated cellular heterogeneity in the papillary thyroid carcinoma microenvironment.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Clustering', 'Gene Ontology enrichment analysis']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to characterize the spatial location and RNA profiles of PTC-associated cells within tissue sections. The study identifies specific cell types and their spatial distribution, revealing cellular heterogeneity associated with prognosis. Key ligand-receptor interactions involved in PTC cell transition are discovered, and their correlation with reduced relapse-free survival is highlighted.

title: JAK/STAT3 represents a therapeutic target for colorectal cancer patients with stromal-rich tumors.
main_goals: This study investigates the effectiveness of inhibiting JAK/STAT3 in diverse CRC models and establishes in which contexts high pathway expression is prognostic. Spatial transcriptomics was used to unravel the underlying biology of aberrant signaling. The study concludes that inhibition of JAK/STAT3 represents a promising therapeutic strategy for patients with stromal-rich CRC tumors.

title: Spatial transcriptomic analysis of tumour-immune cell interactions in melanoma arising from congenital melanocytic nevus.
biological_context: Melanoma arising from congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN)
main_goals: The study aimed to determine the intratumoral immune landscape of tumor-infiltrating immune cells (TIICs) and tumor cells during invasion and metastasis in melanoma originating from congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) using spatial transcriptomics. It investigated differential gene expression in melanoma cells and TIICs with increasing invasion depth and compared expression profiles in primary and metastatic lesions.

title: A spatial map of hepatic mitochondria uncovers functional heterogeneity shaped by nutrient-sensing signaling.
main_goals: The study investigates mitochondrial heterogeneity in the liver in the context of liver zonation. It aims to understand how mitochondria sense and integrate nutrient signals to maintain homeostasis by combining intravital microscopy, spatial proteomics, and functional assessment.

title: Harnessing spatial transcriptomics for advancing plant regeneration research.
main_goals: The study utilized spatial transcriptomics to investigate the molecular characteristics of cells during shoot regeneration in tomato callus. It enhances our knowledge of shoot regeneration and demonstrates the potential of spatial transcriptomics in plant biology.

title: Single-nucleus RNA sequencing demonstrates an autosomal dominant Alzheimer's disease profile and possible mechanisms of disease protection.
main_goals: To compare single-nucleus transcriptomes among PSEN1-E280A ADAD carriers, sporadic AD, and controls to identify downstream pathways that distinguish these AD forms in specific cell types. The study also aims to explore possible explanations for protection from AD pathology based on a PSEN1-E280A case with spared neurofibrillary pathology and a homozygous APOE3-Christchurch variant.

title: Cellular neighborhood analysis in spatial omics reveals new tissue domains and cell subtypes.
main_goals: The paper analyzes cellular neighborhoods in spatial omics data to reveal new tissue domains and cell subtypes.

title: Region-specific cellular and molecular basis of liver regeneration after acute pericentral injury.
biological_context: Liver regeneration after acute pericentral injury
main_goals: The study aims to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying liver regeneration after acute pericentral injury. It investigates the roles of different hepatocyte populations, signaling pathways, and immune cells in this process. The findings provide insights into the spatiotemporal dynamics of pericentral regeneration and potential therapeutic targets.

title: CD200<sup>+</sup> fibroblasts form a pro-resolving mesenchymal network in arthritis.
main_goals: The study aims to understand fibroblast phenotype changes during the resolution of inflammation in arthritis. It identifies a phenotypic switch from pro-inflammatory to pro-resolving fibroblasts using positron emission tomography and single-cell RNA sequencing. The study shows CD200+DKK3+ fibroblasts promote resolution of arthritis through CD200-CD200R1 signaling.

title: Digital spatial profiling of segmental outflow regions in trabecular meshwork reveals a role for ADAM15.
main_goals: This study used spatial transcriptomics to identify genes associated with high or low outflow regions in the trabecular meshwork. The study identified differentially expressed genes, highlighting ECM/cell adhesion, signal transduction, and transcription as key biological categories. It also validated the differential expression of ADAM15 in high outflow regions.

title: Single-cell spatial transcriptomic and translatomic profiling of dopaminergic neurons in health, aging, and disease.
biological_context: Mouse brain in health, aging, and Parkinson's disease
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the expression features of dopaminergic neurons and other cell types within their spatial context in healthy, aging, and Parkinson's disease mouse brains. They integrate gene enrichment and genome-wide association study data to identify causative genes for disease investigation. The datasets generated represent a large public resource for the investigation of spatial gene expression in brain cells.

title: Immune mapping of human tuberculosis and sarcoidosis lung granulomas.
main_goals: The study compares the immunological microenvironments of granulomas from TB and sarcoidosis patients using in situ sequencing transcriptomic analysis and multiplexed immunolabeling of tissue sections. It identifies the formation of tertiary immune structures as a common feature in granulomas from TB patients but not in sarcoidosis samples.

title: Mass spectrometry imaging-based metabolomics highlights spatial metabolic alterations in three types of liver injuries.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize metabolic profiles and spatial signatures in different liver injuries induced by ethanol, acetaminophen, and thioacetamide in zebrafish using mass spectrometry imaging. It identifies metabolic reprogramming in liver injury regions and highlights potential biomarkers for liver injuries. The study underscores spatial metabolomics as a tool to elucidate pathogenic mechanisms.

title: In situ single-cell profiling sheds light on IFI27 localisation during SARS-CoV-2 infection.
main_goals: The study utilizes single-cell resolved spatial transcriptomics to delineate immune responses during SARS-CoV-2 infection. It identifies M1 macrophages with elevated expression of IFI27 in areas of infection.

title: Single-cell and spatial multi-omics highlight effects of anti-integrin therapy across cellular compartments in ulcerative colitis.
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to identify the inflammatory cells that contribute to ulcerative colitis and are affected by Vedolizumab (VDZ). This is achieved through single-cell transcriptomic and proteomic analyses of peripheral blood and colonic biopsies, along with spatial multi-omics of formalin-fixed biopsies. The study aims to reveal the broader effects of VDZ on different cell subsets beyond lymphocyte trafficking.

title: Spatiotemporal profiling defines persistence and resistance dynamics during targeted treatment of melanoma.
main_goals: The study aims to define state change and lineage selection during melanoma treatment with spatiotemporal resolution, elucidating how choice and timing of therapeutic agents will impact the ability to eradicate resistant clones. They capture clonal lineage evolution during treatment using spatial transcriptomics in patient derived xenograft models. Deep learning analysis of histopathological slides helps identify phenotypically-distinct populations using imaging data alone.

title: Single-cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Identified Fatty Acid-binding Proteins Controlling Endothelial Glycolytic and Arterial Programming in Pulmonary Hypertension.
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the cellular and molecular mechanisms of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomic analysis. The study identified that FABP4 and FABP5 are highly induced in endothelial cells of PAH models and patients, contributing to enhanced ECs glycolysis and distal arterial programming, leading to vascular remodeling. Genetic deletion of Fabp4/5 attenuated pulmonary vascular remodeling and prevented right heart failure.

title: Comprehensive phenotypic and genomic characterization of venous malformations.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify a possible association between genetic mutations and clinicopathological features in venous malformations. They performed a retrospective clinical, pathological, and genetic study of 114 patients with VMs. Significant genotype-phenotype correlations in clinical and pathological features were observed among the VM genotypes, indicating gene-specific effects.

title: Multimodal mass spectrometry imaging identifies cell-type-specific metabolic and lipidomic variation in the mammalian liver.
main_goals: The study aims to capture the transient lipidome/metabolome from cells in a native liver tissue environment using water gas cluster ion beam secondary ion mass spectrometry imaging (GCIB-SIMS) and desorption electrospray ionization (DESI). It aims to characterize the cellular landscape and metabolic states in different liver cell types at single-cell resolution.

title: Chemokine expression profile of an innate granuloma.
biological_context: Chromobacterium violaceum infection in mouse liver
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the chemokines involved in directing immune cells to form granulomas in the liver in response to Chromobacterium violaceum infection, using spatial transcriptomics. It also investigates the role of CCR2 in macrophage recruitment and granuloma formation.

title: Technical optimization of spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomic datasets to study clinical liver disease.
main_goals: The study aims to establish important aspects of tissue handling, data processing, and downstream analyses for biobanked liver samples using spatial transcriptomics and snRNAseq. It investigates the impact of tissue preservation on transcriptomic data and compares cell-cell interactions predicted from snRNAseq data with those identified using spatial transcriptomics. The study provides a framework for generating spatially resolved, single cell datasets to study gene expression and cell-cell interactions in clinical liver disease.

title: Myeloid-Mas Signaling Modulates Pathogenic Crosstalk among MYC<sup>+</sup>CD63<sup>+</sup> Endothelial Cells, MMP12<sup>+</sup> Macrophages, and Monocytes in Acetaminophen-Induced Liver Injury.
main_goals: This study aims to characterize the microenvironment in acetaminophen-induced liver injury (AILI) using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and intravital imaging. It identifies reciprocal cellular communication among specific cell types, maintained by enhanced glycolysis and the NF-κB/TNF-α signaling pathway. The study also validates the findings in samples from patients with acute liver failure, demonstrating clinical relevance.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals alterations in perivascular macrophage lipid metabolism in the onset of Wooden Breast myopathy in broiler chickens.
biological_context: Wooden Breast myopathy in broiler chickens
main_goals: This study aims to use spatial transcriptomics to characterize the cell-type-specific expression profile associated with the microscopic features observed in Wooden Breast myopathy. The study identified cell-type-specific gene expression patterns in lipid laden macrophages, unaffected myofibers, myositis and vasculature in broiler chickens.

title: Tumoral and stromal hMENA isoforms impact tertiary lymphoid structure localization in lung cancer and predict immune checkpoint blockade response in patients with cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates how hMENA isoforms in tumor cells and CAFs relate to TLS presence, localization and impact on patient outcomes and ICB response in NSCLC. Findings indicate that hMENA isoforms in NSCLC cells and CAFs affect TLS regulation, fibronectin production, and CXCL13 secretion. The hMENA isoform pattern, fibronectin, and LTβR expression predict ICB response in tumors with TLS.

title: Identification of the key DNA damage response genes for predicting immunotherapy and chemotherapy efficacy in lung adenocarcinoma based on bulk, single-cell RNA sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The study aims to identify key DNA damage response (DDR) genes that predict immunotherapy and chemotherapy efficacy in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD). It utilizes bulk RNA-seq, scRNA-seq, and spatial transcriptomics data to isolate EGLN3 as a crucial DDR gene and assess its spatial distribution and association with drug resistance.

title: Spatial proteomics of ER tubules reveals CLMN, an ER-actin tether at focal adhesions that promotes cell migration.
main_goals: The paper maps the proteomic landscape of the human ER and nuclear envelope using TurboID-based proximity labeling. It identifies Calmin (CLMN) as an ER-actin tether that localizes to focal adhesions and regulates cell migration. The study describes a non-canonical mechanism by which ER tubules engage actin to regulate cell migration.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveal neuron-astrocyte synergy in long-term memory.
biological_context: Mouse brain long-term memory formation in the basolateral amygdala
main_goals: The main goal was to illuminate the cellular and molecular architecture of the role of the basolateral amygdala in long-term memory using spatial and single-cell transcriptomics. The study aimed to identify memory-specific transcriptional signatures in subpopulations of neurons and astrocytes and to determine how neurons interact with astrocytes to encode long-term memory.

title: Unveiling inflammatory and prehypertrophic cell populations as key contributors to knee cartilage degeneration in osteoarthritis using multi-omics data integration.
biological_context: Osteoarthritis in human knee articular cartilage
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'immunohistochemistry staining', 'quantitative real-time PCR', 'bulk RNA sequencing', 'genome-wide association studies']
main_goals: The study aims to identify and characterize OA-critical cell populations in human knee articular cartilage using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. The study identified novel chondrocyte populations and marker genes and validated them with other omics data. It also highlights specific cell populations as potential therapeutic targets and suggests their potential for patient stratification in clinical trials.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveals that PTPRG activates the m<sup>6</sup>A methyltransferase VIRMA to block mitophagy-mediated neuronal death in Alzheimer's disease.
main_goals: The study aims to understand the mechanism of neuronal death in Alzheimer's disease by using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data. It identifies that microglia subpopulation Mic_PTPRG can communicate with neurons and cause them to express PTPRG, which activates the m<sup>6</sup>A methyltransferase VIRMA to block mitophagy-mediated neuronal death.

title: The cycling and aging mouse female reproductive tract at single-cell resolution.
main_goals: The study systematically characterized morphological and gene expression changes occurring in the mouse female reproductive tract during the estrous cycle, decidualization, and aging using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It reveals the role of fibroblasts in FRT remodeling and suggests a model wherein recurrent FRT remodeling leads to fibrosis and chronic inflammation during aging. The study provides detail into how estrus, pregnancy, and aging shape the organs of the female reproductive tract.

title: Integrating spatial and single-cell transcriptomics to characterize the molecular and cellular architecture of the ischemic mouse brain.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the molecular and spatial characteristics of nonneuronal cells and interactions between cell types in the ischemic brain. It uses spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing to identify gene expression profiles and cell communication pathways in the peri-infarct area of a murine stroke model. The study identifies Lgals9 as a potential treatment target.

title: Resolving the heterogeneous tumour microenvironment in cardiac myxoma through single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'Visium CytAssist spatial transcriptomic (ST) assays']
main_goals: The study aims to dissect the tumor microenvironment (TME) in cardiac myxoma (CM) at single-cell and spatial resolution using single-cell transcriptomic sequencing and spatial transcriptomic assays. The goals include understanding the differentiation of myxoma tumor cells and advancing the understanding of the TME in CM to promote the development of medical therapies.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals heterogeneity of histological subtypes between lepidic and acinar lung adenocarcinoma.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the heterogeneity of histological subtypes in early-stage lung adenocarcinoma using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics. They identified signature gene profiles for lepidic and acinar subtypes and investigated the relationship between CD8+ T cells and PD-L1 expression in tumor endothelial cells.

title: Spatial and single-cell analyses uncover links between ALKBH1 and tumor-associated macrophages in gastric cancer.
main_goals: This study explores the clinical and pathological relevance of ALKBH1 in gastric cancer, its impact on the tumor immune microenvironment, and its potential for precision oncology. They identified ALKBH1 as a potential diagnostic biomarker, linked elevated ALKBH1 expression to macrophage infiltration, and correlated ALKBH1 inactivation with sensitivity to small-molecule drugs.

title: Biomarker Identification in Liver Cancers Using Desorption Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry (DESI-MS) Imaging: An Approach for Spatially Resolved Metabolomics.
main_goals: The paper describes a detailed protocol for using DESI-MS imaging on liver cancer samples to distinguish malignant lesions from adjacent normal liver tissue. The goal is to identify new biomarkers of malignancy using spatially resolved metabolomics.

title: Characterization of the Nucleus Pulposus Progenitor Cells via Spatial Transcriptomics.
main_goals: The study aimed to generate a spatially resolved transcriptional atlas of the mouse intervertebral disc (IVD) using the 10x Genomics Visium platform. The atlas was used to characterize nucleus pulposus progenitor cells (NPPCs) and their spatial distribution within the IVD. The study also aimed to validate or refute previous findings regarding specific NPPC markers like Tie2.

title: Machine learning enables non-Gaussian investigation of changes to peripheral nerves related to electrical stimulation.
main_goals: This study uses machine learning to analyze histological samples of the sciatic nerve in rats after electrical stimulation. They use convolutional neural networks and support vector machines for cell segmentation and analysis. The study highlights the efficacy of machine learning in nerve measurement and identifies anatomical changes even at safe stimulation levels.

title: An atlas of cells in the human tonsil.
main_goals: The study generated an atlas of the human tonsil composed of >556,000 cells profiled across five different data modalities. It identified 121 cell types and states, defined developmental trajectories, and enabled an understanding of the functional units of the tonsil. The atlas was used to annotate cells from B cell-derived mantle cell lymphomas, linking transcriptional heterogeneity to normal B cell differentiation states of the human tonsil.

title: Spatial metabolome of biosynthesis and metabolism in Cyclocarya paliurus leaves.
main_goals: The study aims to obtain the spatial distribution information of metabolites in the leaves of Cyclocarya paliurus using DESI-MSI and non-targeted metabolomics. It analyzes the changes of metabolites in C. paliurus and identifies the main pathways for biosynthesis of flavonoid precursor.

title: Spatial Metabolomics Identifies LPC(18:0) and LPA(18:1) in Advanced Atheroma With Translation to Plasma for Cardiovascular Risk Estimation.
