title: Spatial transcriptomics reveal topological immune landscapes of Asian head and neck angiosarcoma.
data_modalities_used: ['whole genome sequencing', 'gene expression profiling', 'spatial transcriptomics', '10X Visium', 'NanoString profiling']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to reveal the topological immune landscapes of Asian head and neck angiosarcoma. By integrating multi-omic data, it identifies distinct tumor microenvironment profiles and dominant inflammatory signals, aiming to improve treatment strategies.

title: Whole organism profiling of the Timp gene family.
biological_context: Whole organism profiling of Timp gene family in adult mammals
main_goals: To analyze the expression of Timp genes across healthy tissues and cell types in adult mammals using single-cell RNA sequencing data. The study aims to describe unique expression profiles of Timp genes and identify cluster-specific patterns, particularly in stromal and endothelial cells, to provide physiological context for their known functions.

title: Integrating single-cell RNA sequencing with spatial transcriptomics reveals an immune landscape of human myometrium during labour.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'transcriptomics', 'proteomics', 'cytokine arrays', 'Histological staining', 'flow cytometry', 'western blotting']
main_goals: This paper investigates the immune landscape of human myometrium during labor by integrating single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It aims to identify immune cell types, their transcriptional characteristics, distribution, and function, as well as changes in cytokines and cytokine receptors. The study provides insights into the immune mechanisms underlying labor.

title: Integrating single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics reveals MDK-NCL dependent immunosuppressive environment in endometrial carcinoma.
main_goals: This study aimed to assess cell populations in the tumor microenvironment of endometrial carcinoma (EC) by integrating single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. The research identified that EC cells can confer a malignant phenotype to endothelial cells via the MDK-NCL signal, which is also associated with suppressed immune activity.

title: Spatial and temporal dynamics of ATP synthase from mitochondria toward the cell surface.
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatial and temporal dynamics of ectopic ATP synthase (eATP synthase) on cancer cell surfaces. It elucidates the intracellular transport mechanism of eATP synthase from mitochondria to the cell surface, mediated by DRP1 and KIF5B, and its anchoring via mitochondrial-plasma membrane fusion.

title: Single-Cell Spatial Analysis Identifies Regulators of Brain Tumor-Initiating Cells.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'single-cell assay for transposase-accessible chromatin using sequencing', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study performed spatial transcriptomic and single-cell analyses of the mouse and human GBM microenvironment to dissect the impact of distinct anatomical regions on GBM. It identified that the biglycan-LRP6 axis could be a therapeutic target to curb tumor growth by regulating brain tumor-initiating cells (BTICs).

title: Spatially Resolved Transcriptomics Deconvolutes Prognostic Histological Subgroups in Patients with Colorectal Cancer and Synchronous Liver Metastases.
biological_context: Colorectal cancer with synchronous liver metastases
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'genomic assessment', 'bulk transcriptomic assessment', 'IHC', 'GeoMx spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: To determine the practical application of histological assessment of immune cell infiltration and stromal content in predicting outcome following synchronous resection of primary colorectal cancer and CRLM, and to interrogate the underlying functional biology that drives disease progression. The study used spatial transcriptomics to reveal intratumoral and interlesional heterogeneity and identify transcriptomic programs driving different phenotypes.

title: Integrated single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomics captures transitional states in soybean nodule maturation.
biological_context: Soybean nodule maturation and rhizobium-legume symbiosis
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Trajectory Inference']
main_goals: To establish a cell atlas of soybean nodules and roots by integrating single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to understand transitional states in soybean nodule maturation and identify functionally distinct subgroups of uninfected cells and a transitional subtype of infected cells.

title: Spatial Proteomics Analysis of Soft and Stiff Regions in Human Acute Arterial Thrombus.
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the molecular pathological differences between the soft and stiff regions of human arterial thrombus using a spatial proteomic workflow. It identified dysregulated proteins, with TGF-β1 being a prominent fibrosis-related protein, and demonstrated its inhibitory effect on thrombosis in a mouse model. The findings highlight spatially distinct protein compositions in thrombi and suggest TGF-β1 as a therapeutic target.

title: Exploring Spatial Heterogeneity of Immune Cells in Nasopharyngeal Cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial heterogeneity of immune cells in Nasopharyngeal Cancer (NPC) by applying multiplexed tissue analysis. It quantifies protein biomarkers to understand the spatial distribution of cell types and their association with different immune phenotypes (inflamed, immune-excluded, desert). The findings aim to highlight immune-related biomarkers for patient stratification and therapeutic targeting in NPC.

title: Identification of Spatial Proteomic Signatures of Colon Tumor Metastasis: A Digital Spatial Profiling Approach.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify spatial proteomic signatures associated with colon tumor metastasis using a digital spatial profiling approach. The researchers used machine learning and differential co-expression analyses to pinpoint biomarkers within and around the tumor microenvironment that predict recurrence risk. The findings highlight potential biomarkers for developing low-cost assays for prognostication.

title: Multi-omic and spatial dissection of immunotherapy response groups in non-small cell lung cancer.
biological_context: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) immunotherapy response
main_goals: This study aimed to dissect the characteristics of immunotherapy response groups in NSCLC using multi-omic and spatial profiling. It investigated the role of the tumor microenvironment and identified specific molecular markers associated with response or refractoriness to immune checkpoint inhibitors.

title: Analysis of Donor Pancreata Defines the Transcriptomic Signature and Microenvironment of Early Neoplastic Lesions.
biological_context: Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) lesions and healthy adult human pancreas
main_goals: To characterize the transcriptomic signature and microenvironment of early neoplastic lesions (PanIN) in adult human donor pancreata. The study aimed to compare healthy pancreata to pancreatic cancer and peritumoral tissue to understand early tumorigenesis pathways.

title: Vascular mechanisms of post-COVID-19 conditions: Rho-kinase is a novel target for therapy.
biological_context: Post-COVID-19 conditions (long COVID) with a focus on vascular dysfunction.
data_modalities_used: ['blood biomarkers', 'cardiorenal imaging', 'pulmonary imaging', 'gluteal subcutaneous biopsy', 'wire myography', 'histopathology', 'immunohistochemistry', 'spatial transcriptomics', "Masson's trichrome", 'picrosirius red']
main_goals: This study investigated the vascular mechanisms underlying post-COVID-19 conditions, identifying enhanced vascular fibrosis and myosin light chain phosphorylation. It highlights Rho-kinase as a novel therapeutic target for clinical trials in patients with long COVID.

title: Integrated mass spectrometry imaging and metabolomics reveals sublethal effects of indoxacarb on the red fire ant Solenopsis invicta.
biological_context: Red fire ant (Solenopsis invicta) treated with indoxacarb
main_goals: To integrate mass spectrometry imaging and metabolomics to reveal the sublethal effects of indoxacarb on the red fire ant Solenopsis invicta. The study aimed to identify disturbed metabolic expression levels and their spatial distribution within the whole-body tissue of ants treated with indoxacarb, providing insights into the toxicity mechanism.

title: Spatial metabolomics reveal mechanisms of dexamethasone against pediatric pneumonia.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial metabolomics', 'Desorption Electrospray Ionization mass spectrometry imaging', 'molecular biology', 'targeted metabolomics']
main_goals: This study aimed to reveal the mechanisms of dexamethasone against pediatric pneumonia using spatial metabolomics. It identified critical biomarkers and related pathways, validating findings in a rat model to provide evidence for precise treatment.

title: Epigenetic and transcriptomic characterization reveals progression markers and essential pathways in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study characterizes the epigenetic and transcriptomic landscape of ccRCC to identify tumor-specific markers and understand their role in disease progression and spatial heterogeneity. It reveals ceruloplasmin (CP) as a marker associated with reduced survival and explores its function in stroma interactions, while also detailing how BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations affect chromatin accessibility.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomics reveals pathogenesis of viral myocarditis.
biological_context: Viral myocarditis in neonatal mouse hearts
main_goals: This study used integrated single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to create a high-resolution transcriptome map of reovirus-induced myocarditis in neonatal mouse hearts. It aimed to understand the temporal, spatial, and cellular heterogeneity of host-virus interactions. The research identified immune-mediated injury and stress responses, and a complex network of cellular phenotypes and interactions associated with the disease.

title: Spatial transcriptomic profiling of coronary endothelial cells in SARS-CoV-2 myocarditis.
main_goals: The study aimed to examine coronary endothelial and myocardial programming in patients with severe COVID-19 using digital spatial transcriptomics. It investigated the differential expression patterns in myocardial and coronary vascular tissue to assess the paracrine effect of SARS-CoV-2 infection and its link to cardiovascular events. The findings highlight altered myocardial programming potentially associated with capillary endothelial cells, but diminished endotheliitis in larger vessels.

title: Using mass spectrometry imaging to visualize age-related subcellular disruption.
biological_context: Age-related diseases, cellular stress, organelle dysfunction
main_goals: To visualize age-related subcellular disruption using mass spectrometry imaging. The paper focuses on the role of organelle dysfunction, metabolic flux changes, and endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria contact sites in aging. It highlights the need for tools that can resolve metabolite pools and metabolic flux at single-cell resolution in aging models.

title: Spatiotemporally deciphering the mysterious mechanism of persistent HPV-induced malignant transition and immune remodelling from HPV-infected normal cervix, precancer to cervical cancer: Integrating single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptome.
biological_context: Cervical cancer progression from normal cervix to precancerous lesions (HSIL) and malignant transition, mediated by HPV infection.
main_goals: This study aimed to decipher the spatiotemporal mechanism of HPV-induced malignant transition and immune remodelling during cervical carcinogenesis. It integrated single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to map cellular heterogeneity and spatial distribution across disease stages. The findings identified unique HPV-related epithelial clusters, critical node genes, and characterized immune cell dynamics and the evolving tumor microenvironment.

title: Spatial landscape of the tumor immune microenvironment.
main_goals: To characterize the single-cell tumor immune landscapes in brain tumors and lung adenocarcinomas using multiplexed imaging mass cytometry. The studies identified specific cell subtypes and cell-cell interactions correlated with distinct clinical outcomes, providing insights into tumor biology and prognostic prediction based on spatial architecture.

title: Impact of spatial metabolomics on immune-microenvironment in oral cancer prognosis: a clinical report.
data_modalities_used: ['MALDI imaging for metabolites', 'immunohistochemistry for immune markers']
main_goals: This clinical report investigates the impact of spatial metabolomics on the immune microenvironment in oral cancer prognosis. It used MALDI imaging and immunohistochemistry to characterize two primary oral tumors, identifying distinct metabolic and immune profiles associated with recurrence. The findings suggest that altered tumor metabolomics and a modified immune microenvironment could serve as potential markers for recurrence.

title: Ganglioglioma deep transcriptomics reveals primitive neuroectoderm neural precursor-like population.
data_modalities_used: ['single nucleus RNA-seq', 'cellular indexing of transcriptomes and epitopes by sequencing', 'spatially-resolved RNA-seq', 'transcriptomic data']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Transcriptome analysis', 'Gene regulatory network interrogation', 'Developmental trajectory analysis', 'Spatially-resolved transcriptomics', 'Deconvolution']
main_goals: This study aims to characterize gangliogliomas using deep transcriptomic approaches, uncovering a CD34+ neuroectoderm-like neural precursor cell population. The findings aim to refine tumor classification, identify therapeutic targets, and understand the cellular hierarchy and transcriptional control mechanisms within these tumors.

title: Spatial proteomics of tumor microenvironments reveal why location matters.
main_goals: The paper analyzes spatial proteomics of tumor microenvironments to understand why location matters in biological processes. It aims to provide insights into the role of spatial organization within tumors.

title: Cryptosporidium uses multiple distinct secretory organelles to interact with and modify its host cell.
biological_context: Cryptosporidium infection in intestinal epithelial cells
main_goals: This paper generated a whole-cell spatial proteome of Cryptosporidium sporozoites to identify secreted effector proteins. The study discovered multiple distinct secretory organelles and compartment markers, revealing how these secreted proteins assemble at the parasite-host interface to anchor the parasite. Ultimately, it demonstrates that Cryptosporidium employs a complex set of secretion systems to interact with and modify its host cell.

title: Transcriptomic landscapes of effective and failed liver regeneration in humans.
main_goals: This paper aimed to systematically assess early transcriptional changes during liver regeneration in humans and how these processes differ in people with dysfunctional liver regeneration. It identified an aggravated transcriptional inflammatory response with higher ICAM-1 induction in individuals with dysfunctional regeneration, linked to reduced DUSP4 expression in liver sinusoidal endothelial cells.

title: Localized microglia dysregulation impairs central nervous system myelination in development.
biological_context: Human central nervous system development and myelination
main_goals: This paper uses digital spatial transcriptomics to uncover that localized dysregulated innate immune responses in microglia/macrophages are associated with impeded myelination in the developing human brain. It identifies a distinct signature of Type II interferon signaling in poorly myelinating areas and links it to increased mature oligodendrocytes that fail to form myelin processes. The study also identifies Osteopontin (SPP1) as a potential biomarker.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics during human organogenesis.
main_goals: To provide a global view of human embryonic cell-type specification during organogenesis using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. The study sheds light on developmental processes such as axial patterning, stage transition, and differences between human and mouse embryonic development.

title: The cell type composition of the adult mouse brain revealed by single cell and spatial genomics.
biological_context: Adult mouse brain cell type composition
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell type composition analysis', 'Spatial gene expression analysis', 'Heritability enrichment analysis']
main_goals: To construct a comprehensive atlas of cell types in each mouse brain structure by integrating single-nucleus RNA-seq and Slide-seq. The study characterized cell type diversity, developed a framework for genetic access to cell types, elucidated signaling, and identified region-specific specializations in gene expression.

title: Glioblastoma-instructed microglia transition to heterogeneous phenotypic states with phagocytic and dendritic cell-like features in patient tumors and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts.
main_goals: To systematically characterize the tumor microenvironment (TME) in Glioblastoma (GBM) patient-derived orthotopic xenografts (PDOXs) and patient tumors at the single-cell and spatial levels. The study investigates the phenotypic heterogeneity of GBM-instructed microglia and other myeloid cells, and how these adaptations are recapitulated in preclinical models. It also examines the impact of temozolomide treatment on the TME.

title: Spatial metabolomics reveal divergent cardenolide processing in the monarch (Danaus plexippus) and the common crow butterfly (Euploea core).
biological_context: Cardenolide processing in butterfly caterpillars (Danaus plexippus and Euploea core)
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial distribution and processing of cardenolides in two butterfly species, Danaus plexippus and Euploea core, using mass spectrometry imaging. It reveals that monarchs sequester cardenolides, while crows degrade them in the gut lumen, identifying integument cells as the final storage site in monarchs. The research highlights the utility of mass spectrometry imaging for understanding the kinetics of various compounds in insects.

title: Distinct myofibre domains of the human myotendinous junction revealed by single-nucleus RNA sequencing.
main_goals: This study uses single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to profile the human myotendinous junction. The aim is to identify genes and distinct myonuclei profiles characterizing this specialized muscle domain and its potential role in musculoskeletal pathologies. The findings reveal specific transcriptomic signatures at the MTJ.

title: KLF5 inhibition potentiates anti-PD1 efficacy by enhancing CD8<sup>+</sup> T-cell-dependent antitumor immunity.
data_modalities_used: ['RNA sequencing', 'immunohistochemistry', 'western blotting', 'real time-PCR', 'ELISA', 'luciferase assay', 'chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)', 'flow cytometry', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of Krüppel-like Factor 5 (KLF5) in the tumor microenvironment and its impact on anti-PD1 therapy efficacy. The authors found that KLF5 inhibition enhances anti-PD1 efficacy by increasing CD8+ T-cell-dependent antitumor immunity through the KLF5/COX2/PGE2 axis. They also developed a KLF5/COX2-associated immune score (KC-IS) to predict patient survival.

title: An integrated single cell and spatial transcriptomic map of human white adipose tissue.
biological_context: Human white adipose tissue (WAT) across different depots (subcutaneous, omental, perivascular) and its association with metabolic states.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Deconvolution', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: To create a high-resolution, integrated map of human white adipose tissue by combining single-cell and spatial transcriptomic data. This map aims to identify cell subpopulations, their spatial organization, and their associations with metabolic states like insulin resistance and dyslipidemia.

title: Sharp cell-type-identity changes differentiate the retrosplenial cortex from the neocortex.
biological_context: Mouse retrosplenial cortex development and cell-type organization
data_modalities_used: ['transcriptomics', 'multiplexed in situ hybridization', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Type Identification', 'Spatial Mapping']
main_goals: This study aims to spatially map and interpret the excitatory cell-type landscape of the mouse retrosplenial cortex (RSC). It investigates sharp changes in gene expression and cell types at the granular-dysgranular border of the RSC, and compares these to the neocortex, revealing distinct cell-type compositions in homologous laminae. The findings highlight intrinsic cell-type specializations within the RSC and an organizational principle of sharp cell-type identity variation.

title: APOE modulates microglial immunometabolism in response to age, amyloid pathology, and inflammatory challenge.
biological_context: Alzheimer's disease and aging, specifically focusing on the role of Apolipoprotein E (APOE) in microglial immunometabolism.
main_goals: To systematically address the role of APOE across age, neuroinflammation, and AD pathology by combining multiple transcriptomic and metabolic analyses. The study aimed to understand how APOE, particularly the E4 allele, modulates microglial immunometabolism and its specific responses to amyloid pathology and inflammatory challenges.

title: Single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics reveal cancer-associated fibroblasts in glioblastoma with protumoral effects.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Sequence Analysis, RNA']
main_goals: This paper identifies cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in glioblastoma for the first time, characterizing their protumoral effects and interactions with glioblastoma stem cells (GSCs). It demonstrates CAF proximity to GSCs, endothelial cells, and M2 macrophages, and highlights their role in GSC enrichment and M2 macrophage polarization. The study also infers crosstalk mediators and shows that CAFs enhance in vivo tumor growth.

title: Cell-type profiling of the sympathetic nervous system using spatial transcriptomics and spatial mapping of mRNA.
biological_context: Development of the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) in chick embryos
data_modalities_used: ['Slide-seq', 'scRNA-seq', '10x Genomics Visium', 'HiPlex RNAscope fluorescence in situ hybridization', 'confocal microscopy']
main_goals: To address the unclear molecular identification of neural progenitor cells in the developing sympathetic nervous system by integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-seq. The study aimed to demonstrate a robust strategy for acquiring and integrating these data types to improve resolution of molecular heterogeneities in neural tissue architectures.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals niche-specific enrichment and vulnerabilities of radial glial stem-like cells in malignant gliomas.
biological_context: Malignant gliomas (Diffuse midline glioma-H3K27M mutant and glioblastoma)
data_modalities_used: ['short-read spatial transcriptomics', 'long-read spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell transcriptomic datasets', 'human neural stem cell derived orthotopic DMG model']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: To reveal the spatial organization of cellular states and niche-specific regulatory programs in malignant gliomas (DMG and GBM) using spatial transcriptomics. The study identified radial glial stem-like (RG-like) cells in neuron-rich invasive niches and confirmed the role of FAM20C in RG-like cell invasive growth.

title: Spatiotemporal mapping of immune and stem cell dysregulation after volumetric muscle loss.
main_goals: To map the spatial distribution of immune and stem cell dysregulation after volumetric muscle loss (VML) and identify cellular crosstalk driving aberrant regeneration. The study aims to understand the mechanisms behind VML-induced fibrosis and inflammation and to explore potential therapeutic targets. The findings suggest that targeting specific cellular circuits can enhance muscle regeneration and reduce negative outcomes.

title: Moxibustion improves hypothalamus Aqp4 polarization in APP/PS1 mice: Evidence from spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study investigates whether moxibustion can improve the polarization of Aquaporin-4 (AQP4) around the blood-brain barrier (BBB) in Alzheimer's disease (AD) models. Using spatial transcriptomics, the research analyzed AQP4 expression and polarization in wild-type, APP/PS1, and moxibustion-treated APP/PS1 mice, finding that moxibustion reversed abnormal AQP4 polarization, particularly in the hypothalamus. The study also identified other genes with similar depolarization patterns and linked improvements to increased mitochondrial respiratory chain enzyme expression.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics revealed local invasion-related genes in colorectal cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to reveal genes associated with local invasion in colorectal cancer (CRC) by leveraging spatial transcriptomics. The research identified genes overexpressed at the invasive margin and investigated their correlation with patient prognosis, as well as validated the functional role of AKR1B1 in CRC cell behavior.

title: Spatial transcriptomics analysis of zone-dependent hepatic ischemia-reperfusion injury murine model.
biological_context: Hepatic ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury in a murine model
main_goals: To dissect I/R injury patterns and their associated molecular changes in the liver using spatial transcriptomics. The study reveals pericentral zones are most sensitive to I/R injury and investigates potential therapeutic strategies.

title: Spatial proteomics reveals secretory pathway disturbances caused by neuropathy-associated TECPR2.
biological_context: Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy 9 (HSAN9) cell model
main_goals: This study uses spatial proteomics to investigate the molecular consequences of TECPR2 deficiency in a HSAN9 cell model. It aims to understand how TECPR2's role in the secretory pathway and autophagy impacts neuronal function and to identify specific trafficking and sorting defects.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Depict Ligand-Receptor Cross-talk Heterogeneity at the Tumor-Stroma Interface in Long-Term Ovarian Cancer Survivors.
biological_context: High-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC) and its tumor microenvironment (TME) in long-term survivors (LTS) and short-term survivors (STS)
main_goals: To investigate the stromal heterogeneity of the tumor microenvironment (TME) in ovarian cancer using spatial transcriptomics, identify predictive markers of long-term survivors (LTS), and explore ligand-receptor cross-talk between tumor cells and cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in relation to survival. The study aims to reveal spatially resolved CAF-tumor cross-talk signaling networks associated with long-term survival.

title: Identification and characterization of a proliferative cell population in estrogen receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer through spatial and single-cell transcriptomics.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell RNA-sequencing', 'scRNA-seq', 'protein-based dual immunohistochemical (IHC)', 'public breast cancer cohorts']
main_goals: This study applied spatial and single-cell transcriptomics to identify and characterize a proliferative cell population in estrogen receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer. The research elucidated the role of this population in estrogen-dependent tumor growth and its relationship with clinical outcomes and treatment response.

title: Genetic perturbations go spatial.
main_goals: This paper reviews a strategy to track pooled CRISPR-modified cells in vivo using protein barcodes (Pro-Codes) and measure their impact on the tumor microenvironment through multiplexed imaging and spatial transcriptomics. It highlights the importance of cell intrinsic features and extrinsic interactions.

title: Genomic and microenvironmental heterogeneity shaping epithelial-to-mesenchymal trajectories in cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Trajectory Inference', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To develop a method to evaluate EMT transformation in individual tumors based on transcriptomic signals. The study explores EMT trajectories in various epithelial cancers, identifies prognostic macro-states, and investigates the spatial heterogeneity and microenvironmental interactions associated with EMT. It also catalogs genomic events underlying EMT evolution.

title: Distinct tissue niches direct lung immunopathology via CCL18 and CCL21 in severe COVID-19.
main_goals: This study investigates the local immune response in severe COVID-19 using advanced imaging and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies activated adventitial niches as crucial microenvironments that orchestrate prolonged lung immunopathology. The research highlights the roles of CCL21 and CCL18 in endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, fibrosis, and T cell accumulation, proposing immune-stromal interaction mechanisms for chronic inflammation.

title: Increased fatty acid metabolism and decreased glycolysis are hallmarks of metabolic reprogramming within microglia in degenerating white matter during recovery from experimental stroke.
data_modalities_used: ['liquid chromatography-mass spectroscopy (LC-MS)', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'RNA in situ hybridization']
main_goals: To evaluate metabolic changes during stroke recovery in mice. The study identified increased fatty acid metabolism and decreased glycolysis in microglia within degenerating white matter up to 12 weeks after stroke, as indicated by metabolomic and spatial transcriptomic analyses.

title: In vivo profiling of the Zucchini proximal proteome in the Drosophila ovary.
biological_context: Zucchini proximal proteome in the Drosophila ovary
main_goals: This study used TurboID proximity labeling to investigate the interactome of Zucchini (Zuc), a key factor of piRNA biogenesis in the Drosophila ovary. Quantitative mass spectrometry identified Zuc-proximal proteins, many localized to the outer mitochondrial membrane, and revealed previously unreported interacting partners. The functional relevance of several candidates was validated by assessing transposable element derepression.

title: Unique DUOX2<sup>+</sup>ACE2<sup>+</sup> small cholangiocytes are pathogenic targets for primary biliary cholangitis.
main_goals: This study identifies unique DUOX2+ACE2+ small cholangiocytes as pathogenic targets in primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). It found their selective decrease in PBC patients is associated with disease severity and that increased serum anti-pIgR autoantibody levels are present in PBC patients. The research suggests preserving these cholangiocytes and targeting anti-pIgR autoantibodies could be therapeutic strategies for PBC.

title: Spatial and molecular profiling of the mononuclear phagocyte network in classic Hodgkin lymphoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Clustering']
main_goals: This study aimed to define the global immune-cell composition of classic Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL) and non-lymphoma lymph nodes using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and multiplexed immunofluorescence. It sought to explore the organization of mononuclear phagocyte (MNP) networks and their interactions with Hodgkin Reed-Sternberg cells (HRSCs). The research aimed to reveal the complexity and spatial polarization within the MNP compartment and their potential roles in immune evasion by cHL.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal aberrant lymphoid developmental programs driving granuloma formation.
main_goals: This study investigated granuloma formation in sarcoidosis by performing single-cell sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The research aimed to understand the immune environment and reconstruct gene regulatory networks to identify key cell types and processes involved in granuloma development. The findings suggest that granulomas adopt aspects of lymphoid organ development in aberrant combinations.

title: Targeting Immune-Fibroblast Crosstalk in Myocardial Infarction and Cardiac Fibrosis.
biological_context: Human myocardial infarction and cardiac fibrosis
data_modalities_used: ['multi-omic single-cell gene expression', 'epitope mapping', 'chromatin accessibility profiling', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'in vivo mouse models', 'cultured human heart fibroblasts', 'cultured human dermal fibroblasts']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference']
main_goals: This study investigated the molecular mechanisms of immune-fibroblast crosstalk in human cardiac disease. It identified disease-associated fibroblast trajectories, revealed interactions between macrophages and fibroblasts via IL-1β signaling, and validated the therapeutic potential of targeting inflammation to treat fibrosis.

title: Maintenance of pluripotency in the entire ectoderm enables neural crest formation.
main_goals: This study investigates the maintenance of pluripotent-like stem cells in the entire ectoderm during embryogenesis and their role in neural crest formation. It reveals the unexpected persistence of pluripotent cells across the ectoderm late in neurulation, challenging current understanding of gastrulation and proposing a mechanism for neural crest stemness.

title: Multimodal human thymic profiling reveals trajectories and cellular milieu for T agonist selection.
biological_context: Human thymus development and T cell selection
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study used CITE-seq and spatial transcriptomics to profile the human thymus. It aimed to understand thymocyte trajectories and cellular interactions involved in T cell agonist selection, identifying divergence points and the roles of various cell types in different spatial niches.

title: MALDI mass spectrometry imaging shows a gradual change in the proteome landscape during mouse ovarian folliculogenesis.
main_goals: This study aimed to characterize the proteome of individual mouse ovarian follicles at different growth stages using a spatial proteomics approach. It correlated proteomic data with spatial information from MALDI-MSI to map protein profiles within the native ovarian context, identifying proteins with gradual quantitative changes during follicle differentiation.

title: A cellular taxonomy of the adult human spinal cord.
main_goals: To present a cellular taxonomy of the adult human spinal cord using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics, and to demonstrate its relevance to human disease by analyzing spinal motoneurons. The study identified numerous glial and neuronal clusters and highlighted specialized molecular features of motoneurons, suggesting reasons for their selective vulnerability in diseases like ALS.

title: Analysis of donor pancreata defines the transcriptomic signature and microenvironment of early pre-neoplastic pancreatic lesions.
biological_context: Early pre-neoplastic pancreatic lesions and the adult human pancreas microenvironment
data_modalities_used: ['multiplex immunohistochemistry', 'single cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'histopathological analysis']
main_goals: To characterize the transcriptomic signature and microenvironment of early pre-neoplastic pancreatic lesions (PanIN) in adult human pancreata. The study aims to understand the early stages of pancreatic tumorigenesis and identify factors that may influence malignant progression.

title: Spatial transcriptomics analysis of neoadjuvant cabozantinib and nivolumab in advanced hepatocellular carcinoma identifies independent mechanisms of resistance and recurrence.
biological_context: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treated with neoadjuvant cabozantinib and nivolumab
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To characterize the tumor microenvironment in HCC resection specimens from a clinical trial of neoadjuvant cabozantinib and nivolumab using spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to identify the molecular and cellular landscapes underlying treatment responses and recurrence, and to discover new therapeutic targets.

title: Gene Expression Changes in Cultured Reactive Rat Astrocyte Models and Comparison to Device-Associated Effects in the Brain.
biological_context: Foreign body response to implanted neurotechnology
main_goals: To compare the transcriptomic profiles of cultured reactive astrocytes with in vivo gene expression changes surrounding implanted devices in the brain. The study aims to identify biomarkers of the foreign body response to implantable neurotechnology and assess in vitro model development. It reveals overlapping gene expression between culture models and tissue samples, with cytokine-induced cells showing more similarity to chronic implantation effects.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals unique gene expression changes in different brain regions after sleep deprivation.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to investigate the impact of sleep deprivation across different brain regions. It identifies pronounced gene expression differences, particularly in the hippocampus, neocortex, hypothalamus, and thalamus, with region-specific changes in both the genes and their regulation. The research also highlights the development of bioinformatic tools for anatomical registration and brain-wide comparison of gene expression data.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals a conserved segment polarity program that governs muscle patterning in Nematostella vectensis.
biological_context: Larval development in Nematostella vectensis, focusing on muscle patterning and segment polarity
main_goals: The study aimed to identify the molecular basis for segment polarization in developing Nematostella vectensis larvae. It utilized spatial transcriptomics to create a 3D gene expression atlas, leading to the identification of Lbx and Uncx genes. Functional analysis confirmed their role in segment polarity and muscle patterning.

title: Spatiotemporal immune atlas of the first clinical-grade, gene-edited pig-to-human kidney xenotransplant.
main_goals: This study investigated the human immune response to a gene-edited pig kidney xenotransplant using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. It aimed to understand the infiltration and phenotype of human immune cells within the xenograft under conventional pharmacologic immunosuppression. The findings demonstrate that standard immunosuppression can limit the infiltration of human immune cells early after xenotransplantation.

title: Single-cell and spatial multi-omics highlight effects of anti-integrin therapy across cellular compartments in ulcerative colitis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to identify inflammatory cells contributing to ulcerative colitis (UC) and affected by vedolizumab (VDZ) treatment. The researchers performed single-cell and spatial multi-omics analyses to investigate the broader effects of VDZ beyond lymphocyte trafficking. Findings highlight alterations in mononuclear phagocyte and fibroblast subsets in active colitis and their potential role in VDZ responsiveness.

title: Identification of a tumour immune barrier in the HCC microenvironment that determines the efficacy of immunotherapy.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Ligand-Receptor Network Analysis']
main_goals: This paper aims to identify spatial structures within the tumor microenvironment (TME) that influence immunotherapy efficacy in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It identifies a tumor immune barrier (TIB) formed by SPP1+ macrophages and cancer-associated fibroblasts, which limits immune infiltration and impacts anti-PD-1 treatment response. The study proposes disrupting the TIB by blocking SPP1 as a therapeutic strategy to enhance immunotherapy in HCC.

title: MIF promotes cell invasion by the LRP1-uPAR interaction in pancreatic cancer cells.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Visualization', 'cell invasion assays', 'proliferation assays', 'in vivo tumorigenicity', 'transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of Macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) in pancreatic cancer progression. It demonstrates a novel link between MIF and urokinase-type plasminogen activator receptor (uPAR) in promoting cell invasion, mediated by the LRP1 receptor. The findings suggest MIF as a potential therapeutic target for pancreatic cancer.

title: Murine breast cancers disorganize the liver transcriptome in a zonated manner.
biological_context: Murine breast cancers disorganizing liver transcriptome
main_goals: Investigate the abundance and zonation of hepatic genes in cancer-bearing mice using spatial transcriptomics. Demonstrate that breast cancers affect liver zonation in various distinct manners depending on biological pathways and activate innate immune cells in zonated manners, disrupting zonated liver functions.

title: The power of combined spatial transcriptomics and genome wide association studies (GWAS) approaches to heritable prostate cancer.
main_goals: This paper discusses the potential of combining spatial transcriptomics and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) to better understand heritable prostate cancer. It aims to leverage these approaches for precision medicine in the context of this disease.

title: The relevance between hypoxia-dependent spatial transcriptomics and the prognosis and efficacy of immunotherapy in claudin-low breast cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Tumor Microenvironment']
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial heterogeneity of hypoxia in claudin-low breast cancer using spatial transcriptomics and immunofluorescence. It aims to correlate this hypoxia-dependent spatial distribution with patient prognosis and immunotherapy response, identifying potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Multiplexed 3D atlas of state transitions and immune interaction in colorectal cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper uses multiplexed tissue imaging, 3D reconstruction, spatial statistics, and machine learning to identify cell types and states underlying morphological features in colorectal cancer. It reveals recurrent transitions between tumor morphologies and investigates immune cell suppression at the tumor invasive margin, highlighting interconnected tertiary lymphoid structures with graded molecular properties.

title: Spatial and single-cell transcriptomics decipher the cellular environment containing HLA-G+ cancer cells and SPP1+ macrophages in colorectal cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the cellular interactions at the invasion front of colorectal cancer (CRC) using spatial and single-cell transcriptomics. The findings highlight that CRC cells at the invasion front induce SPP1+ macrophages via HLA-G, conferring anti-tumor immunity, and promoting CRC cell proliferation and invasion. It elucidates specific cell-cell signaling pathways within the tumor microenvironment.

title: High-Resolution Analysis of Mononuclear Phagocytes Reveals GPNMB as a Prognostic Marker in Human Colorectal Liver Metastasis.
main_goals: This study aims to identify prognostic markers in human colorectal liver metastasis (CLM) by analyzing mononuclear phagocytes. It uses single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to characterize macrophage populations and their association with clinical outcomes, highlighting GPNMB as a negative prognostic marker.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics reveals pro-inflammatory fibroblast involved in lymphocyte recruitment through CXCL8 and CXCL10.
biological_context: human oral mucosa in health and oral chronic inflammatory disease
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplex fluorescence in situ hybridisation', 'sequencing']
main_goals: To characterize human oral mucosa in health and chronic inflammatory disease by integrating single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and multiplex fluorescence in situ hybridisation. The study aims to define spatial arrangements of cells, identify specialized epithelial and stromal compartments, and map a pathogenic fibroblast population involved in lymphocyte recruitment.

title: Lineage-specific regulatory changes in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy unraveled by single-nucleus RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: To elucidate lineage-specific changes in pathological cardiac remodeling of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) using single-nucleus RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. The study identified key genes involved in cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and cardiac fibrosis progression, and validated findings experimentally.

title: Clinical Significance of Signal Regulatory Protein Alpha (SIRPα) Expression in Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
main_goals: This study aimed to clarify the clinical significance of SIRPα expression in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It investigated the correlation between SIRPα expression and clinicopathologic factors, patient survival, and immune cell infiltration. The findings suggest that high SIRPα expression indicates poor prognosis in HCC and propose SIRPα blockage as a potential treatment strategy.

title: Hypercapnia alters stroma-derived Wnt production to limit β-catenin signaling and proliferation in AT2 cells.
biological_context: Lung repair after injury, specifically in the context of COVID-19 and hypercapnia
main_goals: This paper investigates how hypercapnia affects lung repair by examining its impact on β-catenin signaling and proliferation in alveolar type II (AT2) cells. The study demonstrates that hypercapnia alters Wnt production in fibroblasts, leading to reduced AT2 cell proliferation, and suggests this mechanism contributes to impaired lung repair in conditions like COVID-19.

title: High cardiomyocyte diversity in human early prenatal heart development.
main_goals: This paper characterizes human prenatal cardiomyocytes using integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies eight distinct cardiomyocyte types with location-dependent properties and explores their ligand-receptor interactions with other cell types. The study highlights the heterogeneity and complexity of early prenatal heart development.

title: Multimodal single-cell and whole-genome sequencing of small, frozen clinical specimens.
biological_context: Melanoma and Uveal Melanoma Liver Metastasis
main_goals: This study demonstrates the feasibility of performing multimodal single-cell and whole-genome sequencing on small, frozen clinical specimens. It shows that these methods can yield high-quality biological data comparable to fresh tissues, while mitigating artifacts. The research illustrates the ability to resolve cellular, genomic, spatial, and clonotype dynamics during anti-PD-1 therapy in melanoma and provides a single-cell atlas of uveal melanoma liver metastasis.

title: Subclonal evolution and expansion of spatially distinct THY1-positive cells is associated with recurrence in glioblastoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the molecular pathways mediating glioblastoma recurrence and resistance to temozolomide and radiation. It identifies THY1-positive mesenchymal cells in the perivascular niche as key drivers of recurrence. The study also demonstrates that inhibiting TGFΒRI activity restores sensitivity to chemoradiation.

title: Reconstruction of Plastid Proteomes of Apicomplexans and Close Relatives Reveals the Major Evolutionary Outcomes of Cryptic Plastids.
biological_context: Apicomplexans, chrompodellids, and squirmids (ACS clade), parasites
main_goals: Reconstruct the evolution of cryptic plastids in the ACS clade by generating new transcriptomes, constructing a phylogenomic tree, and examining the distribution of plastid proteins. The study aims to understand the degrees of plastid reduction and identify potential evolutionary innovations.

title: Insulin-like growth factor 1 reduces coronary atherosclerosis in pigs with familial hypercholesterolemia.
biological_context: Coronary atherosclerosis in pigs with familial hypercholesterolemia
main_goals: This study investigates the therapeutic potential of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in reducing coronary atherosclerosis in pigs with familial hypercholesterolemia. IGF-1 was found to decrease atheroma burden, promote plaque stability, and reduce systemic oxidative stress and chemokine levels, providing evidence for potential clinical trials.

title: Combined Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Reveal the Metabolic Evolvement of Breast Cancer during Early Dissemination.
biological_context: Breast cancer dissemination to axillary lymph nodes
main_goals: This study investigates the metabolic changes in breast cancer cells during early dissemination to axillary lymph nodes. It identifies a specific disseminated cancer cell cluster with high oxidative phosphorylation and tracks the metabolic transition from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation as an early event in lymph node metastasis.

title: Molecular and spatial signatures of mouse brain aging at single-cell resolution.
main_goals: This paper generated a high-resolution cell atlas of brain aging within the frontal cortex and striatum using spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomics. It quantified changes in gene expression and spatial organization of major cell types over the mouse lifespan, observing more pronounced changes in non-neuronal cells. The study identified molecular and spatial signatures of glial and immune cell activation during aging and compared these to inflammatory challenge.

title: Molecular characterization of onychomatricoma: Spatial profiling reveals the role of onychofibroblasts in its pathogenesis.
biological_context: Onychomatricoma (OM), a rare nail unit tumour
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: To characterize molecular features involved in the pathogenesis of onychomatricoma (OM) using digital spatial profiling (DSP) and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq). The study aimed to identify genes and pathways contributing to OM development, particularly focusing on the role of onychofibroblasts and Wnt signaling. The findings suggest that OM is a tumor with a significant origin from onychofibroblasts and is associated with upregulated Wnt signals.

title: Resolving the gene expression maps of human first-trimester chorionic villi with spatial transcriptome.
main_goals: This study used the modified Stereo-seq method to map the spatial transcriptome of human placental villi in the first trimester. It identified cell types and their spatial distribution, and analyzed cell-cell communication and regulatory activities to understand placental development, physiology, and pathology.

title: Quantitative spatial evaluation of tumor-immune interactions in the immunotherapy setting of metastatic melanoma lymph nodes.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: This study aimed to quantitatively and spatially characterize tumor-immune interactions within metastatic melanoma lymph nodes using multiplex immunofluorescence. The goal was to identify spatial-immune signatures that inform recurrence risk following anti-PD1 immunotherapy. The research found specific spatial patterns, like a community cluster of tumor and dendritic cells and enrichment of dendritic cells in cytotoxic T cell and tumor cell neighborhoods, associated with no recurrence.

title: A spatially resolved atlas of the human lung characterizes a gland-associated immune niche.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aims to redefine the tissue architecture of the human lung by using multi-omic single cell/nuclei and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies macro and micro-anatomical tissue compartments and discovers a survival niche for IgA plasma cells in airway submucosal glands, with implications for respiratory health.

title: Stromal Reprogramming through Dual PDGFRα/β Blockade Boosts the Efficacy of Anti-PD-1 Immunotherapy in Fibrotic Tumors.
main_goals: The study aimed to investigate stromal reprogramming via dual PDGFRα/β blockade to enhance anti-PD-1 immunotherapy efficacy in fibrotic tumors. It elucidated the mechanism involving PMN-MDSC recruitment and demonstrated synergistic tumor suppression through combined treatment, highlighting stromal reprogramming's impact on immune reactivation.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics reveals innervation-responsive functional clusters in skeletal muscle.
biological_context: Skeletal muscle innervation and response to denervation
main_goals: This study uses spatially resolved transcriptomics and immunofluorescence to identify innervation-responsive functional clusters in skeletal muscle. It characterizes the spatial distribution and nerve dependence of specific pathways like atrophic signaling and polyamine metabolism, providing a resource for future studies on skeletal muscle homeostasis.

title: Mechanism of Rotenone Toxicity against Plutella xylostella: New Perspective from a Spatial Metabolomics and Lipidomics Study.
main_goals: To investigate the in situ metabolic regulation of Plutella xylostella towards rotenone using spatial metabolomics and lipidomics. The study aimed to understand how rotenone affects purine and amino acid metabolisms and lipids within the insect, providing insights into its toxicity mechanism.

title: Spatial characterization of the effect of age and sex on macular layer thicknesses and foveal pit morphology.
biological_context: Human macula morphology and retinal layer thicknesses
main_goals: To characterize the spatial effects of age and sex on macular retinal layer thicknesses and foveal pit morphology using advanced OCT image analysis. The study aims to create a detailed database of normative retinal layer thickness maps and foveal pit shapes to aid in differentiating natural changes from disease-related ones.

title: Investigation on property differences of ginseng and American ginseng by spatial metabolomics of neurochemicals with desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry imaging.
biological_context: Rat brain neurochemical distribution and metabolism in response to ginseng and American ginseng
main_goals: This work aimed to screen neurochemicals related to the warm and cool properties of ginseng and American ginseng, investigate their distributions in the rat brain, and explore their metabolic mechanisms. The study applied spatial metabolomics using DESI-MSI to identify and classify neurochemical markers associated with these properties.

title: Mucosal exposure to non-tuberculous mycobacteria elicits B cell-mediated immunity against pulmonary tuberculosis.
biological_context: Pulmonary tuberculosis immunity and vaccine efficacy modulation by non-tuberculous mycobacteria exposure
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study investigates the effect of simultaneous BCG immunization and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) exposure on protection against pulmonary tuberculosis in a mouse model. It aims to elucidate the role of B cells and germinal center formation in this enhanced immunity. The findings suggest that NTM exposure improves BCG efficacy by promoting B cell-mediated immune responses.

title: Spatial transcriptomics landscape of lesions from non-communicable inflammatory skin diseases.
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatial transcriptomics landscape of lesions from non-communicable inflammatory skin diseases (ncISD). It identifies localized inflammatory amplification cascades initiated by a low number of cytokine transcripts within abundant immune cell infiltrates.

title: Single-cell transcriptomic and spatial landscapes of the developing human pancreas.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell trajectory inference', 'Spatial differentiation trajectories', 'Cell-cell connectivity analysis']
main_goals: This paper presents detailed transcriptomic analysis of cell types in the developing human pancreas, integrating single-cell RNA sequencing with spatial transcriptomics. It aims to reveal temporal-spatial gene cascades and identify progenitor populations and their differentiation pathways. The study also explores mesenchymal contributions to exocrine acinar cell states and predicts interactions between Schwann cells and endocrine progenitors.

title: Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Decodes Wharton's Jelly-Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cells Heterogeneity and a Subpopulation with Wound Repair Signatures.
main_goals: This study systematically analyzes the characteristics of WJ-MSCs using single-cell and spatial transcriptome sequencing to understand their heterogeneity and identify functional subpopulations. It characterizes four WJ-MSC subpopulations and highlights a biofunctional-type subpopulation with promising wound repair properties in vitro and in vivo, enriched in the fetal segment of the umbilical cord.

title: A human fetal lung cell atlas uncovers proximal-distal gradients of differentiation and key regulators of epithelial fates.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'single-cell ATAC sequencing', 'high-throughput spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell imaging']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Visualization', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper presents a multiomic cell atlas of human lung development, combining single-cell RNA and ATAC sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and imaging. It identifies new cell states, including developmental-specific secretory progenitors and a subtype of neuroendocrine cell. The atlas is used to generate and test predictions about cell-cell signaling and transcription factor hierarchies using organoid models.

title: Persistent alveolar type 2 dysfunction and lung structural derangement in post-acute COVID-19.
main_goals: This study investigates the long-term effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection on lung tissue pathology in patients who died post-acute COVID-19. It uses multiplexed imaging to compare their lung tissue with acute COVID-19, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, and healthy lung tissue. The findings reveal persistent viral presence, accumulation of senescent alveolar type 2 cells, and fibrosis with hypervascularization in post-acute COVID-19 lungs.

title: Eukaryotic evolution: Spatial proteomics sheds light on mitochondrial reduction.
biological_context: Mitochondrial reduction in a free-living protist
main_goals: The study delivers the first multi-organelle spatial proteome of a free-living protist. It uncovers a previously overlooked function of highly reduced mitochondria.

title: Spatial transcriptomic characterization of COVID-19 pneumonitis identifies immune circuits related to tissue injury.
main_goals: This study used spatial transcriptomics to characterize COVID-19 pneumonitis and identify immune circuits related to tissue injury. It found a common immune-cell signaling circuit in severe tissue areas involving cytotoxic lymphocytes and pro-inflammatory macrophages, with IFNG expression by cytotoxic lymphocytes associated with chemokine induction. The study's findings may inform future therapeutic strategies for COVID-19.

title: A mass spectrometry imaging approach on spatiotemporal distribution of multiple alkaloids in Gelsemium elegans.
main_goals: To simultaneously analyze the spatiotemporal distribution of multiple alkaloids in Gelsemium elegans using DESI-MSI. The study aimed to visualize alkaloid distribution in different organs and growth stages, revealing diffusion and transfer patterns during development.

title: A spatiotemporal steroidogenic regulatory network in human fetal adrenal glands and gonads.
biological_context: Human fetal adrenal glands and gonads during sexual differentiation
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: To analyze the spatiotemporal regulatory network of steroidogenesis in human fetal adrenal glands and gonads. The study aims to understand the coordination of steroidogenic and non-steroidogenic cells in adrenal cortex development and steroid synthesis, and how gene expression shifts to accelerate DHEA synthesis in males and cortisol synthesis in females during sexual differentiation.

title: B cell expansion hinders the stroma-epithelium regenerative cross talk during mucosal healing.
main_goals: This study longitudinally examined immune cell composition during intestinal damage and regeneration. It found that expanded B cells during mucosal healing hinder epithelial-stromal cross-talk, impairing tissue repair. B cell depletion accelerated recovery and enhanced tissue remodeling.

title: Spatial metabolomics identifies lipid profiles of human carotid atherosclerosis.
data_modalities_used: ['histological staining', 'Desorption electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry imaging (DESI-MSI)', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study investigated the spatial lipid profiles of human carotid atherosclerotic plaques across different pathological stages using DESI-MSI. It aimed to correlate these lipid profiles with histological information and identify distinct metabolic pathways in different plaque regions. The findings reveal spatial metabolic differences critical for atherosclerosis progression.

title: Assessment of spatial transcriptomics for oncology discovery.
biological_context: Oncology discovery, specifically in pancreatic adenocarcinoma
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Biomarkers', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper assesses the utility of spatial transcriptomics for oncology discovery. It demonstrates the capture of key tumor depth features like hypoxia and vasculature, identifies relative cell-type locations, and showcases target identification approaches in clinical pancreatic adenocarcinoma samples by highlighting tumor intrinsic biomarkers and paracrine signaling.

title: Spatial transcriptomics demonstrates the role of CD4 T cells in effector CD8 T cell differentiation during chronic viral infection.
biological_context: Chronic viral infection, specifically in the context of CD4 T cell help for CD8 T cell responses.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics and scRNA-seq to investigate CD4 T cell heterogeneity and cellular interactions during chronic viral infection. It aims to understand the functional and numerical limitations of repopulating CD4 subsets in orchestrating CD8 T cell responses, particularly in the context of CD4 depletion. The findings highlight disruptions in splenic architecture and reduced colocalization between Tfh and progenitor CD8 T cells as potential mechanisms for impaired CD8 differentiation.

title: Microglial INPP5D limits plaque formation and glial reactivity in the PSAPP mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of microglial INPP5D in Alzheimer's disease using the PSAPP mouse model. It demonstrates that conditional INPP5D knockdown in microglia increases plaque burden and glial reactivity. Spatial transcriptomics revealed a plaque-specific gene expression profile altered by INPP5D knockdown, highlighting CST7 as a novel plaque marker.

title: Targeting CCL5 signaling attenuates neuroinflammation after seizure.
main_goals: This study investigated transcriptional changes in seizure mouse models using spatial transcriptomics to identify targets for neuroinflammation. They found that CCL5/CCR5 signaling plays a role and that blocking it with maraviroc attenuated neuroinflammation and neuron degeneration.

title: Delineating the dynamic evolution from preneoplasia to invasive lung adenocarcinoma by integrating single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) progression from adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) to minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (MIA) and invasive adenocarcinoma (IAC)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study aims to elucidate the cell ecology and spatial niche implicated in the dynamic process of lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) progression using integrated single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and spatial transcriptomics (ST). It identifies key cancer cell subpopulations and tumor microenvironment (TME) cell types involved in invasion and characterizes their spatial distributions and interactions. The findings highlight the role of UBE2C+ cancer cells and specific TME cells, as well as TGF-β signaling, in LUAD invasion.

title: Protein Alterations in Cardiac Ischemia/Reperfusion Revealed by Spatial-Omics.
main_goals: To identify the protein signature of cardiac ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury in rats by combining protein MALDI-MSI and label-free proteomics on the same tissue section. The study aimed to demonstrate that a single tissue section can be used for protein-based spatial-omics and to offer a new methodology to investigate the mechanisms of cardiac I/R injury.

title: Mapping single-cell transcriptomes in the intra-tumoral and associated territories of kidney cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study mapped over 270,000 single-cell transcriptomes and 100 microdissected whole exomes from kidney tumors and associated territories. It investigated the spatial heterogeneity of CD8+ T cell clonotypes and inferred stromal cell clonality. The research identified conserved meta-programs distinguishing tumor cell function and a potential therapeutic target at the tumor-normal interface.

title: Molecular and subregion mechanisms of episodic memory phenotypes in temporal lobe epilepsy.
biological_context: Temporal lobe epilepsy with hippocampal sclerosis
main_goals: This study investigates the molecular and subregion mechanisms underlying episodic memory dysfunction in temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) patients with hippocampal sclerosis. Using spatial quantitation, it compares protein and transcript expression in key memory-related brain regions between TLE patients with and without memory impairment. The findings aim to elucidate region-specific molecular signatures associated with memory deficits in TLE, independent of cell loss.

title: Spatial metabolomics on liver cirrhosis to hepatocellular carcinoma progression.
biological_context: Liver cirrhosis to hepatocellular carcinoma progression
main_goals: This study utilizes mass spectrometry-mediated spatial metabolomics to examine hundreds of metabolites in an untargeted fashion across different subregions of HCC tissue. The goal is to identify altered metabolic pathways, particularly amino acid and glycerophospholipid metabolism, and their connection through the urea cycle, to gain knowledge on HCC metabolic reprogramming and identify potential biomarkers for early detection.

title: Plaque contact and unimpaired Trem2 is required for the microglial response to amyloid pathology.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of plaque contact and functional TREM2 in microglial response to amyloid pathology. Using spatial transcriptomics in aged Alzheimer's mouse models, it identifies plaque-induced gene expression in microglia and shows that this response is dependent on both direct plaque contact and unimpaired TREM2 function.

title: Defining the spatial-molecular map of fibrotic tendon healing and the drivers of Scleraxis-lineage cell fate and function.
main_goals: This study aimed to define the spatial-molecular map of fibrotic tendon healing and identify the drivers of Scleraxis-lineage cell fate and function. By combining lineage tracing with spatial transcriptomics, the researchers identified distinct tissue areas and fibroblast trajectories, along with key transcription factors regulating cell fate decisions during tendon healing.

title: Molecular and spatial heterogeneity of microglia in Rasmussen encephalitis.
main_goals: This study used single-nucleus RNA-sequencing and spatial proteomic analysis to assess gene expression and identify distinct microglial populations in brain tissue from children with Rasmussen encephalitis. The findings highlight increased expression of immune regulatory and T-cell activation markers in RE microglia and their spatial proximity to lymphocytes, elucidating the complex immune microenvironment of the disease.

title: Effect of the intratumoral microbiota on spatial and cellular heterogeneity in cancer.
biological_context: Oral squamous cell carcinoma and colorectal cancer
data_modalities_used: ['Visium spatial transcriptomics', 'GeoMx digital spatial profiling', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Sequence Analysis, RNA', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This study investigates the effect of intratumoral microbiota on spatial and cellular heterogeneity in cancer. By applying in situ spatial-profiling technologies and single-cell RNA sequencing to oral squamous cell carcinoma and colorectal cancer, the authors reveal spatial, cellular, and molecular host-microbe interactions. They developed a new method, INVADEseq, to identify cell-associated bacteria and their host cell interactions, uncovering pathways involved in inflammation, metastasis, cell dormancy, and DNA repair.

title: Tissue-resident memory T cells: The key frontier in local synovitis memory of rheumatoid arthritis.
main_goals: This paper discusses the role of tissue-resident memory T cells (T_RM) in the local recurrence of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It highlights the potential of integrating single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to identify therapeutic targets for suppressing local arthritis flares and preventing extra-articular organ involvement.

title: The neurons that restore walking after paralysis.
biological_context: Spinal cord injury and recovery of walking after paralysis
main_goals: This paper identifies a specific subpopulation of excitatory interneurons in the lumbar spinal cord that are essential for regaining walking after paralysis through epidural electrical stimulation (EES) combined with neurorehabilitation. The study uses snRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics in mice to map the molecular atlas of recovery, revealing these crucial neurons. Augmenting their activity restored walking, while ablating them prevented recovery, thus identifying them as a recovery-organizing neuronal subpopulation.

title: Reduced mitochondria provide an essential function for the cytosolic methionine cycle.
biological_context: Oxymonad protists, specifically Paratrimastix pyriformis, and their mitochondria-related organelles (MROs)
data_modalities_used: ['proteome', 'localization of organelle proteins by isotope tagging (LOPIT)']
main_goals: This paper reveals a novel function of mitochondria-related organelles (MROs) in the oxymonad Paratrimastix pyriformis. By solving its MRO proteome using LOPIT, the study identified enzymes of the glycine cleavage system that produce folate derivatives for the cytosolic methionine cycle. This finding provides insight into the metabolic adaptations of organisms with reduced mitochondria.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of the lacrimal gland features macrophage activity and epithelium metabolism as key alterations during chronic inflammation.
biological_context: Lacrimal gland inflammation in a mouse model of Sjögren's syndrome
main_goals: This study analyzes chronic inflammation in the lacrimal gland of a mouse model of Sjögren's syndrome using bulk RNAseq and Visium spatial gene expression. The research aims to identify key alterations in macrophage activity and epithelium metabolism, and validate specific pathways. The findings suggest that modulating identified pathways could offer a therapeutic strategy for aqueous-deficiency dry eye disease.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal the fibrosis-related immune landscape of biliary atresia.
main_goals: This study investigated the relationship between inflammation and fibrosis in biliary atresia (BA) using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identified fibrosis-related immune cell subpopulations within the fibrotic niche of BA liver and highlighted key pathways and molecules involved. The findings aim to explain the rapid progression of liver fibrosis in BA compared to other liver diseases.

title: A single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomic atlas of the COVID-19 liver reveals topological, functional, and regenerative organ disruption in patients.
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the molecular underpinnings of liver dysfunction in COVID-19 by performing single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomic profiling. The researchers identified SARS-CoV-2 RNA in hepatocytes and characterized extensive changes in cellular composition and gene expression, revealing hepatocellular injury, ductular reaction, vascular expansion, and fibrogenesis. The atlas provides insights into liver physiology and pathology in COVID-19.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptome analysis reveals critical roles for mechano-sensing genes at the border zone in remodeling after myocardial infarction.
biological_context: Myocardial infarction (MI) and left ventricular remodeling
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study performed an integrative analysis of spatial transcriptomics and snRNA-seq in a murine MI model to investigate the mechanisms of ventricular remodeling. It identified mechano-sensing genes at the border zone playing a critical role in this process. The study highlights mechano-sensing genes as adaptive regulators of left ventricular remodeling.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics of the infarcted heart define the dynamic onset of the border zone in response to mechanical destabilization.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'snRNA-seq', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplexed RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization']
main_goals: This paper uses single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to redefine the border zone (BZ) of the infarcted heart based on cardiomyocyte transcriptomes. It identifies two distinct BZ layers (BZ1 and BZ2) and proposes a 'loss of neighbor' hypothesis for the transcriptional response induced by mechanical destabilization.

title: Identification of new components of the basal pole of Toxoplasma gondii provides novel insights into its molecular organization and functions.
main_goals: This study used spatial proteomics and ultrastructure expansion microscopy to identify new components of the basal complex of Toxoplasma gondii. It aimed to position these components within the basal complex and investigate their functional roles in parasite motility, cell division, and cell-cell communication.

title: Prostaglandin E<sub>2</sub> synchronizes lunar-regulated beach spawning in grass puffers.
data_modalities_used: ['RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplex fluorescent in situ hybridization']
main_goals: This study investigates the mechanisms behind lunar-synchronized beach spawning in grass puffers. It identifies semilunar genes, including those related to reproduction and prostaglandin E (PGE) receptors, and demonstrates PGE2's role in triggering spawning behavior. The research also pinpoints CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein δ (cebpd) as a key transcription factor regulating lunar-synchronized gene expression.

title: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome type 1 causes impaired anti-microbial immunity and inflammation due to dysregulated immunometabolism.
biological_context: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome type 1, Crohn's disease-like inflammation, lung fibrosis, granulomatous colitis
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the cellular basis of inflammation in Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome type 1 (HPS-1) by investigating peripheral blood cells and serum. It revealed an inflammatory monocyte phenotype, dysregulated cytokine signaling, and macrophage lipid accumulation in HPS-1 patients. The research identified Rab32-dependent amplified mTOR signaling as a key mechanism contributing to impaired anti-microbial immunity and inflammation in HPS-1.

title: A Novel Transcriptome Approach to the Investigation of the Molecular Pathology of Vitreous and Retinal Detachment.
main_goals: This paper investigates the molecular pathology of vitreous and retinal detachment using a novel transcriptome approach. It focuses on the role of laminocytes in pathological posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) and discusses the potential of spatial transcriptomics to overcome limitations of bulk RNA-Seq for future therapeutic target development.

title: Subcellular spatial transcriptomics identifies three mechanistically different classes of localizing RNAs.
