main_goals: This study uses subcellular spatial transcriptomics to identify RNAs localized in the apical and basal domains of the Drosophila follicular epithelium. It analyzes the mechanisms mediating their localization, identifying at least three distinct mechanisms involving dynein/BicD/Egl machinery, kinesin-1, and a non-canonical translation- and dynein-dependent mechanism.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis of a Diverse Patient Cohort Reveals a Conserved Architecture in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer.
main_goals: The study employed spatial transcriptomics to analyze a diverse TNBC patient cohort, revealing a conserved spatio-transcriptional architecture. It identified race-associated differences in tumor microenvironment features and provided insights into TNBC disparities.

title: Spatial metabolomics reveals upregulation of several pyrophosphate-producing pathways in cortical bone of Hyp mice.
biological_context: Cortical bone of Hyp mice, a model for X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH)
data_modalities_used: ['spatial metabolomics', 'MALDI-Fourier-transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry imaging (MSI)', 'undecalcified bone cryosections']
main_goals: To characterize in situ metabolic changes in bones of Hyp mice using spatial metabolomics to understand the mechanism by which PHEX deficiency regulates bone cell metabolism and impairs bone mineralization. The study identified upregulation of pyrophosphate-producing pathways.

title: Multiomic analysis reveals conservation of cancer-associated fibroblast phenotypes across species and tissue of origin.
biological_context: Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in the tumor microenvironment across multiple tissue types and species.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper investigates the heterogeneity of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) using a multiomics approach. It identifies three conserved CAF superclusters (SSL, MR, IM) across species and tissue types, and examines how manipulating mechanical forces or immune checkpoints affects CAF subpopulations and tumor growth. The findings suggest that CAF supercluster balance has translational implications and identifies species- and tumor-agnostic therapeutic targets.

title: Spatial transcriptome profiling of normal human liver.
main_goals: This study conducted spatial transcriptomics on normal human liver tissue sections to provide detailed information of liver zonation at the transcriptional level. It presents high-quality data from two human donors, classifying hepatocytes into four sub-groups. The data serves as a reliable reference for studies on spatial heterogeneity of liver lobules.

title: High-resolution single-cell analysis paves the cellular path for brain regeneration in salamanders.
main_goals: To understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms of salamander brain regeneration using high-resolution single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. These studies shed light on cell differentiation paths in the salamander telencephalon and contribute to understanding vertebrate brain evolution, development, and regeneration.

title: Small cell carcinoma of the ovary hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT): A review and novel case with dual germline SMARCA4 and BRCA2 mutations.
biological_context: Small cell carcinoma of the ovary hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT)
main_goals: This paper presents a case of Small cell carcinoma of the ovary hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT) in a patient with dual germline SMARCA4 and BRCA2 mutations. It describes the patient's disease presentation, histopathology, and treatment. The study also shares spatial transcriptomics data obtained from the tumor.

title: The human myocardium harbors a population of naive B-cells with a distinctive gene expression signature conserved across species.
main_goals: To characterize the presence and biological function of B-cells in the human heart and compare them to findings in murine models. The study aimed to determine if human myocardial B-cells are similar to their counterparts in rodents, particularly regarding their naive state and gene expression signature.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis Reveals Associations between Genes and Cellular Topology in Breast and Prostate Cancers.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study aimed to identify topology-associated genes (TAGs) that correlate with image topological features (ITFs) in breast and prostate cancer spatial transcriptomic samples. The research investigated themes among these correlated genes through functional enrichment analysis and explored their potential utility in diagnostic and prognostic models.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Analysis Reveals that CCL17 and CCL22 are Robust Indicators of a Suppressive Immune Environment in Angioimmunoblastic T Cell Lymphoma (AITL).
main_goals: This study applied spatial transcriptomics to analyze the tumor immune microenvironment of Angioimmunoblastic T cell Lymphoma (AITL). It revealed that AITL exhibits a suppressive immune environment characterized by up-regulated CCL17 and CCL22, decreased NK and CD8+ CTL markers, and colocalization of Treg cells with CD4+ TFH-GC regions. The findings suggest anti-CCR4 therapy as a potential treatment strategy.

title: Upper cortical layer-driven network impairment in schizophrenia.
main_goals: This paper investigates the impact of schizophrenia on the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and immunohistochemistry. It reveals a reduction in GABAergic neurons and an increase in principal neurons, particularly in upper cortical layers, with associated transcriptomic changes. The findings suggest a general network impairment within upper cortical layers as a core substrate of schizophrenia.

title: Single-cell transcriptomics shows dose-dependent disruption of hepatic zonation by TCDD in mice.
biological_context: TCDD-induced hepatic pathologies in mice, specifically fat accumulation, inflammation, and fibrosis, and their relationship with liver zonation disruption.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate cell-specific and spatially resolved dose-dependent changes in gene expression induced by TCDD in mice livers. It utilized single-nuclei RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to show dose-dependent disruption of hepatic zonation, with macrophages infiltrating hepatocyte regions and altered gene expression, suggesting a link to NAFLD pathologies.

title: Angiotensin-converting Enzyme-2 (ACE2) Expression in Pediatric Liver Disease.
main_goals: This study aimed to assess Angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE2) expression in pediatric liver disease using novel methods. It investigated ACE2 localization and quantified its expression in liver tissue and plasma, correlating it with disease status. The study also utilized machine learning for histological analysis and spatial transcriptomics to identify cell composition.

title: Spatial transcriptomics shows moxibustion promotes hippocampus astrocyte and neuron interaction.
main_goals: This study investigates whether moxibustion can alleviate cognitive impairment in Alzheimer's disease (AD) models by promoting astrocyte-neuron interaction and enhancing synaptic plasticity. The research uses spatial transcriptomics to evaluate transcriptome characteristics and astrocyte-neuron interactions in APP/PS1 mice treated with moxibustion. The findings suggest that moxibustion improves learning and memory, synaptic structure, and the interaction between astrocytes and neurons.

title: Single-cell spatial transcriptomics reveals a dynamic control of metabolic zonation and liver regeneration by endothelial cell Wnt2 and Wnt9b.
main_goals: This study identifies an unequivocal role of endothelial cell Wnt2 and Wnt9b in regulating liver zonation and regeneration. It demonstrates how these Wnts control beta-catenin targets in zone 3 and influence gene expression. The research also highlights the potential of Wnt signaling activators as a regenerative therapy for acetaminophen overdose acute liver failure.

title: Spatial transcriptomic analysis delineates epithelial and mesenchymal subpopulations and transition stages in childhood ependymoma.
biological_context: childhood ependymoma posterior fossa subgroup A (PFA)
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'immunohistochemistry', 'bulk transcriptomic data', 'in vitro functional assays']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze the tumor microenvironment of childhood ependymoma posterior fossa subgroup A (PFA). It delineates epithelial and mesenchymal subpopulations and identifies transition stages, revealing that myeloid cell interaction is a leading cause of mesenchymal transition, distinct from hypoxia-induced transition. The findings advance understanding of PFA biology, cellular interactions, and their influence on tumor progression.

title: Spatial transcriptomic profiling of coronary endothelial cells in SARS-CoV-2 myocarditis.
main_goals: To examine coronary endothelial and myocardial programming in patients with severe COVID-19 utilizing digital spatial transcriptomics. The study investigated the differential expression patterns in myocardial and coronary vascular tissue of control and COVID-19 patients. It aimed to understand the paracrine effect of SARS-CoV-2 infection in cardiac tissue and its role in cardiovascular events.

title: Spatial transcriptomics tools allow for regional exploration of heterogeneous muscle pathology in the pre-clinical rabbit model of rotator cuff tear.
biological_context: Rotator cuff tear in a rabbit model
main_goals: To evaluate the potential and challenges of spatial transcriptomics technology to add dimensionality to transcriptional data in an attempt to better understand regional cellular activity in heterogeneous skeletal muscle tissue. The protocol was applied to a rabbit model of rotator cuff tear and its utility for retrospective studies was assessed. The findings demonstrate the protocol's ability to explore spatial transcriptional patterns and relate them to histology, even for long-stored tissues.

title: Muscle injury induces a transient senescence-like state that is required for myofiber growth during muscle regeneration.
biological_context: Muscle regeneration following injury and in a model of Muscular Dystrophy (D2-mdx mice).
main_goals: The study demonstrates that muscle injury induces a transient senescence-like state in multiple cell types within regenerating skeletal muscle. This senescent state is shown to be required for myofiber growth and myonuclear accretion during muscle regeneration, as blocking senescent cells with ABT-263 impairs these processes.

title: Single cell and spatial transcriptomic analyses reveal microglia-plasma cell crosstalk in the brain during Trypanosoma brucei infection.
main_goals: To understand the transcriptional and functional responses of the brain to chronic T. brucei infection by integrating single cell and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies microglia-plasma cell crosstalk mediated by IL-10 and BAFF signalling.

title: Proper acquisition of cell class identity in organoids allows definition of fate specification programs of the human cerebral cortex.
biological_context: Human cerebral cortex development using organoids
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper presents a comprehensive multiomic atlas of human cortical organoid development from progenitor to differentiated cell types. It aims to validate organoids as a model for human corticogenesis by correlating cellular diversification with endogenous processes and to define molecular trajectories and identify genes with potential human-specific roles.

title: Case report: Understanding the impact of persistent tissue-localization of SARS-CoV-2 on immune response activity via spatial transcriptomic analysis of two cancer patients with COVID-19 co-morbidity.
biological_context: Hepatocellular carcinoma and colorectal cancer patients with COVID-19 co-morbidity
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This case report examines post-COVID-19 tissue-localized immune responses in cancer patients. Using spatial transcriptomic analysis, it demonstrates a lymphocyte-associated SARS-CoV-2 response and identifies patient-specific memory B cells as key contributors. The study also evaluates the spatial associations between SARS-CoV-2 immunological effects and anti-tumor immune responses, suggesting potential modulation of the tumor microenvironment by persistent viral immunity.

title: Neurons burdened by DNA double-strand breaks incite microglia activation through antiviral-like signaling in neurodegeneration.
data_modalities_used: ['single-nucleus transcriptomics', 'bulk transcriptomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'organotypic mouse brain slice culture']
main_goals: This study characterizes DNA double-strand break (DSB)-bearing neurons in a mouse model of neurodegeneration using transcriptomic techniques. It reveals that DSB-bearing neurons activate senescent and antiviral immune pathways, leading to microglia activation through NF-kappaB signaling. The findings highlight a novel role for neurons in disease-associated neuroinflammation.

title: Integrating microarray-based spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing reveals tissue architecture in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
biological_context: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) tumor microenvironment (TME)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to integrate single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and microarray-based spatial transcriptomics (ST) to reveal the tissue architecture of the tumor microenvironment in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. By using multimodal intersection analysis (MIA), the researchers annotated cellular components within tumor and stromal regions, mapped the spatial distribution of identified cell subsets, and identified differences in TME features between metastatic and non-metastatic samples. The findings provide insights into the spatial landscape of the TME and potential cross-talk among diverse cells for cancer intervention.

title: Intratumor heterogeneity and T cell exhaustion in primary CNS lymphoma.
data_modalities_used: ['flow cytometry', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'B cell receptor sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'histopathology']
main_goals: This study aimed to characterize the intratumor heterogeneity and T cell exhaustion in primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL) using advanced single-cell and spatial omics techniques. The findings highlight the transcriptional and spatial heterogeneity of malignant B cells and the prevalence of T cell exhaustion in the tumor microenvironment, suggesting potential for personalized treatments.

title: Microenvironment components and spatially resolved single-cell transcriptome atlas of breast cancer metastatic axillary lymph nodes.
biological_context: breast cancer metastatic axillary lymph nodes
main_goals: This study investigates the transcriptional profiling and spatial organization of breast cancer metastatic axillary lymph nodes. It identifies osteoclast-like giant cells (OGC) and characterizes tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) within the lymph node microenvironment. The research aims to understand the impact of breast cancer cells on the lymph node microenvironment using integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.

title: A cellular hierarchy in melanoma uncouples growth and metastasis.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'mouse genetics', 'lineage tracing', 'quantitative modelling', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Clustering', 'Cell Tracking']
main_goals: This paper investigates the cellular hierarchy in melanoma and provides evidence for a hierarchical model of tumor growth mirroring embryonic neural crest development. It identifies a perivascular niche associated with tumorigenic competence and demonstrates that distinct melanoma subpopulations fuel primary tumor growth versus metastatic dissemination.

title: An in situ analysis pipeline for initial host-pathogen interactions reveals signatures of human colorectal HIV transmission.
biological_context: Human colorectal mucosa and HIV transmission
main_goals: To create a comparative map of early mucosal transmission events of HIV in intact human colorectal explants. The study used a combination of RNAscope, cyclic immunofluorescence, and image analysis to quantify HIV transmission signatures within 2 hours of topical exposure. The findings reveal that HIV enriches to mucosal dendritic cells and submucosal macrophages, and these cells facilitate HIV transfer to CD4+ T cells, maximizing the likelihood of mucosal infection.

title: CD8+ and FoxP3+ T-Cell Cellular Density and Spatial Distribution After Programmed Death-Ligand 1 Check Point Inhibition.
biological_context: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC)
main_goals: To analyze CD8+ and FoxP3+ T-cell cellular density and intercellular distances in HNSCC samples from a neoadjuvant trial of durvalumab +/- metformin. The study investigated how these immune cell characteristics vary with treatment, HPV status, and pathologic response, and explored associations with T-cell signatures identified via digital spatial genomic profiling.

title: Transcriptomic changes in autophagy-related genes are inversely correlated with inflammation and are associated with multiple sclerosis lesion pathology.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'post-mortem human MS brain tissues', 'experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) mouse model']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of autophagy in multiple sclerosis (MS) by examining transcriptomic changes in autophagy-related genes. It demonstrates that decreased expression of ATG genes is associated with MS lesions and inversely correlated with inflammation, suggesting a negative regulation of autophagy possibly mediated by mTORC1 activation.

title: Transcriptional and Immune Landscape of Cardiac Sarcoidosis.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'GeoMx digital spatial profiler', 'single-nucleus RNA sequencing', 'immunofluorescence staining', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the cellular and transcriptional landscape of cardiac sarcoidosis using spatial transcriptomics and single-nucleus RNA sequencing. It compared the transcriptomic profiles of cardiac sarcoidosis with other inflammatory heart diseases, identified novel markers for giant cells (GPNMB), and described the spatial distribution of different immune cell populations within cardiac granulomas.

title: Spatial Proteomics for Further Exploration of Missing Proteins: A Case Study of the Ovary.
main_goals: To identify and explore "missing proteins" (MPs) in human ovaries using an integrated omics approach. The study aimed to validate the existence of these proteins at the single-cell type level and map their spatial localization within ovarian tissues.

title: Transcriptomic profiling of cardiac tissues from SARS-CoV-2 patients identifies DNA damage.
main_goals: This study investigated the host transcriptome landscape of cardiac tissues from SARS-CoV-2 and pH1N1 patients using targeted spatial transcriptomics. The aim was to identify molecular changes associated with cardiovascular complications in COVID-19, comparing them with pH1N1 influenza. The findings revealed distinct transcriptomic profiles, highlighting DNA damage and M1-like macrophage infiltration in COVID-19 cardiac tissues.

title: Resident macrophage subpopulations occupy distinct microenvironments in the kidney.
biological_context: Kidney homeostasis and response to acute kidney injury
main_goals: This paper aimed to investigate whether kidney-resident macrophages (KRMs) are a heterogeneous population differentiated by function and location. The study combined multiple techniques to characterize distinct KRM subpopulations and their spatial organization in the kidney, and how this organization changes following acute kidney injury.

title: Zebrafish Danio rerio myotomal muscle structure and growth from a spatial transcriptomics perspective.
biological_context: Zebrafish myotomal muscle structure and growth
main_goals: To examine zebrafish myotomal muscle structure and growth using a spatial transcriptomics approach. The study aimed to spatially map different muscle fiber types and identify regions of active myogenesis and hyperplasia. This research is the first to apply spatial transcriptomics to fish myotomal muscle.

title: Spatial molecular anatomy of germ layers in the gastrulating cynomolgus monkey embryo.
main_goals: The paper presents a spatial and temporal survey of the molecular dynamics of cell types in non-human primate embryos during gastrulation using spatial transcriptomics. It reconstructs three-dimensional digital models from serial sections of cynomolgus monkey gastrulating embryos. The study identifies gene expression profiles unique to the germ layers and reveals conserved and divergent processes during mammalian gastrulation through cross-species comparison.

title: Lung epithelial and myeloid innate immunity in influenza-associated or COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis: an observational study.
biological_context: Influenza-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (IAPA) and COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA)
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'RNAscope', 'bronchoalveolar lavage samples', 'tracheobronchial biopsy samples', 'nCounter gene expression analysis', 'protein analysis']
main_goals: The study aimed to explore the role of lung epithelial and myeloid innate immunity in patients with IAPA or CAPA. Using spatial transcriptomics and other methods, researchers observed a downregulation of genes associated with antifungal effector functions and IFNγ signaling in patients with IAPA and CAPA. They visualized SARS-CoV-2 infection disrupting the epithelial barrier in one CAPA patient.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomic profiling of ovarian aging in mice.
main_goals: This study aims to spatially resolve the transcriptomic landscape of ovaries from young and aged outbred mice to understand the mechanisms underlying age-related fertility decline. The study identifies cell populations and transcriptomic changes associated with ovarian aging. The findings provide insights into the localization and cell-population-specific mechanisms of ovarian aging.

title: Spatially restricted drivers and transitional cell populations cooperate with the microenvironment in untreated and chemo-resistant pancreatic cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to provide a deeper understanding of the intricate substructure of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma tumors using spatial omics data to potentially improve therapy for patients with this disease. It utilizes single-cell/nucleus RNA sequencing, bulk-proteogenomics, spatial transcriptomics and cellular imaging to characterize tumor cell subpopulations and their interactions with the microenvironment in both untreated and chemo-resistant samples.

title: Single-Nucleus RNA Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics Reveal the Immunological Microenvironment of Cervical Squamous Cell Carcinoma.
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to investigate the immunological microenvironment of cervical squamous cell carcinoma (CSCC) using single-nucleus RNA sequencing (snRNA-seq) and SpaTial enhanced resolution omics-sequencing (Stereo-seq). The study identifies a cluster of pro-tumorigenic cancer-associated myofibroblasts (myCAFs) associated with poorer survival and potential immunotherapy resistance. Immunohistochemistry and multiplex immunofluorescence staining are used to validate the spatial distribution and potential function of myCAFs.

title: Integrated multi-omics reveals cellular and molecular interactions governing the invasive niche of basal cell carcinoma.
main_goals: The study aims to define the cellular contributors of tumor progression in basal cell carcinoma using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies the cell populations and their transcriptional reprogramming contributing to the spatial organization of the basal cell carcinoma invasive niche. The study also demonstrates the power of integrated spatial and single-cell multi-omics to decipher cancer-specific invasive properties and develop targeted therapies.

title: Spatial Gene Expression Changes in the Mouse Heart After Base-Targeted Irradiation.
main_goals: Characterize late changes in gene expression using spatial transcriptomics in a mouse model of base regional radiosensitivity after irradiation to the heart base. Identify spatially resolved gene expression changes in irradiated tissues. Understand the cardiac base's radiosensitivity.

title: Spatially resolved deconvolution of the fibrotic niche in lung fibrosis.
main_goals: The study investigates spatial gene expression in lung fibrosis using digital profiling technology to identify region-specific gene expression signatures. It spatially maps cellular composition within and distant from the fibrotic niche and investigates cellular cross-talk. The study also identifies that loss of NFKB inhibitor zeta in alveolar epithelial cells dysregulates the TGFβ/IL-6 signaling axis.

title: Checkpoint Blockade-Induced Dermatitis and Colitis Are Dominated by Tissue-Resident Memory T Cells and Th1/Tc1 Cytokines.
biological_context: Immune checkpoint blockade-induced dermatitis and colitis
main_goals: The study aims to understand the immunologic mechanisms of irAEs by analyzing tissues from patients with irAE dermatitis and colitis using multiparameter immunofluorescence (IF), spatial transcriptomics, and RNA in situ hybridization (RISH). The goal is to identify potential treatment targets.

title: Phosphoproteomics of primary AML patient samples reveals rationale for AKT combination therapy and p53 context to overcome selinexor resistance.
main_goals: To identify the molecular context for monotherapy sensitivity as well as rational drug combinations for AML using phosphoproteomics. They profile selinexor signaling responses using phosphoproteomics in primary AML patient samples and cell lines, then combine selinexor with the AKT inhibitor MK-2206 to overcome dysregulated AKT-FOXO3 signaling in resistant cells, resulting in synergistic anti-proliferative effects. High-throughput spatial proteomics is used to profile subcellular compartments and measure global proteome and phospho-proteome dynamics.

title: Spatial Proteomics Reveals Differences in the Cellular Architecture of Antibody-Producing CHO and Plasma Cell-Derived Cells.
biological_context: CHO cells producing recombinant antibody and plasma cell-derived myeloma cell line
main_goals: The study aims to compare the subcellular spatial proteomes of a CHO-K1 cell line producing high titers of recombinant antibody and an antibody-producing plasma cell-derived myeloma cell line. The authors report differences in the localization of proteins associated with vesicle-mediated transport, transcription, and translation, which may affect antibody production in both cell lines. The study highlights the potential of subcellular spatial proteomics combined with protein expression as a potent workflow to identify characteristics of highly efficient recombinant protein-expressing cell lines.

title: Spatiotemporal dynamics of macrophage heterogeneity and a potential function of Trem2<sup>hi</sup> macrophages in infarcted hearts.
main_goals: Investigate the spatiotemporal dynamics of MI-associated immune cells using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing in a mouse model of MI. Identify immune cell populations and their dynamic changes after MI. Determine the role of Trem2 expressing macrophages in infarcted hearts.

title: GREM1/PPP2R3A expression in heterogeneous fibroblasts initiates pulmonary fibrosis.
main_goals: The study aims to identify fibroblast subtypes in a mouse model of silicosis using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies a group of inflammatory-proliferative fibroblasts expressing GREM1/PPP2R3A that play a key role in the early pathological stage of pulmonary fibrosis.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics as a Novel Approach to Redefine Electrical Stimulation Safety.
main_goals: This study investigates the biological response to electrical stimulation in the rat visual cortex using spatial transcriptomics. The goal is to assess the spatial patterns of gene expression related to cellular processes like inflammation, cell cycle progression, and neuronal plasticity following electrical stimulation using different electrode types and stimulation parameters. The data is analyzed to generate new hypotheses and inform safety standards for stimulation in the cortex.

title: Quantification of spatial pharmacogene expression heterogeneity in breast tumors.
main_goals: This study analyzed the spatial expression of pharmacogenes in breast cancer tissues using Visium spatial transcriptomics. The goals were to determine if these pharmacogenes are expressed heterogeneously across tumor tissue and to determine which pharmacogenes have the most spatial expression heterogeneity.

title: Identification of Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress-Related Subtypes, Infiltration Analysis of Tumor Microenvironment, and Construction of a Prognostic Model in Colorectal Cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Prognostic model']
main_goals: The study aims to analyze the role of ER stress-related gene patterns in colorectal cancer (CRC) development and their influence on the tumor microenvironment (TME). It identifies ER stress-related patterns, evaluates cell-infiltrating patterns, and constructs a prognostic model to predict patient survival. The study also uses spatial transcriptomics data to explore ER stress-related gene patterns in CRC tissues and their association with the immunosuppressive TME.

title: Spatial Profiling of Protein and RNA Expression in Tissue: An Approach to Fine-tune Virtual Microdissection.
main_goals: The study demonstrates that automated custom antibody visualization protocols can be utilized to guide ROI selection in conjunction with spatial proteomics assays. It also tests the ability of selecting small ROIs using the spatial transcriptomics assay to allow the investigation of highly-specific areas of interest.

title: Spatially Resolved Transcriptomes of Mammalian Kidneys Illustrate the Molecular Complexity and Interactions of Functional Nephron Segments.
main_goals: The study applies spatial transcriptomics sequencing (ST-seq) to normal human and murine kidneys to spatially resolve gene expression signatures of distinct nephron structures and microvascular regions. It aims to confirm current knowledge of transcript localization within the kidney and provide a valuable resource for future kidney research. The study also investigates cellular communication within glomeruli and regions of proximal tubules-peritubular capillaries.

title: The UIP/IPF fibroblastic focus is a collagen biosynthesis factory embedded in a distinct extracellular matrix.
main_goals: The study aims to identify distinct protein compositions in histologically defined regions of UIP/IPF tissue using spatial proteomics. The primary finding is that fibroblastic foci are the main site of collagen biosynthesis and that the adjacent alveoli are abnormal. This information is intended to inform future mechanistic studies on fibrosis progression.

title: Multidimensional Immunophenotyping of Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms Reveals Novel T Cell and Macrophage Signature.
main_goals: The study aims to comprehensively profile immune cell infiltration in IPMN using spatial transcriptomics and flow cytometry to understand how these lesions progress to pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The study found that T cells are the dominant immune cell, and regions of high-grade dysplasia (HGD) are relatively deplete of T cells and enriched with macrophages compared to low-grade dysplasia (LGD).

title: Integrated single cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal autoreactive differentiated B cells in joints of early rheumatoid arthritis.
main_goals: This study investigates the presence and characteristics of differentiated B cells in joint tissue of early Rheumatoid Arthritis patients using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It aims to understand the local B cell composition and maturation process in the joints at the onset of the disease. The study identifies autoreactive plasma cells and suggests that plasma cell niches are present from the time of diagnosis.

title: Objective assessment of tumor infiltrating lymphocytes as a prognostic marker in melanoma using machine learning algorithms.
main_goals: The study evaluated the prognostic value of objective automated electronic TILs (eTILs) quantification to define a subset of melanoma patients with a low risk of relapse after surgical treatment. They analyzed data for 785 patients and found that eTIL% and etTILs scores are robust prognostic markers. They also showed the molecular correlates behind these scores.

title: Spatial proteomics with subcellular resolution.
main_goals: The paper focuses on spatial proteomics with subcellular resolution.

title: Dissecting the treatment-naive ecosystem of human melanoma brain metastasis.
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to perform single-cell/nucleus RNA-seq in treatment-naive MBMs and ECMs, and matched spatial single-cell transcriptomics and T cell receptor (TCR)-seq to gain insights into MBM biology. It also aims to validate key observations in independent patient cohorts, patient-derived MBM/ECM xenograft models, RNA/ATAC-seq, proteomics, and multiplexed imaging.

title: Spatial transcriptomics atlas reveals the crosstalk between cancer-associated fibroblasts and tumor microenvironment components in colorectal cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to explore the crosstalk between cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and the tumor microenvironment (TME) in colorectal cancer using spatial transcriptomics and bulk-RNA sequencing. It identifies two distinct types of CAFs and investigates their functional significance in TME to understand their cancer-promoting functions and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Single-cell roadmap of human gonadal development.
main_goals: The study generated a comprehensive map of first- and second-trimester human gonads using multi-omics approaches. It identified human-specific regulatory programs controlling germline and somatic cell lineage development and defined somatic cell states at the time of sex specification. Furthermore, it identified specific fetal testicular macrophages and their signaling roles.

title: Biological Misinterpretation of Transcriptional Signatures in Tumor Samples Can Unknowingly Undermine Mechanistic Understanding and Faithful Alignment with Preclinical Data.
biological_context: Colorectal, breast, pancreatic, ovarian and prostate cancer
data_modalities_used: ['laser capture microdissection', 'flow cytometry', 'bulk biopsy clinical samples', 'multiregional biopsy clinical samples', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This paper investigates the influence of stromal content on gene expression signatures (GESs) in tumor tissue and demonstrates the potential for misinterpretation of GESs due to widespread stromal influences. The study uses colorectal cancer as an exemplar and utilizes multiple profiling methodologies to assess the impact of stromal content on widely used GESs. A freely available resource, ConfoundR, is also generated to enable users to test the extent of stromal influence on gene signatures across multiple cancer datasets.

title: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of the Molecular Expression Pattern and Intercellular Interactions in the Glial Scar Response to Spinal Cord Injury.
main_goals: The study constructed tissue-wide gene expression patterns of mouse spinal cords over the course of scar formation using spatial transcriptomics after spinal cord injury. They profiled gene expression gradients from the leading edge to the core of the scar areas and delineated the origins, functional diversity, and possible trajectories of subpopulations of fibroblasts, glia, and immune cells. They also described the extent of the scar boundary and profiled the bidirectional ligand-receptor interactions at the neighboring cluster boundary.

title: Imaging Mass Cytometry Reveals Predominant Innate Immune Signature and Endothelial-Immune Cell Interaction in Juvenile Myositis Compared to Lupus Skin.
biological_context: Juvenile dermatomyositis (DM) and childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus (cSLE) skin
main_goals: The study uses imaging mass cytometry to characterize cutaneous inflammatory cell populations and cell-cell interactions in juvenile dermatomyositis (DM) as compared to childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus (cSLE). It identifies immune cell population differences in DM and cSLE skin, highlighting a predominant innate immune signature and endothelial cell-immune cell interaction in DM.

title: Soluble TREM2 levels reflect the recruitment and expansion of TREM2<sup>+</sup> macrophages that localize to fibrotic areas and limit NASH.
main_goals: The study aims to functionally characterize the role of bone marrow-derived TREM2-expressing macrophage populations in NASH. It identifies that TREM2+ macrophages localize to sites of hepatocellular damage, inflammation and fibrosis in the steatotic liver. The study also highlights the clinical relevance of systemic soluble TREM2 levels in the context of NASH.

title: Spatial Metabolomics Reveals Localized Impact of Influenza Virus Infection on the Lung Tissue Metabolome.
biological_context: Influenza A virus infection in mouse lung tissue
main_goals: The study used spatial metabolomics to understand changes in the lung and serum metabolome of mice infected with influenza A virus compared to uninfected controls. It determined metabolites altered by infection in specific lung tissue sites and distinguished metabolites perturbed by infection between lung tissue and serum samples. The findings highlight the utility of a spatial approach to understanding the intersection between the lung metabolome, viral infection, and disease severity.

title: Lymphatics act as a signaling hub to regulate intestinal stem cell activity.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of lymphatics in regulating intestinal stem cell (ISC) activity. It identifies lymphatics as a central signaling hub in the intestinal crypt, influencing ISC maintenance and differentiation. The study uses spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing to identify specific lymphatic signals (WNT2, R-SPONDIN-3, and REELIN) that govern ISC regenerative potential.

title: Spatial transcriptomics identifies enriched gene expression and cell types in human liver fibrosis.
main_goals: The main goal was to localize cell types in cirrhotic explants of patients with end-stage liver disease using spatial transcriptomics combined with scRNAseq and gene deconvolution analysis. They aimed to identify enriched cell types in fibrotic liver regions compared to parenchymal areas. The study demonstrates the potential of spatial transcriptomics for refining the localization of gene content and cell lineages in the search for antifibrotic targets.

title: Identification of early neurodegenerative pathways in progressive multiple sclerosis.
main_goals: The study aims to identify multicellular mechanisms of progressive MS pathogenesis and trace their origin in relation to spatially distributed stages of neurodegeneration. It identifies defunct trophic and anti-inflammatory intercellular communications within areas of early neuronal decline. The findings aim to provide a new framework for drug development strategies, rooted in an understanding of the complex cellular and signaling dynamics in human diseased tissue.

title: Lipid-associated macrophages in the tumor-adipose microenvironment facilitate breast cancer progression.
main_goals: The study identifies a novel subtype of macrophages called lipid-associated macrophages (LAMs) in the tumor-adipose microenvironment (TAME) of breast cancer. They characterize LAMs using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics, revealing their unique features, functional signatures, and distribution in the TAME. The study also demonstrates that LAMs depletion synergizes the antitumorigenic effects of anti-PD1 therapy.

title: Spatial profiling of early primate gastrulation in utero.
main_goals: The study aims to illuminate early gastrulation of marmoset embryos in utero using spatial transcriptomics and stem-cell-based embryo models. It aims to delineate the emergence of the anterior visceral endoderm and reveal the molecular code of lineage specification in the primate embryo. This provides an in vivo reference to decipher human development.

title: Interleukin-17 governs hypoxic adaptation of injured epithelium.
main_goals: The study investigates the role of IL-17A in activating HIF1α during epithelial injury and hypoxia. It identifies the IL-17A-HIF1α axis as a driver of glycolysis in wound front epithelia, essential for repair. The findings highlight the coupling of inflammatory, metabolic, and migratory programs in epithelial healing.

title: Simultaneous and Spatially-Resolved Analysis of T-Lymphocytes, Macrophages and PD-L1 Immune Checkpoint in Rare Cancers.
main_goals: The study uses multiplexed immunofluorescence and open-source tools to analyze T-lymphocytes, macrophages, and PD-L1 expression in penile, vulvar, and anal cancers. It aims to demonstrate the reliability and robustness of the methodology for detecting cell phenotypes in the tumor microenvironment. The goal is to show that this method can be applied to other solid tumors.

title: Spatial region-resolved proteome map reveals mechanism of COVID-19-associated heart injury.
main_goals: The study aims to establish a region-resolved proteome map of the myocardia and microvessels with obvious inflammatory cells from hearts of patients with COVID-19. It identifies molecular dysfunctions in different cardiac regions, particularly in the left atrial myocardia and microvessels. The findings can guide in improving clinical treatments for cardiovascular diseases associated with COVID-19.

title: A reference tissue atlas for the human kidney.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell/nucleus transcriptomics', 'subsegmental laser microdissection transcriptomics', 'proteomics', 'near-single-cell proteomics', '3D imaging', 'CODEX imaging', 'spatial metabolomics']
main_goals: The Kidney Precision Medicine Project (KPMP) is constructing a spatially specified human kidney tissue atlas in health and disease with single-cell resolution. This paper describes the construction of an integrated reference map of cells, pathways, and genes using unaffected regions of nephrectomy tissues and undiseased human biopsies. The resulting reference atlas provides a framework for the classification of kidney disease.

title: Spatial maps of hepatocellular carcinoma transcriptomes reveal spatial expression patterns in tumor immune microenvironment.
main_goals: The study aims to reveal intratumor heterogeneity of HCC and unexplored spatial expression patterns in the immune microenvironment based on spatial transcriptomics techniques. It highlights the clinical significance and spatial discrepancy of key molecules, providing novel insight for further developing therapeutic strategies in HCC.

title: Cardiac fibroblasts regulate the development of heart failure via Htra3-TGF-β-IGFBP7 axis.
main_goals: This study elucidates that Htra3 is a critical regulator of cardiac fibrosis and heart failure by maintaining the identity of quiescent cardiac fibroblasts through degrading transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β). It also highlights the roles of cardiac fibroblasts in regulating cardiomyocyte homeostasis and cardiac fibrosis through the Htra3-TGF-β-IGFBP7 pathway, which would be a therapeutic target for heart failure.

title: The spatiotemporal program of zonal liver regeneration following acute injury.
biological_context: Mouse liver regeneration after acetaminophen intoxication
main_goals: This study uses spatially resolved single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to study the dynamics of mouse liver regeneration after acute acetaminophen (APAP) intoxication. The study aims to understand the coordinated programs of zonal liver regeneration.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics with single-cell transcriptomics reveals a spatiotemporal gene landscape of the human developing kidney.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Deconvolution', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The study profiled the spatiotemporal gene programs of the human embryonic kidneys by integrating microarray-based spatial transcriptomics and single-cell transcriptomics. It mapped transcriptomic signatures of scRNA-seq cell types upon kidney sections and established gene characteristics in the medullary regions. The research also built a regulatory network for nephrogenic niche development and highlighted the roles of Wnt, FGF, and JAG1-Notch2 signaling.

title: A Cellular Resolution Spatial Transcriptomic Landscape of the Medial Structures in Postnatal Mouse Brain.
main_goals: The study aims to create a cellular resolution spatial transcriptomic landscape of the medial structures in the postnatal mouse brain.

title: Dissecting Tissue Compartment-Specific Protein Signatures in Primary and Metastatic Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinomas.
main_goals: This study uses spatial proteomics to analyze primary and lymph node metastasis from an oropharyngeal SCC cohort to understand the expression of proteins within tumors, and stromal compartments of the respective sites in samples of both matched and unmatched patients. The study highlights the utility of spatial proteomics for delineating the tumor and stromal compartment composition, and utility toward understanding these properties in locoregional metastasis. These findings indicate unique biological properties of lymph node metastases that may elucidate further understanding of distant metastatic in OPSCC.

title: Behind the Wall-Compartment-Specific Neovascularisation during Post-Stroke Recovery in Mice.
main_goals: This study characterizes the spatio-temporal alterations within the ischemic core from the acute to the chronic phase of stroke using MELC for sequential immunohistochemistry. It identifies distinct processes of neovascularization in the ischemic core and peri-infarct area during post-stroke tissue remodeling. The study proposes that neovascularization of the ischemic core comprises arteriogenesis as well as angiogenesis originating from the leptomenigeal vasculature.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of macrophage infiltration in non-small cell lung cancer reveals determinants of sensitivity and resistance to anti-PD1/PD-L1 antibodies.
main_goals: The study investigated the predictive value of TAM infiltration in patients with NSCLC treated with ICBs and characterized their transcriptomic profiles. They aimed to identify determinants of response to ICBs in tumors with high CD163+ infiltration.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals metabolic changes underly age-dependent declines in digit regeneration.
main_goals: The study used spatial transcriptomics to characterize the transcriptional profile within the blastema during digit regeneration in young and aged mice. They identified a metabolic shift in aged blastema associated with increased bioenergetic requirement, hypoxia, and angiogenic signaling, leading to impaired regeneration. They found that oxaloacetate administration can enhance bone regeneration in aged mice.

title: Spatial and temporal heterogeneity in the lineage progression of fine oligodendrocyte subtypes.
biological_context: Mouse brain and spinal cord development
main_goals: The study aims to map the spatial and temporal heterogeneity of oligodendrocyte lineage progression in the brain and spinal cord using in situ sequencing. It investigates the abundance of distinct oligodendrocyte populations and their neighboring preferences at different postnatal stages. The findings reveal regional differences in the timing of oligodendrocyte differentiation and myelination.

title: The normal and fibrotic mouse lung classified by spatial proteomic analysis.
biological_context: Mouse lung, healthy and during a fibrosis model
main_goals: The study classifies normal lung constituents and shows the progress of lung fibrosis over a 4 weeks course using in situ spatial proteomics. It highlights the changing landscape and cell-specific quantitative variation of a multidrug transporter. An early decline in AT2 alveolar cells and a progressive increase in stromal cells is observed as the core of the fibrotic process.

title: Spatial metabolomics for evaluating response to neoadjuvant therapy in non-small cell lung cancer patients.
main_goals: The study evaluates the potential application of spatial metabolomics in cancer tissues to assess the response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). It uses mass spectrometry imaging combined with machine learning to develop a metabolic classifier to predict prognosis. The study finds that the metabolic constitutions of both tumor cells and the stroma are valuable additions to the classical histomorphology-based assessment of tumor response.

title: Integrating single-cell RNA sequencing with spatial transcriptomics reveals immune landscape for interstitial cystitis.
main_goals: The study aims to investigate the role of immunity in interstitial cystitis (IC) bladders by integrating single-cell RNA sequencing with spatial transcriptomics. The goal is to depict the immune landscape for IC and provide insights into the pathophysiology of IC.

title: Distinct phenotypic states and spatial distribution of CD8<sup>+</sup> T cell clonotypes in human brain metastases.
main_goals: The study analyzes human brain metastases to demonstrate their robust infiltration by CD8+ T cell subsets with distinct antigen specificities, phenotypic states, and spatial localization. It identifies signaling pathways within CD8+ T cells and their surrounding environment that may be targeted for immunotherapy of brain metastases.

title: Multidimensional Immune Profiling of Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus In Vivo Stratified by Patient Response to Antimalarials.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the immunologic profile of patients with CLE stratified by treatment outcomes to identify potential biomarkers of inducible response. They performed mass cytometry imaging of skin biopsy samples from CLE patients and stratified them according to their response to antimalarial therapy (HCQ responders, QC responders, or nonresponders). The findings indicate differential immune cell compositions between patients with CLE, offering guidance for future research on precision-based medicine and treatment response.

title: Spatial transcriptomics unveils ZBTB11 as a regulator of cardiomyocyte degeneration in arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.
main_goals: The study aims to delineate local changes in gene expression in ACM hearts using Tomo-Seq to identify new genes and pathways relevant for specific remodeling processes. It identifies ZBTB11 as a novel driver of cardiomyocyte loss. The research uncovers molecular mechanisms involved in human cardiomyopathy.

title: Mapping the developing human immune system across organs.
biological_context: Developing human immune system across organs
main_goals: The study reconstructs the developing human immune system by profiling nine prenatal tissues using single-cell RNA sequencing, antigen-receptor sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics. This reveals the late acquisition of immune-effector functions and the maturation of monocytes and T cells before peripheral tissue seeding. The study also characterizes human prenatal B1 cells and sheds light on the origin of unconventional T cells.

title: Intrinsic Differences in Spatiotemporal Organization and Stromal Cell Interactions Between Isogenic Lung Cancer Cells of Epithelial and Mesenchymal Phenotypes Revealed by High-Dimensional Single-Cell Analysis of Heterotypic 3D Spheroid Models.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize multicellular spheroids of isogenic cancer cells of various phenotypes and demonstrate proof-of-principle for the applicability of the spheroid model to evaluate the impact of cancer cell phenotype in drug screening experiments using high-dimensional and spatially resolved imaging mass cytometry (IMC) analyses. They developed 3D homotypic and heterotypic spheroid models comprising EGFRi-sensitive or EGFRi-resistant NSCLC cells and investigated intrinsic differences between epithelial and mesenchymal-like cancer cells.

title: Developmental landscape of human forebrain at a single-cell level identifies early waves of oligodendrogenesis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The study aims to characterize transcriptomic neural diversity in the human forebrain at post-conception weeks (PCW) 8-10 using single-cell RNA sequencing and single-cell ATAC-seq. It identifies a first wave of oligodendrocyte lineage cells as early as PCW 8 and predicts key transcriptional events leading to the specification of oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs). The study also identifies regions in the human ventral fetal forebrain where oligodendrogenesis first occurs using in situ sequencing.

title: Spatiotemporal mapping of gene expression landscapes and developmental trajectories during zebrafish embryogenesis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The study aims to reconstruct spatially resolved developmental trajectories of cell-fate transitions and molecular changes during zebrafish embryogenesis using Stereo-seq and scRNA-seq data. It also investigates the spatial distribution of ligand-receptor pairs to identify important interactions during embryo development. The study provides a reference for understanding vertebrate development.

title: High-resolution 3D spatiotemporal transcriptomic maps of developing Drosophila embryos and larvae.
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to dissect the spatiotemporal transcriptomic changes of developing Drosophila with high resolution and sensitivity using Stereo-seq. They demonstrate that Stereo-seq data can be used for the 3D reconstruction of the spatial transcriptomes of Drosophila embryos and larvae and to identify functional subregions, spatial cell state dynamics, and regulons of transcription factors.

title: Virus-related collapsing glomerulopathy, a common mechanism of injury?
biological_context: Collapsing glomerulopathy related to HIV infection or SARS-CoV-2
main_goals: The paper investigates patients with collapsing glomerulopathy related to HIV infection or SARS-CoV-2 using spatial transcriptomics. It provides evidence that collapsing glomerulopathy may have different molecular signatures despite similar morphologic appearance.

title: Determining protein polarization proteome-wide using physical dissection of individual Stentor coeruleus cells.
main_goals: The paper describes an approach for analyzing protein distribution within the giant ciliate Stentor coeruleus using microsurgery to separate cellular fragments along the anterior-posterior axis and then performing proteomic analysis. The study aims to determine the extent of proteome polarization with respect to cell polarity axes. The results reveal that a significant portion of the proteome shows polarized localization.

title: Moving translational mass spectrometry imaging towards transparent and reproducible data analyses: a case study of an urothelial cancer cohort analyzed in the Galaxy framework.
main_goals: The paper demonstrates the application of the Galaxy MSI tool set for reproducible analysis of a urothelial carcinoma dataset. It aims to make translational MSI data analysis transparent and reproducible, encouraging the community to adopt these practices. It also identified discriminative m/z features for tumor vs. stroma and muscle-infiltrating vs. non-muscle infiltrating urothelial tumors.

title: Spatial transcriptomic reconstruction of the mouse olfactory glomerular map suggests principles of odor processing.
main_goals: The paper aims to create a map of glomerular positions in the mouse olfactory bulb using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and machine learning. This map aims to provide insights into the organization of the olfactory system and how it relates to odor perception and discrimination.

title: Spatial CRISPR genomics identifies regulators of the tumor microenvironment.
main_goals: The paper introduces Perturb-map, a spatial functional genomics approach using CRISPR screens. It investigates the effects of gene knockouts on tumor growth, histopathology, and immune composition in a mouse model of lung cancer.  The study focuses on how TGFβ responsiveness of cancer cells can affect the tumor microenvironment.

title: Spatially Annotated Single Cell Sequencing for Unraveling Intratumor Heterogeneity.
main_goals: The paper introduces spatially annotated single cell sequencing (based on FUNseq) to profile tumor cells with deep scRNA-seq and single cell resolution. It investigates the spatial organization of cells in a 2D epithelial cell mass and how cells respond to their microenvironment. The study aims to unravel the mechanistic basis for intratumor heterogeneity.

title: Single-cell and spatially resolved analysis uncovers cell heterogeneity of breast cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to identify cell populations and their spatial distribution in breast cancer tissues by combining snRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. It seeks to decipher neoplastic subtypes, their spatial organization, and their association with patient survival and therapeutic response.

title: Performance scaling for structural MRI surface parcellations: a machine learning analysis in the ABCD Study.
main_goals: This paper investigates the impact of different structural MRI parcellations on the predictive performance of machine learning models for various phenotypic measures in adolescents. It explores the relationship between parcellation characteristics (e.g., number of parcels, type) and predictive accuracy, along with the effects of different machine learning pipelines and strategies.

title: Clonal relations in the mouse brain revealed by single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper uses in vivo barcoding of early progenitors to profile cell phenotypes and clonal relations in the mouse brain. It aims to reconstruct thousands of clones and discover fate-restricted progenitor cells in the mouse hippocampal neuroepithelium, and to understand the migration patterns of clonally related cells.

title: Spatial transcriptomic and single-nucleus analysis reveals heterogeneity in a gigantic single-celled syncytium.
main_goals: The paper investigates the spatial transcriptomic and single-nucleus heterogeneity within the slime mold Physarum polycephalum. It aims to identify regional differences in gene expression within the organism and to characterize the transcriptional profiles of individual nuclei. The study explores how nuclei variation contributes to cell growth, metabolism, and reproduction within this syncytial organism.

title: The synergism of spatial metabolomics and morphometry improves machine learning-based renal tumour subtype classification.
main_goals: The study aims to improve renal tumor subtype classification using a combination of spatial metabolomics and morphometry data with machine learning. The synergism of these data types is explored to achieve better classification accuracy.

title: Spatial maps of hepatocellular carcinoma transcriptomes highlight an unexplored landscape of heterogeneity and a novel gene signature for survival.
main_goals: This study investigated the heterogeneity of gene expression in HCC using spatial transcriptomics. It identified gene expression clusters and marker genes, and constructed a 6-gene signature for prognostic prediction. The study aims to clarify sources of HCC heterogeneity and uncover pathogenic mechanisms.

title: MEK inhibition suppresses metastatic progression of KRAS-mutated gastric cancer.
main_goals: To elucidate the mechanism underlying oncogene-induced gastric tumor progression using an organoid-based model.  To investigate the role of hypoxia signaling and MAPK pathway in metastasis. To evaluate the efficacy of MEK inhibitor trametinib in suppressing metastasis of KRAS-mutated gastric cancer.

title: Spatial discordances between mRNAs and proteins in the intestinal epithelium.
main_goals: To investigate the spatial discordances between mRNA and protein expression along the villus axis of the intestinal epithelium; to use spatial sorting and a Bayesian approach to infer protein translation and degradation rates; to determine if space-independent protein synthesis delays can explain mRNA-protein discordances.

title: 5-Alpha reductase inhibitors induce a prostate luminal to club cell transition in human benign prostatic hyperplasia.
main_goals: To characterize gene expression changes in prostates from 5ARI-treated men using spatial profiling approaches.  To determine the histological response to 5ARI treatment and elucidate the mechanism of adaptation by prostate luminal cells.  To confirm the findings using two independent spatial profiling platforms.

title: Sequencing of a Chinese tetralogy of Fallot cohort reveals clustering mutations in myogenic heart progenitors.
main_goals: To identify genetic causes of Tetralogy of Fallot in a Chinese cohort using whole-genome sequencing. To integrate these genetic findings with single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data to understand the impact of mutations on early cardiac development. To reveal cellular hotspots in early heart development contributing to cardiac malformations.

title: Spatiotemporal Evolution and Regional Differences in the Production-Living-Ecological Space of the Urban Agglomeration in the Middle Reaches of the Yangtze River.
main_goals: To identify the evolution and regional differences in the production-living-ecological space (PLES) in the middle reaches of the Yangtze River urban agglomeration.  The study uses the Theil index and exploratory spatial data analysis (ESDA) to measure regional differences in PLES between resource- and non-resource-based cities.  The findings reveal spatial aggregation in PLES and that regional differences mainly stem from intraregional variations.

title: Spatial variability of the sources and distribution of fluoride in groundwater of the Sanya alluvial plain aquifers in northern Tanzania.
main_goals: To investigate the spatial variability of fluoride in groundwater in the Sanya alluvial plain of northern Tanzania. To associate the distribution of fluoride with spatial variability in terrain slopes, volcanic deposits, and groundwater resource development.  To provide insights for improving safe water supply processes and drilling permit issuance in fluorotic regions.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics to define transcriptional patterns of zonation and structural components in the mouse liver.
main_goals: To apply Spatial Transcriptomics to analyze the mouse liver transcriptome, confirming that heterogeneity is primarily determined by lobular zonation.  To introduce novel computational approaches enabling transcriptional gradient measurements across tissue structures.  To identify previously uncharacterized structures within liver tissue.

title: Spatially Resolved Transcriptomic Analysis of Acute Kidney Injury in a Female Murine Model.
biological_context: Acute Kidney Injury in a female murine model
main_goals: To generate spatial maps of gene expression in a female murine model of acute kidney injury (AKI) using 10x Genomics Visium. To use computational tools (Giotto and SPOTlight) to analyze the spatial data and identify cell-cell interactions during the injury and repair process.  To provide an interactive data visualization application for the scientific community to explore the results.

title: Subtyping non-small cell lung cancer by histology-guided spatial metabolomics.
main_goals: To subtype non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) into adenocarcinoma (AC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC) using a spatial metabolomics approach. To discriminate tumor and stroma regions in NSCLC tissues. To detect NSCLC with rarely arising mutations of the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) gene.

title: The Impact of Histological Annotations for Accurate Tissue Classification Using Mass Spectrometry Imaging.
main_goals: Investigate the impact of histological annotation on the accuracy of tumor tissue classification using mass spectrometry imaging.  Determine the effect of tissue heterogeneity on the impact of histological annotations.  Show that the impact of annotations is more significant in heterogeneous tissues like pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma than in homogeneous tissues like kidney tumors.

title: Heat-evolved algal symbionts enhance bleaching tolerance of adult corals without trade-off against growth.
main_goals: This study demonstrates that heat-evolved microalgal symbionts can enhance the thermotolerance of adult corals without impacting growth. The research utilized mass spectrometry imaging to investigate the molecular basis of this enhanced thermotolerance, suggesting algal pigments play a key role in photoprotection. The findings indicate a potential for long-term stability of this novel symbiosis for coral reef restoration.

title: Tissue morphology influences the temporal program of human brain organoid development.
main_goals: This paper investigates how tissue morphology influences the temporal program of human brain organoid development. Using snRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics, it shows that organoids with proper morphology better mimic in vivo development. The study demonstrates that correct spatial coordinates are necessary for accurate temporal progression in developing brain cells.

title: Spatial metabolomics using imaging mass spectrometry to identify the localization of asparaptine A in Asparagus officinalis.
main_goals: To apply spatial metabolomics using IMS to identify the localization of asparaptine A in Asparagus officinalis green spears. The study aimed to characterize metabolite distribution patterns and specifically localize asparaptine A. It provides biological context for asparaptine A's function and identifies a region for future multiomics studies.

title: Tumor Microenvironment Profiles Reveal Distinct Therapy-Oriented Proteogenomic Characteristics in Colorectal Cancer.
main_goals: To understand the molecular architecture of the colorectal cancer tumor microenvironment under different therapeutic regimes (chemotherapy vs. chemo+immunotherapy) using high-plex spatial proteogenomics (DSP). The study aims to identify distinct therapy-oriented characteristics, including immune infiltration and potential biomarkers like PD-L1, to inform patient stratification and therapeutic improvement.

title: Stratification of chemotherapy-treated stage III colorectal cancer patients using multiplexed imaging and single-cell analysis of T-cell populations.
main_goals: To assess immune signatures in stage III CRC tumor and TME using multiplexed imaging and single-cell analysis. Evaluate correlations of these signatures with patient outcomes (DFS, OS) following adjuvant chemotherapy. Compare multi-marker classification of immune cells with single markers for prognostication.

title: Dissecting mammalian spermatogenesis using spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Mammalian spermatogenesis, Testis, Diabetes-induced male infertility
main_goals: To create a spatial transcriptomics atlas of mouse and human testis using Slide-seq. To develop a computational framework for localizing testicular cell types. To identify spatially patterned genes/programs and compare cellular compositions between mouse and human testes. To investigate spatial disruptions in diabetic mouse testis.

title: Profiling of lung SARS-CoV-2 and influenza virus infection dissects virus-specific host responses and gene signatures.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Differential Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper uses spatial transcriptomics (NanoString GeoMX) to profile the pulmonary transcriptional landscape in COVID-19, H1N1 influenza, and uninfected controls. It aims to define the host response to SARS-CoV-2, investigate spatial distribution effects, and identify virus-specific gene signatures, highlighting the utility of spatial methods for understanding pathogenesis and finding biomarkers.

title: Phosphoproteome profiling uncovers a key role for CDKs in TNF signaling.
biological_context: TNF signaling, apoptosis, and necroptosis in human cell lines (A549, U937)
main_goals: To dissect diverse TNF signaling functions using systems-level proteomic analysis, identifying functional modules of phosphorylation and phosphorylation-dependent protein translocations. The study uncovered a key role for cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) in TNF-induced cell fate decisions.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals a role for sensory nerves in preserving cranial suture patency through modulation of BMP/TGF-β signaling.
main_goals: To investigate the role of sensory nerves in cranial suture patency using spatial transcriptomics. The study shows that sensory nerves, via signals like FSTL1, regulate mesenchymal progenitor cell proliferation and differentiation through BMP/TGF-β signaling, thereby influencing cranial bone patterning and preventing premature suture closure.

title: Single-Cell Atlas of Lineage States, Tumor Microenvironment, and Subtype-Specific Expression Programs in Gastric Cancer.
main_goals: To create a comprehensive single-cell atlas of gastric cancer across stages and subtypes, identify distinct cell lineage states and tumor microenvironment components, and characterize subtype-specific expression programs. They identified novel cell populations and correlated specific cell types like plasma cells and fibroblasts with subtypes and prognosis. Findings were validated using spatial transcriptomics, bulk RNA-seq, and functional models, providing a high-resolution molecular resource.

title: Fluorescent Multiplex Immunohistochemistry Coupled With Other State-Of-The-Art Techniques to Systematically Characterize the Tumor Immune Microenvironment.
biological_context: HER2+ breast cancer, Luminal B breast tumor
data_modalities_used: ['flow cytometry', 'multiplex bead-based immunoassays', 'chromogenic immunohistochemistry (IHC)', 'fluorescent multiplex IHC', 'immunofluorescence', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: The paper provides an overview and discusses the application of state-of-the-art techniques, including fluorescent multiplex IHC and spatial transcriptomics, to characterize the tumor immune microenvironment. It illustrates their use with representative data from breast cancer and demonstrates their potential for identifying cellular phenotypes and spatial relationships, such as co-localization in tertiary lymphoid structures.

title: Integrated spatial multiomics reveals fibroblast fate during tissue repair.
data_modalities_used: ['single cell chromatin accessibility', 'single cell RNA-seq', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: To characterize cells involved in wound healing across time and space using an integrated spatial multiomics platform. Specifically, to track fibroblast fate and impute spatial epigenomes to reveal potential mechanisms controlling fibroblast behavior (migration, proliferation, differentiation) during skin injury.

title: 3D cell neighbour dynamics in growing pseudostratified epithelia.
main_goals: This paper investigates 3D cell organization and neighbor dynamics in growing pseudostratified epithelia using light-sheet microscopy and 3D segmentation. It applies physical principles (Euler's, Lewis', Aboav-Weaire's laws) to cell packing configurations. The main goal is to show that complex 3D cellular organization emerges from simple physical principles.

title: Highly Multiplexed Image Analysis of Intestinal Tissue Sections in Patients With Inflammatory Bowel Disease.
biological_context: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) in human intestine
covered_analysis_steps: ['Highly Multiplex Image Analysis', 'Cell Typing', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Cell Composition Analysis']
main_goals: Characterize the inflammatory environment of human IBD tissues using imaging mass cytometry. Quantify immune cell types and characterize their spatial interactions within the inflammatory environment. Use this approach to understand IBD pathogenesis and progression.

title: A single-cell and spatially resolved atlas of human breast cancers.
main_goals: To create a single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics atlas of human breast cancers. To reveal recurrent neoplastic cell heterogeneity, characterize immune and mesenchymal cell profiles, understand spatial organization of niches, and stratify tumors into ecotypes based on cellular composition.

title: An N-Cadherin 2 expressing epithelial cell subpopulation predicts response to surgery, chemotherapy and immunotherapy in bladder cancer.
main_goals: This study aims to identify an epithelial subpopulation in bladder cancer using multi-omics data, including spatial transcriptomics and proteomics, to predict therapeutic response to surgery, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy. It characterizes the CDH12-expressing subpopulation and its association with clinical outcome and molecular features.

title: Identification of HSC/MPP expansion units in fetal liver by single-cell spatiotemporal transcriptomics.
biological_context: Mouse fetal liver development and hematopoiesis
main_goals: Construct a spatiotemporal transcriptome map of mouse fetal liver, identify heterogeneous HSC/MPP subsets and novel 'pocket-like' units (HSC PLUS) through integrative spatial and single-cell analysis, validate niche cell (macrophage) and growth factor support for HSC/MPP expansion, and perform cross-species comparison with human FL.

title: Assessing the replicability of spatial gene expression using atlas data from the adult mouse brain.
main_goals: To assess the replicability of spatial gene expression patterns defining canonical brain subdivisions between two datasets: Allen Brain Atlas in situ hybridization (ISH) and spatial transcriptomics (ST). They apply supervised learning methods to classify brain areas based on expression, finding higher performance within datasets than between them.

title: Visualization and Analysis of Gene Expression in Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection Tissue Section by Spatial Transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper aimed to apply spatial transcriptomics to study Stanford type A aortic dissection in challenging fibrous tissue. It involved establishing a suitable data processing pipeline by comparing algorithms and using it to visualize spatial gene expression, identify cell types, and explore heterogeneity to gain biological insights into the disease pathogenesis.

title: Time lapse synchrotron IR chemical imaging for observing the acclimation of a single algal cell to CO<sub>2</sub> treatment.
biological_context: Algal cells (Thalassiosira weissflogii) acclimating to CO2 changes
main_goals: To use time-lapse synchrotron IR chemical imaging to observe and analyze the spatial and temporal chemical composition changes within a single algal cell during acclimation to different CO2 concentrations. The study applied preprocessing, fringe correction, and principal component analysis to identify changes in carbohydrate, lipid, and nucleic acid pools as a local metabolism response.

title: ZNRF3 and RNF43 cooperate to safeguard metabolic liver zonation and hepatocyte proliferation.
biological_context: Liver zonation, hepatocyte proliferation, WNT signaling, intestinal stem cells
main_goals: This paper investigates how ZNRF3 and RNF43 restrict hepatocyte proliferation in the liver despite high WNT/β-Catenin activity, while preserving metabolic function required for liver zonation. It shows that these E3 ligases fine-tune WNT signaling and their deletion promotes proliferation and ultimately liver tumors, highlighting their role in safeguarding liver homeostasis.

title: Integration of spatial and single-cell transcriptomics localizes epithelial cell-immune cross-talk in kidney injury.
biological_context: Acute kidney injury (AKI) in mice and human nephrectomy
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-nuclear sequencing', 'single-cell sequencing', 'histopathology', 'multiplexed CO-Detection by indEXing (CODEX) immunofluorescence']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This study integrates spatial and single-cell transcriptomics to map cell types and understand epithelial cell-immune cross-talk in kidney injury. It characterized the spatial transcriptomic signature of two murine AKI models, identifying localized regions of reduced expression and patterns of immune and epithelial cell colocalization. The research aimed to uncover mechanisms driving immune cell infiltration and validate findings with immunofluorescence.

title: Single cell and spatial transcriptomics in human tendon disease indicate dysregulated immune homeostasis.
main_goals: This study uses single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to investigate human tendon disease. The findings indicate dysregulated immune homeostasis within the affected tendons, providing new biological insights into the disease pathogenesis.

title: An integrated multi-omics analysis identifies prognostic molecular subtypes of non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study performs an integrative multi-omics analysis to identify prognostic molecular subtypes of NMIBC. It characterizes these subtypes based on transcriptomics and chromosomal instability, and validates their prognostic value. The findings aim to provide a framework for biomarker discovery and treatment optimization.

title: Spatiotemporal analysis of bubonic plague in Pernambuco, northeast of Brazil: Case study in the municipality of Exu.
biological_context: Bubonic plague in humans in Pernambuco, Brazil
