covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This study used multiplexed ion beam imaging (MIBI-TOF) to characterize the tumor-immune microenvironment in triple-negative breast cancer. It revealed variability in immune cell composition and spatial organization, identifying structured immune infiltrates associated with patient survival and cell-type/location-specific checkpoint protein expression.

title: The Chemoattractant Receptor Ebi2 Drives Intranodal Naive CD4<sup>+</sup> T Cell Peripheralization to Promote Effective Adaptive Immunity.
biological_context: Lymph node immune cell localization and function
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of the chemoattractant receptor Ebi2 in directing the spatial distribution of naive CD4+ T cells within lymph nodes. It demonstrates that Ebi2-mediated localization of these cells alongside cDC2 dendritic cells is crucial for efficient adaptive immunity, including antigen recognition, T cell expansion, differentiation, and effective CD8+ T cell memory responses. The findings highlight the importance of microanatomical organization within lymph nodes for optimizing immune responses.

title: Single-Cell Analyses of Colon and Blood Reveal Distinct Immune Cell Signatures of Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease.
data_modalities_used: ['mass cytometry (CyTOF)', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'flow cytometry', 'RNA in situ hybridization']
main_goals: To characterize and compare immune cell populations in the mucosa and blood from patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) and controls at single-cell resolution. The study aimed to identify distinct immune cell signatures of ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD) and utilized various single-cell technologies to achieve this. The findings are intended to inform the development of targeted therapies for different types of IBD.

title: Reference-based analysis of lung single-cell sequencing reveals a transitional profibrotic macrophage.
biological_context: Lung fibrosis induced by bleomycin in mice
main_goals: To characterize macrophage heterogeneity in bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis using single-cell RNA sequencing. The study identified a novel transitional profibrotic macrophage subgroup by employing a reference-based computational framework. This subgroup was found to localize to the fibrotic niche and exert a profibrotic effect, with human orthologs upregulated in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis patients.

title: B cells and tertiary lymphoid structures promote immunotherapy response.
biological_context: Melanoma and Renal Cell Carcinoma treated with Immune Checkpoint Blockade (ICB)
data_modalities_used: ['bulk RNA sequencing', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'Mass cytometry', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of B cells and tertiary lymphoid structures in the response to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) therapy. The study utilized RNA sequencing and mass cytometry to identify B cell signatures and their localization within tumors of responders. Findings suggest potential implications for developing biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Resolving early mesoderm diversification through single-cell expression profiling.
biological_context: Early mesoderm formation during mammalian gastrulation in mouse embryos
main_goals: To analyze single-cell expression profiles of epiblast and nascent Flk1(+) mesoderm from gastrulating mouse embryos at embryonic day 6.5 to understand early mesoderm formation. The study also investigated the function of the transcription factor Tal1 in precursor cells.

title: Memory CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells are generated in the human fetal intestine.
data_modalities_used: ['mass cytometry', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'high-throughput T cell antigen receptor (TCR) sequencing', 'Imaging mass cytometry']
main_goals: This paper investigates the CD4+ T cell compartment in the human fetal intestine using a combination of functional assays and high-throughput omics techniques. It aims to characterize these cells and provide evidence for the generation of memory-like CD4+ T cells in the fetal intestine, suggesting an exposure to foreign antigens.

title: Single-cell analysis of endometriosis reveals a coordinated transcriptional programme driving immunotolerance and angiogenesis across eutopic and ectopic tissues.
main_goals: To characterize peritoneal and ovarian endometriosis lesions at single-cell resolution and compare them to matched eutopic endometrium, identifying cell types and microenvironmental features. The study aims to provide a holistic view of the endometriosis microenvironment for future therapeutic and diagnostic development.

title: Pan-cancer single-cell analysis reveals the heterogeneity and plasticity of cancer-associated fibroblasts in the tumor microenvironment.
biological_context: Pan-cancer analysis of 10 solid cancer types
main_goals: This study performs a pan-cancer analysis of 226 samples across 10 solid cancer types to profile the tumor microenvironment at single-cell resolution. It illustrates the commonalities and plasticity of heterogeneous cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and their interactions with other cells. The study highlights the shared characteristics and dynamics of CAFs, emphasizing their heterogeneity and plasticity across different cancer types.

title: Mass cytometry reveals systemic and local immune signatures that distinguish inflammatory bowel diseases.
biological_context: Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
main_goals: This paper uses mass cytometry to analyze leukocyte subsets and their functions in blood and intestinal tissue from healthy and IBD subjects. The study aims to identify systemic and local immune signatures that can distinguish between different inflammatory bowel diseases and their phenotypes, highlighting the role of gut-tropic leukocytes in circulation.

title: Single-cell analysis of the human pancreas in type 2 diabetes using multi-spectral imaging mass cytometry.
biological_context: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) in the human pancreas
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper uses imaging mass cytometry (IMC) with a panel of 34 antibodies to quantify markers of pancreatic cells and stromal components in type 2 diabetes (T2D). It aims to identify alterations in islet architecture, endocrine cell composition, and immune cell constituents in T2D pancreata compared to controls. The study demonstrates the utility of IMC for investigating cellular-level events in T2D pathophysiology.

title: Hipposeq: a comprehensive RNA-seq database of gene expression in hippocampal principal neurons.
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive, quantitative, whole-genome characterization of gene expression for major excitatory neuronal classes in the hippocampus using RNA-seq. The study aims to clarify transcriptional properties, identify lesser-known cell classes, and reveal regional variations within the hippocampus. The developed resource, Hipposeq, serves as a public platform for data analysis and visualization.

title: Transcriptomic and immunophenotypic profiling reveals molecular and immunological hallmarks of colorectal cancer tumourigenesis.
data_modalities_used: ['digital spatial profiling (GeoMx)', 'imaging mass cytometry', 'single-cell RNA-sequencing', 'histology images']
main_goals: To dissect the transcriptional and immunologic alterations that accompany malignant transformation in colorectal cancer (CRC) and to identify clinically relevant biomarkers through spatial profiling of pT1 CRC samples. The study used digital spatial profiling and imaging mass cytometry to analyze gene expression and immune contextures across different histological regions of CRC.

title: Transcriptome analysis of individual stromal cell populations identifies stroma-tumor crosstalk in mouse lung cancer model.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This study dissects the contribution of specific hematopoietic stromal cells in a mouse lung cancer model. It identifies cell-type-specific differentially regulated genes and develops a computational model for crosstalk signaling discovery, revealing paracrine and autocrine pathways in NSCLC. The findings aim to provide insights into the tumor microenvironment for developing targeted therapeutic strategies.

title: Intra- and Inter-cellular Rewiring of the Human Colon during Ulcerative Colitis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction']
main_goals: The study generates a comprehensive atlas of colon cells from ulcerative colitis (UC) patients and healthy individuals to understand the cell type specificities and pathways associated with UC risk alleles. It identifies specific cell subsets and their intercellular interactions that expand with disease, contributing to inflammation. The work proposes a framework for mapping risk variants to cell types and pathways.

title: Spatial Architecture of Myeloid and T Cells Orchestrates Immune Evasion and Clinical Outcome in Lung Cancer.
main_goals: This study analyzes the spatial architecture of myeloid and T cells within the tumor microenvironment (TME) of treatment-naïve early-stage lung cancer. It identifies four distinct TME archetypes and links their spatial organization to genomic features, immune evasion mechanisms, and clinical outcomes, particularly highlighting the role of neutrophil-rich TMEs in metastasis.

title: Spatial transcriptomic survey of human embryonic cerebral cortex by single-cell RNA-seq analysis.
main_goals: This paper presents a regional characterization of the human cerebral cortex using single-cell transcriptome analysis of over 4,000 cells from 22 brain regions of mid-gestation embryos. It identifies cell sub-clusters, analyzes their regional distribution, and describes regional gene expression patterns and neuron maturation. The study highlights a large proportion of neural disease-related genes within region-specific genes.

title: Single cell transcriptomics of human epidermis identifies basal stem cell transition states.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This paper uses single cell-RNA sequencing to investigate the heterogeneity of basal stem cells in human interfollicular epidermis. It identifies distinct stem cell populations, models cell-cell communication, and suggests a hierarchical differentiation lineage essential for epidermal homeostasis. The study validates the importance of these stem cells by showing that alterations in their gene expression lead to thinner skin.

title: Cytometry by time-of-flight shows combinatorial cytokine expression and virus-specific cell niches within a continuum of CD8+ T cell phenotypes.
biological_context: CD8+ T cell phenotypes and virus-specific responses in humans
main_goals: This paper applies cytometry by time-of-flight (CyTOF) to analyze human CD8+ T cells at an unprecedented protein scale. It reveals combinatorial cytokine expression and distinct niches occupied by virus-specific cells within a continuous spectrum of CD8+ T cell phenotypes. The findings highlight the functional diversity and flexibility of CD8+ T cells in responding to pathogens.

title: Spatial multiomics map of trophoblast development in early pregnancy.
biological_context: Human maternal-fetal interface development in early pregnancy
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell analysis', 'multiomics', 'in vitro models', 'trophoblast organoids', 'trophoblast stem cells']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Communication Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: The study generated a spatially resolved multiomics single-cell atlas of the human maternal-fetal interface. This atlas was used to resolve trophoblast differentiation trajectories, infer transcription factors for EVT invasion, and model arterial transformation. The data aims to inform the design of experimental models of the human placenta in early pregnancy.

title: Single-Cell Transcriptomics Reveal Disrupted Kidney Filter Cell-Cell Interactions after Early and Selective Podocyte Injury.
biological_context: Early and selective podocyte injury in the kidney leading to chronic kidney diseases (CKDs)
main_goals: To map the earliest transcriptional effects of podocyte injury on cell-cell interactions within the kidney filter at single-cell resolution. The study aims to identify key cell-cell communication pathways disrupted by podocyte injury, pointing to potential therapeutic targets for CKDs.

title: Spatially mapping the immune landscape of melanoma using imaging mass cytometry.
main_goals: This study used imaging mass cytometry (IMC) to map the immune landscape of melanoma and identify spatial relationships between different cell types. The researchers aimed to understand how these spatial interactions correlate with response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). They found that the abundance and proximity of proliferating antigen-experienced cytotoxic T cells to melanoma cells were associated with positive ICI response.

title: Single-cell analysis of human non-small cell lung cancer lesions refines tumor classification and patient stratification.
biological_context: Human non-small cell lung cancer lesions
main_goals: This study uses single-cell RNA sequencing and CITE-seq to profile early-stage non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) lesions. It identifies a cellular module (LCAM) associated with immunotherapy response, independent of overall immune cell content, and suggests immune cell composition as a nonredundant biomarker.

title: Long-distance modulation of bystander tumor cells by CD8<sup>+</sup> T cell-secreted IFNγ.
main_goals: This study investigates the long-distance spreading and effects of CD8+ T cell-secreted IFNγ within the tumor microenvironment using intravital imaging. It demonstrates that IFNγ can reach distant tumor cells, modulating their behavior by inducing PD-L1 expression and inhibiting growth, even affecting antigen-loss variants.

title: Spatial detection of fetal marker genes expressed at low level in adult human heart tissue.
biological_context: Heart failure in adult human heart tissue
main_goals: This study examines spatial variations within cardiac biopsies to detect fetal marker genes expressed at low levels in adult human heart tissue, aiming to differentiate disease states in heart failure.

title: Multilineage communication regulates human liver bud development from pluripotency.
biological_context: Human liver bud development from pluripotency
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Differentiation']
main_goals: This paper investigates multilineage communication regulating human liver bud development from pluripotency using three-dimensional organoids. It aims to deconstruct heterogeneity during liver bud development and understand the molecular mechanisms of interlineage communication. The study identifies vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) crosstalk as a key regulator of endothelial network formation and hepatoblast differentiation.

title: Human pluripotent stem cell-derived kidney organoids for personalized congenital and idiopathic nephrotic syndrome modeling.
biological_context: Human congenital and idiopathic nephrotic syndrome modeling using kidney organoids
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'super-resolution imaging', 'electron microscopy', 'RNA sequencing', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study develops next-generation human pluripotent stem cell-derived kidney organoids with superior podocyte characteristics for modeling nephrotic syndrome. The organoids enable personalized modeling of idiopathic and congenital nephrotic syndrome, demonstrating disease mechanisms and the reversibility of genetic defects.

title: Spatial immune profiling of the colorectal tumor microenvironment predicts good outcome in stage II patients.
main_goals: This study evaluated the prognostic significance of cellular subpopulations and their spatial interactions within the colorectal tumor microenvironment using automated image analysis and machine learning. A combinatorial prognostic model was developed and validated, demonstrating the ability to identify patients with excellent survival outcomes.

title: Mass Cytometry of the Human Mucosal Immune System Identifies Tissue- and Disease-Associated Immune Subsets.
biological_context: Human mucosal immune system, inflammatory intestinal diseases, mucosal lymphoid malignancies
main_goals: To use high-dimensional mass cytometry and computational applications to generate a system-wide view of the human mucosal immune system in health and disease. The study aimed to distinguish immune subsets associated with the pathogenesis of complex intestinal disorders and to detect mucosal lymphoid malignancies.

title: Fgf4 maintains Hes7 levels critical for normal somite segmentation clock function.
data_modalities_used: ['mRNA quantification', 'fluorescent hybridization chain reaction', 'volumetric tissue subsets']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of FGF4 in maintaining Hes7 levels critical for normal somite segmentation clock function during vertebrate development. It analyzes mouse mutants lacking FGF4 and quantifies mRNA levels to demonstrate that FGF4 maintains Hes7 expression and oscillatory patterns. The study also shows genetic synergy between Fgf4 and Hes7, suggesting FGF4's importance in preventing segmentation defects.

title: Proteomics. Tissue-based map of the human proteome.
main_goals: To create a tissue-based map of the human proteome using an integrated omics approach, exploring various proteomic subsets and providing a web-based database for data exploration. The study aims to increase knowledge of human biology and disease by resolving molecular details of proteome variation across tissues.

title: Genomic-anatomic evidence for distinct functional domains in hippocampal field CA1.
biological_context: Mammalian hippocampal field CA1 functional domains
main_goals: This paper presents genomic-anatomic evidence for distinct functional domains in hippocampal field CA1. It uses a genome-wide expression digital library to reveal regional and laminar differentiation of CA1 pyramidal neurons. The study suggests that genetically distinct spatial domains of CA1 project to specific subcortical regions, forming independent functional networks.

title: Dissecting the multicellular ecosystem of metastatic melanoma by single-cell RNA-seq.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This study applies single-cell RNA sequencing to metastatic melanoma tumors to dissect the multicellular ecosystem. It reveals transcriptional heterogeneity within malignant cells and identifies distinct tumor microenvironmental patterns, including cell-to-cell interactions. The findings offer insights into targeted and immune therapies by characterizing the cellular states and interactions within melanoma.

title: TREM2 macrophages induced by human lipids drive inflammation in acne lesions.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of TREM2 macrophages and lipids in the pathogenesis of acne. It identifies TREM2 macrophages expressing lipid metabolism and proinflammatory gene programs in acne lesions and demonstrates that squalene induces these macrophages, which are impaired in killing C. acnes. The study also suggests a mechanism for benzoyl peroxide efficacy by showing squalene inhibits oxidative enzymes.

title: Early Fate Defines Microglia and Non-parenchymal Brain Macrophage Development.
main_goals: This study identified two distinct brain macrophage populations, microglia and border-associated macrophages (BAMs), that emerge during development. It reveals that BAMs mostly derive from early erythro-myeloid progenitors in the yolk sac, while microglia development is dependent on TGF-β, unlike BAMs.

title: Aligned collagen is a prognostic signature for survival in human breast carcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'biopsy tissue sections', 'second harmonic generation imaging']
main_goals: To rigorously examine the relationship between a tumor-associated collagen signature-3 (TACS-3), characterized by aligned collagen fibers, and the long-term survival rate of human breast carcinoma patients. The study aimed to establish TACS-3 as a prognostic indicator for survival.

title: Seeing the Confetti Colors in a New Light Utilizing Flow Cytometry and Imaging Flow Cytometry.
biological_context: Hematopoietically derived motile cell types (T and B lymphocytes), intestinal mucosa crypts, microglial heterogeneity, B-cell clonal evolution.
main_goals: This paper analyzes a 10-color biallelic Confetti reporter using flow and imaging flow cytometry. It demonstrates the utility of these techniques for measuring reporter labeling densities and color distributions over time in motile cell populations. This approach opens new avenues for studying tumor heterogeneity and clonal dynamics.

title: Single-cell transcriptomics reveals regulators underlying immune cell diversity and immune subtypes associated with prognosis in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
main_goals: This study utilizes single-cell transcriptomics to analyze the tumor microenvironment (TME) in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It identifies malignant cell signatures, diverse immune cell subtypes (including novel CLEC9A+ DCs), and transcriptional regulators of immune cell diversity. The research also establishes immune subtype-specific signatures associated with prognosis, highlighting potential biomarkers for NPC.

title: Single-cell dissection of transcriptional heterogeneity in human colon tumors.
main_goals: This study dissects transcriptional heterogeneity in human colon tumors using single-cell PCR gene-expression analysis. It demonstrates that cancer tissues contain cell populations mirroring normal colon lineages and that this diversity is largely due to in vivo multilineage differentiation, not just clonal genetic heterogeneity. The study also developed two-gene classifier systems to predict patient survival.

title: The single-cell pathology landscape of breast cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Phenotype Identification', 'Spatial Organization Analysis', 'Tumor Microenvironment Characterization']
main_goals: This paper uses imaging mass cytometry to quantify 35 biomarkers in breast cancer tissue, characterizing cellular phenotypes, their spatial organization, and heterogeneity. The analysis aims to identify multicellular features of the tumor microenvironment and novel breast cancer subgroups associated with distinct clinical outcomes, informing patient-specific diagnosis.

title: Immune phenotyping of diverse syngeneic murine brain tumors identifies immunologically distinct types.
biological_context: Glioblastoma (GBM) brain tumors in mice and humans
main_goals: The study aimed to characterize the immune profiles of diverse syngeneic murine glioblastoma (GBM) tumor models. It identified immunologically distinct tumor types and investigated the impact of tumor resection on the immune microenvironment. The findings guide GBM model selection for immunotherapy and offer insights for clinical applications.

title: A single-cell landscape of high-grade serous ovarian cancer.
biological_context: High-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) ascites ecosystem
main_goals: To comprehensively characterize the HGSOC ascites ecosystem using single-cell RNA sequencing. The study identified inter-patient variability in cell composition and functional programs, shedding light on the subtypes of HGSOC and potential therapeutic targets like the JAK/STAT pathway.

title: Distinct Mesenchymal Lineages and Niches Promote Epithelial Self-Renewal and Myofibrogenesis in the Lung.
main_goals: This paper aims to generate a spatial and transcriptional map of the lung mesenchyme. It identifies distinct mesenchymal lineages and their niche regulatory functions, revealing pathways that promote epithelial self-renewal and myofibrogenesis. The study highlights the importance of developmental pathways in lung regeneration and pathological responses.

title: A Cellular Anatomy of the Normal Adult Human Prostate and Prostatic Urethra.
biological_context: Normal adult human prostate and prostatic urethra
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive cellular anatomy of the normal adult human prostate and prostatic urethra using single-cell RNA sequencing and flow cytometry. The study aims to identify cell type-specific markers to improve purification and create a resource for understanding prostate diseases like benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostate cancer.

title: Liver homeostasis is maintained by midlobular zone 2 hepatocytes.
biological_context: Liver homeostasis and regeneration in mice
main_goals: This paper systematically compares distinct subsets of hepatocytes in mice using 14 fate-mapping strains. It identifies zone 2 hepatocytes as a key contributor to liver homeostasis and regeneration, driven by the IGFBP2-mTOR-CCND1 axis.

title: Single-cell analyses reveal key immune cell subsets associated with response to PD-L1 blockade in triple-negative breast cancer.
main_goals: This study uses single-cell RNA- and ATAC-sequencing to analyze immune cell dynamics in patients with advanced triple-negative breast cancer treated with paclitaxel or atezolizumab. It identifies CXCL13+ T cells as a predictor of response and reveals that CXCL13+ T cells, LTi cells, Bfoc cells, and cDC1 cells increase with combination therapy but decrease with monotherapy.

title: An interactive murine single-cell atlas of the lung responses to radiation injury.
biological_context: Radiation-Induced Lung Injury (RILI) and pulmonary fibrosis
main_goals: To present an interactive murine single-cell atlas of the lung response to irradiation to explore the spatio-temporal dynamics of mechanisms leading to radiation-induced pulmonary fibrosis. The atlas provides unprecedented detail on cell type-specific radiation-induced responses.

title: Molecularly defined and spatially resolved cell atlas of the whole mouse brain.
data_modalities_used: ['multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To generate a comprehensive cell atlas of the whole mouse brain with high molecular and spatial resolution by integrating multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization and single-cell RNA sequencing. The atlas aims to enable systematic quantifications of cell-type composition and organization, identify spatial modules and gradients, and infer cell-type-specific interactions.

title: A single-cell map of intratumoral changes during anti-PD1 treatment of patients with breast cancer.
biological_context: Breast cancer treatment response to anti-PD1 therapy
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptome', 'T cell receptor profiling', 'proteome profiling', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study aims to understand the reasons behind the subset of breast cancer tumors that respond to anti-PD1 immunotherapy. It investigates intratumoral changes at a single-cell level by profiling biopsies before and during treatment. The research identifies immunophenotypes and gene sets correlated with T cell expansion following anti-PD1 treatment, shedding light on response heterogeneity.

title: The local transcriptome in the synaptic neuropil revealed by deep sequencing and high-resolution imaging.
main_goals: This paper uses deep sequencing and high-resolution imaging to identify mRNAs localized to the synaptic neuropil in the hippocampus. It reveals a large number of transcripts, many of which encode known synaptic proteins, highlighting the potential for local protein synthesis to supply, maintain, and modify the synaptic proteome.

title: Spatial and temporal heterogeneity of mouse and human microglia at single-cell resolution.
biological_context: Mouse and human brain development and disease (multiple sclerosis, neurodegenerative diseases)
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell analysis', 'single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization', 'immunohistochemistry', 'computational modelling']
main_goals: To comprehensively characterize subclasses of microglia in multiple regions of the central nervous system during development and disease using single-cell analysis, smFISH, immunohistochemistry, and computational modeling. The study identified time- and region-dependent subtypes of microglia in mice and corresponding clusters in humans, providing insights into the endogenous immune system and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics reveals the architecture of the tumor-microenvironment interface.
biological_context: Zebrafish model of melanoma and human melanoma
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study uses spatially resolved transcriptomics, single-cell RNA-seq, and single-nucleus RNA-seq to investigate tumor-microenvironment interactions at the tumor boundary. It identifies a distinct "interface" cell state characterized by shared cilia gene expression in both tumor and microenvironment cells, conserved in human melanoma. The findings highlight the utility of spatial transcriptomics in understanding tumor adaptation.

title: Distinct microbial and immune niches of the human colon.
main_goals: This paper aims to delineate colonic immune niches at steady state by simultaneously assessing microbiota and single immune cells across the healthy, adult human colon and in paired mesenteric lymph nodes. It describes distinct helper T cell activation and migration profiles along the colon, characterizes regulatory T cell transcriptional adaptation, and shows increasing B cell accumulation, clonal expansion, and mutational frequency from the cecum to the sigmoid colon, linking it to reactive bacterial species.

title: Developmental Heterogeneity of Microglia and Brain Myeloid Cells Revealed by Deep Single-Cell RNA Sequencing.
biological_context: Mouse brain development and neurodegenerative disease
main_goals: This study performed deep single-cell RNA sequencing of microglia and related myeloid cells from various regions of embryonic, early postnatal, and adult mouse brains. The goal was to understand the developmental heterogeneity of these cells and identify distinct subsets and their functions. The findings provide an atlas for dissecting innate immune functions in health and disease.

title: Proliferating SPP1/MERTK-expressing macrophages in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
main_goals: To understand changes in IPF lung cell transcriptomes and gain insight into innate immune aspects of pathogenesis by investigating macrophage subpopulations and their role in myofibroblast activation.

title: Single-cell analysis of human B cell maturation predicts how antibody class switching shapes selection dynamics.
main_goals: This paper provides a comprehensive roadmap of human B cell maturation using single-cell transcriptomics and antibody repertoires. It defines gene expression, antibody repertoires, and clonal sharing of B cell states at single-cell resolution. The study dissects how antibody class-dependent gene expression influences B cell fate and function, highlighting the role of antibody isotype in selection dynamics.

title: High-resolution single-cell atlas reveals diversity and plasticity of tissue-resident neutrophils in non-small cell lung cancer.
main_goals: To dissect the NSCLC tumor microenvironment at high resolution using single-cell data, identify patient subtypes based on immune cell infiltration, associate cellular components with tumor histology and genotypes, and analyze tissue-resident neutrophils (TRNs) to uncover their subpopulations and plasticity. The study also aims to establish a TRN-derived gene signature associated with anti-PD-L1 treatment failure.

title: Subcellular knockout of importin β1 perturbs axonal retrograde signaling.
biological_context: Nerve injury response in sensory neurons
data_modalities_used: ['RNA, Messenger', 'Histology images', 'Axonal transport', 'Neuronal cell body transcriptional responses', 'Peripheral nerve injuries', 'Sciatic nerve']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of subcellular localization of mRNA in axons for retrograde signaling in response to nerve injury. It demonstrates that a specific 3' UTR directs axonal localization of Importin β1 mRNA and protein, and its subcellular knockout in axons impairs retrograde signaling and functional recovery.

title: Unravelling subclonal heterogeneity and aggressive disease states in TNBC through single-cell RNA-seq.
main_goals: This study investigates the subclonal heterogeneity and aggressive disease states in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) using single-cell RNA-sequencing. It reveals how intercellular gene expression heterogeneity correlates with genomic copy number changes and identifies a subpopulation associated with treatment resistance and metastasis, characterized by glycosphingolipid metabolism and innate immunity pathways.

title: Defining T Cell States Associated with Response to Checkpoint Immunotherapy in Melanoma.
main_goals: To identify factors associated with the success or failure of checkpoint therapy in melanoma. The study profiled immune cell transcriptomes to define T cell states and identify predictors and targets for enhancing immunotherapy.

title: Atlas of breast cancer infiltrated B-lymphocytes revealed by paired single-cell RNA-sequencing and antigen receptor profiling.
main_goals: To gain mechanistic insights into the functions and developmental dynamics of tumor-infiltrated immune cells, especially B-lymphocytes, by combining single-cell RNA-sequencing and antigen receptor lineage analysis. The study characterized triple-negative breast cancer infiltrated immune cells and reported an atlas of tumor-infiltrated B-lymphocytes. It identified B-cell heterogeneity, mature and memory characteristics, higher clonality, class switching recombination, and somatic hypermutations in tumor-infiltrated B-cells.

title: Defining the role of pulmonary endothelial cell heterogeneity in the response to acute lung injury.
main_goals: This study identifies multiple pulmonary endothelial cell (EC) populations in the mouse lung, including a novel population termed 'Car4-high' ECs. It characterizes their unique gene signature and potential reparative roles. The research also describes the emergence of proliferative ECs contributing to alveolar revascularization after influenza-induced acute lung injury.

title: CXCL9:SPP1 macrophage polarity identifies a network of cellular programs that control human cancers.
biological_context: Head and neck squamous cell carcinomas
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Polarity']
main_goals: This study examines tumor-to-tumor variation in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas to understand the rules governing intratumoral cellular programs and disease outcome. It identifies macrophage polarity, defined by CXCL9 and SPP1 expression, as a strong prognostic indicator. This polarity also reveals a coordinated network of pro- or antitumor variables that are spatially organized across all tumor-associated cell types.

title: Spatial and temporal diversity in genomic instability processes defines lung cancer evolution.
main_goals: This paper analyzes the spatial and temporal genomic changes during NSCLC evolution by sequencing distinct tumor regions. It reveals branched evolution, intratumor heterogeneity in copy number alterations and APOBEC activity, and shifts in mutation signatures over time in smokers. The findings suggest that regional driver mutations and heterogeneous genome instability processes contribute to treatment challenges in NSCLC.

title: Single-cell Stereo-seq reveals induced progenitor cells involved in axolotl brain regeneration.
main_goals: This paper uses Stereo-seq to capture spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomes of axolotl telencephalon during development and regeneration. It identifies an injury-induced ependymoglial cell cluster as a progenitor population for neurogenesis and uncovers spatially defined neurons that may regress to an immature state. The work provides mechanistic insights into vertebrate brain regeneration.

title: Single-cell analysis of human primary prostate cancer reveals the heterogeneity of tumor-associated epithelial cell states.
main_goals: This study uses single-cell RNA-sequencing to analyze prostate cancer microenvironments from various patient samples and organoids. It aims to characterize heterogeneous epithelial cell states, identify tumor-associated club cells, and compare ERG-negative and ERG-positive tumor cells. The findings offer insights into prostate carcinogenesis and diagnostically relevant information.

title: A topographic atlas defines developmental origins of cell heterogeneity in the human embryonic lung.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To create a comprehensive topographic atlas of early human lung development, define developmental origins of cell heterogeneity, and predict cell interactions within tissue niches. The atlas integrates single-cell RNA sequencing and spatially resolved transcriptomics into a web-based platform for interactive exploration.

title: A subcellular map of the human proteome.
main_goals: To create a comprehensive image-based map of subcellular protein distribution in human cells, the Cell Atlas, by integrating transcriptomics and immunofluorescence microscopy, validated by mass spectrometry. This map details the localization of 12,003 human proteins to 30 subcellular structures and defines the proteomes of 13 major organelles. It allows for the exploration of single-cell variations and provides a resource for refining protein-protein interaction networks and understanding cellular architecture.

title: A high-resolution transcriptomic and spatial atlas of cell types in the whole mouse brain.
biological_context: Whole adult mouse brain cell-type atlas
main_goals: This study reports a comprehensive, high-resolution transcriptomic and spatial cell-type atlas for the whole adult mouse brain. It combines scRNA-seq and MERFISH data to create a hierarchical classification of cell types and an online visualization platform. The findings reveal regional differences in cell-type organization, heterogeneity in neurotransmitter expression, and the role of transcription factors in defining cell types.
